div0.head: Σ

div1.head: Σαβάζιος
div1.sense: a Phyrgian deity, identified with Bacchus, Ar.:— τὰ Σαβάζια Bacchic orgies, Strab.

div1.head: σαβακός
div1.sense: shattered; metaph. enervated, Anth.

div1.head: σαβάκτης
div1.sense: a shatterer, destroyer, of a goblin who broke pots, Epic Hom.

div1.head: σαβαχθανί
div1.sense: a Chaldaean phrase, hast thou forsaken me? NTest.

div1.head: σαβαώθ
div1.sense: hosts, armies, NTest.

div1.head: σαββατίζω
div1.sense: to keep the Sabbath, Lxx.

div1.head: Σαββατισμός
div1.sense: a keeping of days of rest, NTest.

div1.head: Σάββατον
div1.sense: the Hebrew sabbath, i. e. rest, NTest.; also in pl. of the single day, heterocl. dat. pl. σάββασι (as if from σάββας), NTest.
a period of seven days, a week, μία τῶν σαββάτων the first day of the week, NTest.

div1.head: σαβοῖ
div1.sense: a cry at the feast of Sabazios, Dem.

div1.head: σάγαρις
div1.sense: a single edged axe or bill, a weapon used by the Scythian tribes, Hdt., Xen.

div1.head: σαγηναῖος
div1.sense: of or for a drag-net, Anth.

div1.head: σαγηνευτήρ
div1.sense: one who fishes with a drag-net, of a comb, τριχῶν σαγ. Anth., Plut.

div1.head: σαγηνεύω
div1.sense: to take fish with a drag-net (σαγήνη) , Luc.
metaph. to sweep as with a drag-net, i. e. to sweep the population off the face of a country by forming a line and marching over it, a Persian practice, Hdt., etc.: Pass., σαγηνευθεὶς ὑπʼ ἔρωτι Anth.

div1.head: σαγήνη
div1.sense: a large drag-net for taking fish, a seine, Ital. sagena, Luc., NTest.

div1.head: σαγηνοβόλος
div1.sense: one who casts a drag-net, a fisherman, Anth.

div1.head: σαγηνόδετος
div1.sense: attached to a drag-net, Anth.

div1.head: σαγή
div1.sense: a manʼs pack, baggage, αὐτόφορτος οἰκείᾳ σαγῇ, i. e. carrying his own baggage, Aesch.: generally, harness, equipment, Aesch., Eur.
= σάγμα II, a pack-saddle, Babr.

div1.head: σαγηφορέω
div1.sense: to wear a cloak, Strab.

div1.head: σάγμα
div1.sense: mostly in pl. covering: the covering of a shield, Eur., Ar.: a large cloak, Ar.
a pack-saddle, Strab., Plut.
a pile, ὅπλων Plut.

div1.head: σάγος
div1.sense: a coarse cloak, used by the Gauls, Polyb.

div1.head: Σαδδουκαῖοι
div1.sense: Sadducees, name of a Jewish sect, NTest.

div1.head: σαθρός
div1.sense: rotten, decayed, unsound, cracked, Plat., Dem.—adv., σαθρῶς ἱδρυμένος built on unsound foundations, Arist.
metaph., πρίν τι καὶ σαθρὸν ἐγγίνεσθαί σφι before any unsound thought comes into their heads, i. e. before they prove traitors, Hdt.; σ. λόγοι Eur.

div1.head: σαίνω
div1.sense: of dogs, to wag the tail, fawn, Od.; οὐρῆι ἔσηνε, of the dog Argus, Od.
metaph. to fawn, cringe, Pind., Aesch.
c. acc. pers. to fawn upon, Ar.: to pay court to, greet, Pind., Soph.; σα. μόρον to deprecate, shrink from death, Aesch.:—Pass., σαίνομαι ὑπʼ ἐλπίδος Aesch.
to beguile, cozen, deceive, Aesch.
in NTest., σαίνεσθαι ἐν ταῖς θλίψεσι seems to mean to be moved, disturbed.

div1.head: σαίρω
div1.sense: in perf. to draw back the lips and shew the teeth, to grin like a dog, Lat. ringi, σεσαρυῖα (Epic for σεσηρυῖα) Hes.; σεσηρώς Ar.:—in good sense, smiling, Theocr.:—the neut. is used in adv. sense, σεσᾱρὸς γελᾶν to laugh with open mouth, Theocr.; σεσηρὸς αἰκάλλειν, of a fox, Babr.
in pres. and aor1, to sweep a floor, Eur.
c. acc. rei, to sweep up or away, Soph.

div1.head: σακέσπαλος
div1.sense: wielding a shield, Il.

div1.head: σακεσφόρος
div1.sense: shield-bearing, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: σακκίον
div1.sense: a small bag, Xen.
sackcloth, mourning, Menand.

div1.head: σακκογενειοτρόφος
div1.sense: cherishing a huge beard, Anth.

div1.head: σάκκος
div1.sense: a coarse hair-cloth, sackcloth, Lat. cilicium, NTest.
anything made of this cloth, a sack, bag, Hdt., Ar.
a coarse beard, Ar.

div1.head: σάκος
div1.sense: a shield, Hom., etc. The earliest shields were of wicker-work or of wood, covered with ox-hides, and sometimes with metal-plates, (that of Ajax had seven hides and an eighth layer of metal); it was concave, so as to hold liquid, Aesch.

div1.head: σάκτας
div1.sense: a sack, Ar.

div1.head: σάκτωρ
div1.sense: a packer, Ἅιδου σάκτωρ who crowds the nether world (with dead men), Aesch.

div1.head: σακχυφάντης
div1.sense: one who weaves sackcloth, a sailmaker, Dem.

div1.head: σαλάκων
div1.sense: a word of uncertain origin, denoting a swaggerer, Arist.

div1.head: Σαλαμιναφέτης
div1.sense: betrayer of Salamis, Solon.

div1.head: Σαλαμίνιος
div1.sense: Salaminian, of or from Salamis, Hdt.
Σαλαμινία (sub. ναῦς) , ἡ, one of the Athen. sacred ships, Ar., Thuc.; v. πάραλος III.

div1.head: Σαλαμίς
div1.sense: Salamis, an island opposite Athens, Il., etc.
a town of Cyprus founded by Teucer of Salamis, Hhymn., Hdt.

div1.head: σαλάσσω
div1.sense: to overload, cram full, σεσαλαγμένος Anth.

div1.head: σαλεύω
div1.sense: to cause to rock, make to oscillate, shake to and fro, Eur., Anth.; σα. τοὺς ὄχλους to stir them up, NTest.:—Pass. to be shaken to and fro, totter, reel, χθὼν σεσάλευται Aesch.
intr. to move up and down, to roll, toss, as on the sea, Xen.:—metaph. to toss like a ship at sea, to be tempest-tost, be in sore distress, Soph., Eur.
of a ship also, to ride at anchor: metaph., σα. ἐπί τινι to ride at anchor on oneʼs friend, depend upon him, Plut.

div1.head: σάλος
div1.sense: any unsteady, tossing motion, of an earthquake, Eur.: the tossing or rolling swell of the sea, Eur.; so in pl., πόντιοι σάλοι Eur.
of ships or persons in them, a tossing on the sea, Soph.: —metaph. of the ship of the state, tempest-tossing, Soph.; σάλον ἔχειν to be in distress, Plut.

div1.head: σαλπιγγολογχυπηνάδαι
div1.sense: lancer-whiskered-trumpeters, Ar.

div1.head: σαλπιγκτής
div1.sense: a trumpeter, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: σάλπιγξ
div1.sense: a war-trumpet, trump, Il., Trag., etc.:—metaph., Πιερικὰ σ., of Pindar, Anth.
a trumpet-call, ap. Arist.

div1.head: σαλπίζω
div1.sense: to sound the trumpet, give signal by trumpet, Xen.: c. acc. cogn., σα. ῥυθμούς Xen.; cf. ἀνακλητικός: metaph., ἀμφὶ δὲ σάλπιγξεν οὐρανός heaven trumpeted around, of thunder as if a signal for battle, Il.:—impers., ἐπεὶ ἐσάλπιγξε (sc. ὁ σαλπιγκτής) when the trumpet sounded, Xen.

div1.head: Σάμαινα
div1.sense: a ship of Samian build, Plut.

div1.head: Σαμαρεία
div1.sense: Samaria, a city of Palestine

div1.head: Σαμαρείτης
div1.sense: a Samaritan, NTest., etc.;fem. -εῖτις, ιδος, NTest.

div1.head: σαμβύκη
div1.sense: a triangular musical instrument with four strings, Lat. sambuca, Arist.
an engine of like form used in sieges, Plut.

div1.head: σαμβυκιστής
div1.sense: a player on the sambuca:—fem. σαμβῡκίστρια, Plut.

div1.head: Σαμοθρᾴκη
div1.sense: Samothrace, an island near Thrace, the seat of the mysteries of the Cabiri, Hdt.:—the inhabitants were Σαμοθρήικες, Hdt.; adj. Σαμοθρᾴκιος, η, ον, Ionic -θρηίκιος, η, ον, Hdt.

div1.head: Σάμος
div1.sense: Samos, the name of several Greek islands:
an old name for Κεφαλληνία, Hom.
Σάμος Θρηικίη, Σαμοθρᾴκη, Il.
Samos, the large island over against Ephesus, Hhymn., etc.: hence adj. Σάμιος, η, ον, Hdt.

div1.head: σαμφόρας
div1.sense: a horse branded with the letter σάν (v. sub *s, s) , Ar.; cf. κοππατίας.

div1.head: σάνδαλον
div1.sense: a wooden sole, bound by straps round the instep and ankle, mostly in pl. sandals, Hhymn., etc.

div1.head: σανδαράκη
div1.sense: red or orange-coloured mineral, Arist.

div1.head: σανδαράκινος
div1.sense: of orange colour, Hdt.

div1.head: σανδαρακουργεῖον
div1.sense: a pit whence σανδαράκη is dug, Strab.

div1.head: σάνδυξ
div1.sense: a bright red colour, also called ἀρμένιον, Strab.

div1.head: σανίδιον
div1.sense: a small trencher, Ar.
like πινάκιον, a tablet, Aeschin.

div1.head: σανίδωμα
div1.sense: a planking, framework, Polyb.

div1.head: σανίς
div1.sense: a board, plank, Anth., etc.
anything made of planks:
a door, in pl. folding doors, Lat. fores, Hom.:—rare in sg., Eur.
a wooden platform, scaffold or stage, Od.: a shipʼs deck, Eur.
in pl. wooden tablets for writing on, Eur.:—at Athens, tablets on which were written public notices, Ar., etc.
a plank to which offenders were bound or nailed, Hdt.; so perh. in Od. 22. 174.

div1.head: σάος
div1.etym: as Posit., found only in the contr. form σῶς, σᾶ

div1.head: σαπρός
div1.sense: rotten, putrid, Theogn., Ar.; of fish, stale, rancid, τάριχος Ar.
generally, stale, worn out, Lat. obsoletus, Ar.:—of persons, Ar.
of wine, in good sense, mellow, Ar.

div1.head: σαπρότης
div1.sense: rottenness, putridity, Plat.

div1.head: σάπφειρος
div1.sense: a blue gem, the sapphire, or (as others think) lapis lazuli.

div1.head: σαργάνη
div1.sense: a plait, braid, Aesch.
a basket, NTest.

div1.head: σαρδάνιος
div1.sense: used of bitter or scornful laughter, σαρδάνιον γελᾶν (sc. γέλωτα) ; μείδησε σαρδάνιον he laughed a bitter laugh, Od.; so, ἀνεκάγχασε σαρδάνιον Plat.; ridere γέλωτα σαρδάνιον Cic.—Others write Σαρδόνιον, deriving it from Σαρδώ, because such laughter resembled the effect produced by a Sardinian plant, which screwed up the face of the eater, Plut.: (hence our form sardonic).

div1.head: Σάρδεις
div1.sense: Sardes, the capital of Lydia, dat. Σάρδεσι, Aesch.:—adj. Σαρδιᾱνός, Ionic -ηνός, ή, όν, Hdt.; and Σαρδιᾱνικός, ή, όν, Ar.

div1.head: σάρδιον
div1.sense: the Sardian stone, carnelian, Plat.

div1.head: σαρδόνιον
div1.sense: the rope sustaining the upper-edge of a hunting-net, Xen.

div1.head: σαρδόνυξ
div1.sense: the sardonyx, Anth.

div1.head: Σαρδώ
div1.sense: Sardinia, Hdt., Ar.; the obl. cases are sometimes Σαρδόνος, -όνι, -όνα (as if from Σαρδών) , Polyb.:—adj. Σαρδόνιος, η, ον, and Σαρδονικός, ή, όν, Hdt.

div1.head: σάρισα
div1.sense: the sarissa, a long pike used in the Macedonian phalanx, Polyb.

div1.head: σαρκάζω
div1.sense: to tear flesh like dogs, Ar.

div1.head: σαρκίζω
div1.sense: to strip off the flesh, scrape it out, Hdt.

div1.head: σαρκικός
div1.sense: fleshly, sensual, Anth.

div1.head: σάρκινος
div1.sense: of flesh, in the flesh, Theocr.
= σαρκικός, opp. to πνευματικός, NTest.
fleshy, corpulent, Plat.

div1.head: σαρκολιπής
div1.sense: forsaken by flesh, lean, Anth.

div1.head: σαρκοπαγής
div1.sense: compact of flesh, Anth.

div1.head: σαρκοφάγος
div1.sense: eating flesh, carnivorous, Arist.
λίθος σ. a limestone found at Assos in Troas, remarkable for consuming the flesh of corpses laid in it; coffins were made of it, and such a coffin was called a σαρκοφάγος, Juven.

div1.head: σαρκόω
div1.sense: to make to look like flesh, of a sculptor, Anth.

div1.head: σαρκώδης
div1.sense: fleshy, Xen., etc.; θεοὶ ἔναιμοι καὶ σαρκώδεες gods of flesh and blood, Hdt.

div1.head: σάρξ
div1.sense: flesh, Lat. caro, Hom., etc.: in pl. the flesh or muscles of the body, ἔγκατά τε σάρκας τε καὶ ὀστέα Hom.; so in Hes., Aesch., etc.:—so sometimes in sg., the flesh, the body, γέροντα τὸν νοῦν, σάρκα δʼ ἡβῶσαν φέρει Aesch.
the flesh, as opp. to the spirit, NTest.; also for manʼs nature generally, NTest.; πᾶσα σάρξ all human kind, NTest.

div1.head: σάρον
div1.sense: a broom, besom, Anth.

div1.head: σαρόω
div1.sense: to sweep clean, NTest.:— Pass., perf. part. σεσαρωμένος NTest.

div1.head: Σαρπηδών
div1.sense: Σαρπεδον.

div1.head: Σατάν
div1.sense: Satan, i. e. an adversary, enemy: name for the Devil, NTest.

div1.head: σατίνη
div1.sense: a war-chariot, chariot, car, Hhymn., Eur.

div1.head: σάτον
div1.sense: a Hebrew measure, 1/30 of a κόρος, about 1 1/2 modii or 24 sextarii, NTest.

div1.head: σατραπεία
div1.sense: a satrapy, the office or province of a satrap, Hdt., Xen.

div1.head: σατραπεύω
div1.sense: to be a satrap, exercise the authority of one, Xen.
c. gen. to rule as a satrap, σ. τῆς χώρας Xen.;—also c. acc., Xen.

div1.head: σατράπης
div1.sense: a satrap, viceroy, Lat. satrapa, Xen.

div1.head: σάτρα
div1.sense: gold, Ar.

div1.head: σάττω
div1.etym: The Root is !σαγ, as in perf. pass., σάγμα, σάγος, σάγη.
div1.sense: to pack or load, properly of putting the packsaddle on beasts of burthen: hence,
of warriors, in Pass. to be fully armed, Hdt.; χαλκῶι σεσαγμένοι Theocr.
to furnish with all things needful, σάξαντες ὕδατι τὴν ἐσβολήν having furnished the entrance (into Egypt) with water, Hdt.

generally, to load heavily, fill quite full of a thing: Pass., c. gen., πημάτων σεσαγμένος laden with woes, Aesch.; τριήρης σεσαγμένη ἀνθρώπων Xen.:—also c. dat. to fill full with a thing, Luc.; so in Mid., χρυσῶι σαξάμενος πήρην Luc.:—Pass., σεσαγμένος πλούτου τὴν ψυχήν having his fill of riches, Xen.
to pack close, press down, Xen.

div1.head: σατυρικός
div1.sense: like a Satyr, Plut.
of or resembling the Satyric drama, Plat., Arist.:— σατυρικόν, οῦ, a Satyric drama, Xen.

div1.head: Σάτυρος
div1.sense: a Satyr, companion of Bacchus, Hes., etc.: the Satyrs were represented with pointed ears, snub nose, goatʼs tail, and budding horns: later, goatsʼ legs were added. They differed from Pan and Fauns by the want of real horns.

a play in which the chorus consisted of Satyrs, the Satyric drama (not to be confounded with the Rom. Satura or Satira), Ar. It formed the fourth piece of a Tragic tetralogy: the only Satyric drama extant is the Cyclops of Eur.

div1.head: σαυλόομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to swagger, dance affectedly, Eur.

div1.head: σαυλοπρωκτιάω
div1.sense: to walk in a swaggering way, Ar.

div1.head: σαῦλος
div1.sense: swaggering, straddling, Hhymn., etc.

div1.head: σαύνιον
div1.sense: a javelin, Menand., Strab.

div1.head: σαύρα
div1.sense: a lizard, Lat. lacerta, Hdt.

div1.head: σαυροκτόνος
div1.sense: lizard-killer, epith. of Apollo, Plin.

div1.head: Σαυρομάτης
div1.sense: a Sarmatian, Hdt.:—fem. Σαυρομάτις, Hdt.

div1.head: σαῦρος
div1.sense: = σαύρα, Lat. lacertus, Hdt.

div1.head: σαυρωτήρ
div1.sense: a spike at the butt-end of a spear, by which it was stuck into the ground, Il., Hdt.

div1.head: σάφα
div1.sense: clearly, plainly, assuredly, of a surety, with Verbs of knowing, σάφα οἶδα, σάφα εἰδώς, Hom.; also in Trag., σάφʼ οἶδα, σάφʼ ἴσθι, etc.; σάφʼ ἴσθι, ὅτι . . Ar.; also withVerbs of speaking, σάφα εἰπεῖν Hom., Pind.

div1.head: σαφηγορίς
div1.sense: speaking clearly or truly, Anth.

div1.head: σαφήνεια
div1.sense: distinctness, perspicuity, Plat., etc.

div1.head: σαφηνέω
div1.sense: to tell distinctly, Aesch.

div1.head: σαφηνής
div1.sense: τὸ σαφανές the plain truth, Pind. adv. -νῶς, Theogn., Aesch.; Ionic -νέως, Hdt.

div1.head: σαφηνίζω
div1.sense: to make clear or plain, point out clearly, explain, Aesch., Xen.

div1.head: σαφηνιστικός
div1.sense: explanatory, τινος of a thing, Luc.

div1.head: σαφής
div1.sense: clear, plain, distinct, manifest, Hhymn., Aesch., etc.; τὸ σαφές the clear truth, Eur., etc.
of persons, Aesch., Eur.: of oracles and prophets, as in Virgil certus Apollo, sure, unerring, Soph.

adv. σᾰφῶς, Ionic -έως, plainly, distinctly, well, σ. φράσαι, δεικνύναι, εἰδέναι, Hdt., Attic:— certainly, manifestly, Aesch., etc.; ἦν σ. was manifest, Aesch.:—comp. -έστερον, Sup. -έστατα, Aesch., etc.

div1.head: σάω
div1.sense: to sift, bolt, Hdt., in 3rd pl. σῶσι.

div1.head: σβέννυμι
div1.sense: to quench, put out, Lat. extinguere, Hdt., Pind.
generally, to quench, quell, check, σβ. χόλον, μένος Il.; ὕβριν Simon.; κύματα Ar., etc.
Pass. σβέννυμαι (with intr. tenses of Act., v. supr.), to be quenched, go out, Lat. extingui, of fire, Il.: metaph. of men, to become extinct, die, Anth.
generally, to be quelled or lulled, of wind, Od.

div1.head: σβεστήριος
div1.sense: serving to quench fire, Thuc.

div1.head: σεαυτοῦ
div1.sense: of thyself, only in gen., dat. and acc. sg., masc. and fem., Hdt., Attic; ἐν σαυτῷ γενοῦ contain thyself, Soph.:—in pl. separated, ὑμῶν αὐτῶν, etc.: and orig. it was separated in sg., as in Hom., who always says σοὶ αὐτῷ, σʼ αὐτόν.

div1.head: σεβάζομαι
div1.sense: to be afraid of, τι Il.

div1.head: σέβασμα
div1.sense: an object of awe or worship, NTest.

div1.head: σέβας
div1.etym: only in nom., acc., and voc. sg.
div1.sense: reverential awe, a feeling of awe, Hom., etc.:—generally, reverence, worship, Trag.; c. gen. objecti, Διὸς σέβας reverence for Jove, Aesch.
the object of awe, holiness, majesty, Eur.: periphr. for persons, σ. κηρύκων, i. e. Hermes, Aesch.
an object of wonder, a wonder, Hhymn., Soph.: an honour conferred on one, as the arms of Achilles on Ulysses, Soph.

div1.head: Σεβαστιάς
div1.sense: = Lat. Augusta, the Empress, Anth.

div1.head: σεβαστός
div1.sense: reverenced, august: used to render the imperial name Augustus, Strab., NTest.

div1.head: σεβίζω
div1.sense: fut. Attic σεβιῶ: aor1 ἐσέβισα:—like σεβάζομαι, to worship, honour, Lat. revereor, Pind., Trag.; καινὰ λέχη σ. to devote oneself to a new wife, Eur.: —also in Mid., οὐδὲν σεβίζει ἀράς standest not in awe of curses, Aesch.; aor1 pass. part., ἁγὼ σεβισθείς Soph.

div1.head: σέβομαι
div1.sense: Dep.
to feel awe or fear before God, to feel religious awe, feel shame, Il., Ar.; σεφθεῖσα awe-stricken, Plat.: c. inf. to dread or fear to do a thing, Aesch., Plat.
c. acc. pers. to honour with pious awe, to worship, Lat. veneror, Pind., Hdt., etc.:—then, to do homage to, pay honour or respect to, Trag.

div1.head: σέβω
div1.etym: used only in pres. and imperf.
div1.sense: to worship, honour, Pind., Attic; εὖ σέβειν τινά for εὐσεβεῖν εἴς τινα, Eur.:—c. inf., ὑβρίζειν οὐ σέβω, i. e. τὸ ὑβρίζειν, I do not respect, approve of insolence, Aesch.; τὸ μὴ ἀδικεῖν σέβοντες Aesch.—then, σέβομαι as Pass. to be reverenced, Soph.
absol. to worship, be religious, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: Σειληνός
div1.sense: Silenus, companion of Bacchus, Hdt.; father of the Satyrs, Eur.

div1.head: Σειληνώδης
div1.sense: like Silenus, Plat.

div1.head: σειραῖος
div1.sense: joined by a cord or band, ἵππος σ. σειραφόρος, Soph.
of cord, twisted, βρόχοι Eur.

div1.head: σειρά
div1.sense: a cord, rope, string, band, Hom.; σ. χρυσείη a cord or chain of gold, Il.
a cord with a noose, like the lasso, used by the Sagartians and Sarmatians to entangle and drag away their enemies, Hdt.

div1.head: σειραφόρος
div1.sense: led by a rope, Hdt.

σειραφόρος (sc. ἵππος) , a horse which draws by the trace only (being harnessed by the side of the yoke-horses, ζύγιοι) , a trace-horse, outrigger: metaph., sometimes a yoke-mate, coadjutor, Aesch.; sometimes for one who has light work, Aesch.

div1.head: Σειρήν
div1.sense: a Siren: in pl. Σειρῆνες, αἱ, the Sirens, mythical sisters on the south coast of Italy, who enticed seamen by their songs, and then slew them, Od. Hom. only knows of two, whence Epic dual. gen. Σειρήνοιιν.
metaph. a Siren, deceitful woman, Eur.: the Siren charm of eloquence, Aeschin.

div1.head: σειριόκαυτος
div1.sense: scorched by the sun or dog-star, Anth.

div1.head: σείριος
div1.sense: the scorcher, name of the dog-star, Lat. Sirius, which marks the season of greatest heat, i. e. Aug. 24 to Sept. 24, Hes., Eur.; called Σείριος κύων Aesch.; Σείριος ἀστήρ Hes.

div1.head: σειρομάστιξ
div1.sense: a knotted scourge, Eccl., Byz.

div1.head: σεισάχθεια
div1.sense: a shaking off of burdens, Plut.: a name for the disburdening ordinance of Solon., by which all debts were lowered, Solon.

div1.head: σεισίχθων
div1.sense: earth-shaker, epith. of Poseidon, Pind.

div1.head: σεισματίας
div1.sense: of earthquakes, σεισμ. τάφος a burial in the ruins caused by an earthquake, Plut.

div1.head: σεισμός
div1.sense: a shaking, shock, γῆς, χθονὸς σ. an earthquake, Eur.; absol., Hdt., Attic
generally, a shock, agitation, commotion, Plat., NTest.

div1.head: σειστός
div1.sense: shaken, Ar.

div1.head: σείω
div1.sense: to shake, move to and fro, Hom.; σε. ἔγχος, μελίην to shake the poised spear, Il.; κάρα σει., in sign of discontent, Soph.:—also, σείειν τῆι οὐρᾶι Xen.
of earthquakes, which were attributed to Poseidon, Hdt.; absol., σείσας by an earthquake, Ar.: impers., σείει there is an earthquake, Thuc., Xen.
metaph. to shake, agitate, disturb, Pind., Soph.
in Attic, to accuse falsely or spitefully, so as to extort hush-money, Ar.; cf. Lat. concutio.
Pass. to shake, heave, quake, of the earth, Il., Hdt.:—metaph. to be shaken to its foundation, τὸ τερπνὸν πίτνει σεσεισμένον Pind.; οἷς ἂν σεισθῆι θεόθεν δόμος Soph.
generally, to move to and fro, Il.: Pass., ὀδόντες ἐσείοντο his teeth were loosened, Hdt.; σεισθῆναι σάλωι Eur.
Mid. to shake something of oneʼs own, Theocr., Anth.
like Pass. to shake oneself, to shake, Il.

div1.head: σελαγέω
div1.sense: to enlighten, illume:—Pass. to beam brightly, Ar.

div1.head: σελαηγενέτης
div1.sense: father of light, Anth.

div1.head: σέλας
div1.sense: a bright flame, blaze, light, σ. πυρός Il.; alone, Il.:— lightning, a flash of lightning, Il., Hdt., etc.:— a torch, Hhymn.:— the flash of an angry eye, Aesch.: metaph., ἔρωτος σ. Theocr.

div1.head: σελασφόρος
div1.sense: light-bringing, Aesch.

div1.head: σελευκίς
div1.sense: a cup, named after Seleucus, Plut.

div1.head: σεληναίη
div1.etym: poetic for σελήνη, Ar.; Doric σελαναία Eur.

div1.head: σεληναῖος
div1.sense: lighted by the moon, σ. νύξ a moonlight night, Orac. ap. Hdt., Anth.

div1.head: σελήνη
div1.sense: the moon, Lat. luna, Hom.; σ. πλήθουσα the full- moon, Il.; νουμηνία κατὰ σελήνην, i. e. by the lunar month, Thuc.; πρὸς τὴν σελήνην by moonlight, Xen.; so, εἰς τὴν σ. Aeschin.:— τὴν σ. καθαιρεῖν, Hor.ʼs lunam deducere, of witches, Ar.; δεκάτῃ σελήνῃ in the tenth moon (i. e. month), Eur.
as fem. prop. n., Selene, the goddess of the moon, Hes., etc.

div1.head: σεληνιάζομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to be moonstruck, i. e. epileptic, NTest.

div1.head: σεληνιακός
div1.sense: of or for the moon, lunar, Plut.

div1.head: σελιδηφάγος
div1.sense: devouring leaves of books, of a bookworm, Anth.

div1.head: σέλινον
div1.sense: parsley, Lat. apium, Hom., etc.:—with its leaves victors at the Isthmian and Nemean games were crowned, Pind.:—from its being planted in garden borders came the prov., οὐδʼ ἐν σελίνῳ οὐδʼ ἐν πηγάνῳ "tis scarcely begun yet, " Ar.

div1.head: σελίς
div1.sense: a plank: metaph. a leaf of papyrus: — generally, the page of a book, Anth.

div1.head: Σελλοί
div1.sense: the Selli, guardians of the oracle of Zeus at Dodona, bound to live a rough, austere life, Il., Soph.,

div1.head: σέλμα
div1.sense: the deck of a ship, Hhymn., Eur.
in pl. σέλματα, rowing-benches, Lat. transtra, Trag.
generally, a seat, throne, Aesch.
σέλματα πύργων scaffolds behind the parapet, on which the defenders of the wall stood, Aesch.
logs of building timber, Strab.

div1.head: σεμίδαλις
div1.sense: the finest wheaten flour, Lat. simila, similago, Ar.

div1.head: σεμνολογέω
div1.sense: to speak gravely and solemnly, Aeschin.:—also as Dep. σεμνολογέομαι, to talk in solemn phrases, Dem.

div1.head: σεμνολόγος
div1.sense: a grave or solemn talker, Dem.

div1.head: σεμνόμαντις
div1.sense: a grave and reverend seer, Soph.

div1.head: σεμνοποιέω
div1.sense: to make august, to magnify, Strab.

div1.head: σεμνοπροσωπέω
div1.sense: to assume a grave, solemn countenance, Ar.

div1.head: σεμνός
div1.sense: revered, august, holy, awful:
properly of certain gods; at Athens esp. of the Furies, σεμναὶ θεαί or Σεμναί, Trag.; σ. τέλη their rites, Trag.
then of things divine, Hhymn., Trag.; σ. βίος a life devoted to the gods, Eur.; σεμνὰ φθέγγεσθαι εὔφημα, Aesch.; τὸ σ. holiness, Dem.
of human beings, reverend, august, solemn, stately, majestic, Hdt., Attic
of things, Aesch., etc.; οὐδὲν σ. nothing very wonderful, Arist.; σεμνόν ἐστι, c. inf., ʼtis a noble, fine thing to . . , Plat.

in bad sense, proud, haughty, Trag.: —in contempt or irony, solemn, pompous, grand, Aesch., etc.; σεμνὸν βλέπειν to look grave and solemn, Eur.; ὡς σ. οὑπίτριπτος how grand the rascal is! Ar.; ὡς σ. ὁ κατάρατος Ar.
adv. -νῶς, Eur., etc.: comp. -ότερον, Xen.

div1.head: σεμνόστομος
div1.sense: solemnly spoken, Aesch.

div1.head: σεμνότης
div1.sense: gravity, solemnity, dignity, majesty, Eur., Xen.
in bad sense, solemnity, pompousness, Luc.; of a girl, prudery, Eur.

div1.head: σεμνότιμος
div1.sense: reverenced with awe, Aesch.

div1.head: σεμνόω
div1.sense: to make solemn or grand, to exalt, magnify, embellish, Hdt.

div1.head: σεμνύνω
div1.sense: = σεμνόω to exalt, magnify, Hdt., Attic:—Pass. to be in high repute, Plat.
Mid. to be grave, solemn, to affect a grave and solemn air, Eur., Ar.; σ. ἐπί τινι to be proud of a thing, to pique oneself on it, Dem.; ἔν τινι Dem.

div1.head: σε
div1.sense: adverbial Suffix, denoting motion towards, e. g. ἄλλοσε to some other place.

div1.head: σεπτός
div1.sense: august, Aesch.

div1.head: σέρις
div1.sense: a kind of endive or chicory, Anth.

div1.head: σέρφος
div1.sense: a kind of gnat or winged ant, Ar.

div1.head: σεσοφισμένως
div1.etym: adverb from part. perf. pass. of σοφίζομαι
div1.sense: cunningly, Xen.

div1.head: σεῦτλον
div1.etym: Ionic and late Attic for τεῦτλον.

div1.head: σεύω
div1.etym: note that we have ἐσσύμενος not ἐσσυμένος.
div1.sense: to put in quick motion: to drive, hunt, chase away, Hom.; so in Mid., Il.
to set on, let loose at, κύνας σε. ἐπὶ συΐ Il.:—c. inf. to urge on, Od.
of things, to throw, hurl, Il.
Pass. and Mid. to run, rush, dart or shoot along, Hom., Trag.:—c. inf. to hasten, speed to do a thing, Il.
metaph. to be eager, have longings, Od.; v. ἐσσύμενος.

div1.head: σηκάζω
div1.sense: to shut up in a pen: Pass., σήκασθεν (for ἐσηκάσθησαν) κατὰ Ἴλιον were cooped up in Ilium, Il.; ἐν αὐλίῳ σηκασθέντες Xen.

div1.head: σηκίς
div1.sense: a housekeeper, porteress, Ar.

div1.head: σηκίτης
div1.sense: kept in the fold, sucking, of a lamb, Theocr.

div1.head: σηκοκόρος
div1.sense: cleaning a byre or pen, a herdsman, Od.

div1.head: σηκός
div1.sense: a pen, fold, for lambs, kids, calves, Hom., Hes.; σ. δράκοντος the dragonʼs den, Eur.
a sacred enclosure, chapel, shrine, Soph., Eur.
a sepulchre, burial-place, Simon.
the trunk of an old olive-tree, Lys.

div1.head: σηκόω
div1.sense: to weigh, balance, Plut.

div1.head: σήκωμα
div1.sense: in the balance, σμικρὸν τὸ σὸν σ. προστίθης slight is the weight that you throw into the scale, Eur.
= σηκός II, a sacred enclosure, Eur.

div1.head: σημαία
div1.sense: a standard, Polyb.:— a band under one standard, the Roman manipulus, Polyb.

div1.head: σημαίνω
div1.sense: to shew by a sign, indicate, make known, point out, Hom., etc.
absol. to give signs, make signals, Il., Trag.

to give a sign or signal to do a thing, Il.; c. inf., Hdt., etc.; μὴ σημήναντός σου without any order from you, Plat.:—c. gen. to bear command over, τινός or ἐπί τισι Hom.: absol. to give orders, Hom.; σημαίνων σημάντωρ, Soph.

in war, to give the signal of attack, Thuc.; ση. τῆι σάλπιγγι Xen.; ση. ἀναχώρησιν to make signal for retreat, Thuc.:—impers., σημαίνει (sc. ὁ σαλπιγκτής) signal is given, τοῖς Ἕλλησι ὡς ἐσήμηνε when signal was given for the Greeks to attack, Hdt.; ἐσήμαινε πάντα παραρτέεσθαι signal was given to make all ready, Hdt.
to signify, indicate, announce, declare, Eur., Hdt., Attic
generally, to signify, interpret, explain, Hdt., Aesch.; absol., σήμαινε tell, Soph.
= σφραγίζω, to stamp with a sign or mark, to seal, Lat. obsignare, mostly in Mid., Xen.:—Pass., εὖ σεσημάνθαι to be well sealed up, Ar.; τὰ σεσημασμέναι, opp. to τὰ ἀσήμαντα, Dem.
Mid. σημαίνομαι, like τεκμαίρομαι, to give oneself a token, i. e. conclude from signs, conjecture, Soph.
to mark for oneself, σημαίνεσθαι βύβλωι (sc. βοῦν), i. e. by sealing a strip of byblus round his horn, Hdt.

div1.head: σημαιοφόρος
div1.sense: Lat. signifer, a standard-bearer, Polyb.

div1.head: σημαντήριον
div1.sense: a mark or seal upon anything to be kept, Aesch.

div1.head: σημαντρίς
div1.sense: σημαντρὶς γῆ, clay used for sealing, like our wax, Hdt.

div1.head: σήμαντρον
div1.sense: a seal, Hdt., Eur.; metaph., δεινοῖς σημάντροισιν ἐσφραγισμένοι, i. e. wounded, Eur.

div1.head: σημάντωρ
div1.sense: one who gives a signal, a leader, commander, Hom.; of a horse, a driver; of a herd, a herdsman, Il.: a subordinate officer, Hdt.
an informer, guide, indicator, Anth.

div1.head: σῆμα
div1.sense: a sign, mark, token, Hom., etc.; the star on a horseʼs forehead, Il.
a sign from heaven, an omen, portent, Hom., etc.
generally, a sign to do or begin something, Od.; a watchword, Eur.; a battle-sign, signal, Eur.
the sign by which a grave is known, a mound, cairn, barrow, Lat. tumulus, Hom., etc.:—generally, a grave, tomb, Hdt., Attic

a token by which any oneʼs identity was certified: the σήματα λυγρά of Bellerophon were pictorial, not written, tokens (v. γράφω init.), Il.:— the mark on the lot of Ajax, Il.: the device or bearing on a shield, Aesch.; the seal impressed on a letter, Soph.
a constellation, Il., Eur.

div1.head: σηματόεις
div1.sense: full of tombs, Anth.

div1.head: σηματουργός
div1.sense: one who makes devices for shields, Aesch.

div1.head: σημειογράφος
div1.sense: a shorthand writer, Plut.

div1.head: σημεῖον
div1.sense: a sign, a mark, token, Hdt., Attic
a sign from the gods, an omen, Soph., Plat.: esp. of the constellations, Eur.
a sign or signal to do a thing made by flags, Hdt.; αἴρειν, κατασπᾶν τὸ σ. to make or take down the signal for battle, Thuc.; τὰ σημεῖα ἤρθη the signals agreed upon were made, Thuc.
an ensign or flag, on the admiralʼs ship, Hdt.; on the generalʼs tent, Xen.:—then, generally, a standard, ensign, Eur.: hence, a boundary, limit, Dem.
a device upon a shield, Hdt., Eur.; upon ships, a figure-head, Ar.
a signal, watchword, Thuc.
in reasoning, a sign or proof, Ar., Thuc., etc.:— σημεῖον δέ: or σημεῖον γάρ: (to introduce an argument) this is a proof of it, Dem., etc.

div1.head: σημειόω
div1.sense: to mark (by milestones), Polyb.
Mid. to interpret as a sign, Strab.

div1.head: σημειώδης
div1.sense: marked, remarkable, Strab.

div1.head: σήμερον
div1.sense: to-day, Hom., Pind.:—the common Attic form was τήμερον, Ar., etc.; εἰς τήμερον Plat.; ἡ τ. ἡμέρα Dem.

div1.head: σημικίνθιον
div1.sense: the Lat. semicinctium, an apron or kerchief, NTest.

div1.head: σημόθετος
div1.sense: having a mark set or affixed, Anth.

div1.head: σηπεδών
div1.sense: rottenness, putrefaction, Plat.

div1.head: σηπία
div1.sense: the cuttle-fish, which when pursued darkens the water by ejecting a liquid, Ar.

div1.head: σήπω
div1.sense: to make rotten or putrid, make to fester, of a serpentʼs poison, Aesch.
metaph. to corrupt, waste, Plat.
Pass., the perf. σέσηπα being used in pres. sense for σήπομαι: aor2 ἐσάπην short ᾰ]:— to be or become rotten, to rot, moulder, of dead bodies, Il.; of timber, Hdt., Il.
of live flesh, to mortify, Hdt., Plat.

div1.head: σῆραγξ
div1.sense: a hollow rock, cave, Plat.; of a lionʼs den, Theocr.

div1.head: σηρικός
div1.sense: Seric, silken, Luc.:—Subst., σηρικόν, or σιρικόν, οῦ, a silken robe, silk, NTest.

div1.head: Σήρ
div1.sense: the Seres, an Indian people from whom the ancients got silk, Strab.

div1.head: σησαμαῖος
div1.sense: made of sesame, Luc.

div1.head: σησαμῆ
div1.sense: a sesame pudding, Ar.

div1.head: σησάμη
div1.sense: sesame, a plant, from the fruit of which (σήσαμον) an oil was pressed.

div1.head: σησάμινος
div1.sense: made of sesame, Xen.

div1.head: σησαμόεις
div1.sense: of sesame:—as Subst. (contr.) σησαμοῦς, a sesame-cake, Ar.

div1.head: σήσαμον
div1.sense: the seed or fruit of the sesame-plant (σησάμη) , Hdt., Ar.
= σησάμη, Ar., Xen.

div1.head: σησαμότυρον
div1.sense: a mess of sesame and cheese, Batr.

div1.head: σής
div1.sense: a moth which eats woollen stuff, Lat. tinea, Ar.:—metaph. for a bookworm, Anth.

div1.head: Σηστός
div1.sense: Sestos, a town on the European side of the Hellespont, over against Abydos, Il.

div1.head: σητόβρωτος
div1.sense: eaten by moths, NTest.

div1.head: -σθα
div1.sense: an ancient ending of 2 pers. sg. act., in Hom. and other Poets, mostly in subj., as ἐθέλῃσθα, ἔχῃσθα, εἴπῃσθα, rarely in opt. as κλαίοισθα. In Attic it was retained in some irreg. Verbs, ἦσθα, οἶσθα, ᾔδησθα.

div1.head: σθεναρός
div1.sense: strong, mighty, Il., Eur.:—comp. σθεναρώτερος Soph.

div1.head: σθένος
div1.sense: strength, might, Il., Pind.:—c. inf., σθ. πολεμίζειν strength to war, Il.; σθ. ὥστε καθελεῖν Eur.; σθένει by force, Soph.; λόγῳ τε καὶ σθένει both by right and might, Soph.; so, ὑπὸ σθένους Eur.; παντὶ σθένει with all oneʼs might, Thuc.
strength, might, of all kinds moral as well as physical, σθένος τῆς ἀληθείας Soph.; ἀγγέλων σθ. their might or authority, Aesch.
a force of men, like δύναμις, Il., Soph.
metaph., like Lat. vis for copia, a quantity, profusion, Pind.
periphr., like βίη, ἴς, μένος, as σθένος Ἰδομενῆος, Ὠρίωνος, for Idomeneus, Orion, themselves, Il., Hes.

div1.head: σθένω
div1.sense: to have strength or might, be strong or mighty, Soph., Eur.; σθ. χερί, ποσί to be strong in hand, in foot, Soph., Eur.; σθένοντος ἐν πλούτῳ Soph.; τοσοῦτον σθένει Soph.; ὅσονπερ ἂν σθένῃ Soph.; οἱ κάτω σθένοντες they who have power below, Eur.
c. inf. to have strength or power to do, be able, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: σιαγών
div1.sense: the jawbone, jaw, Soph.

div1.head: σίαλον
div1.sense: spittle, saliva, Xen., etc.

div1.head: σίαλος
div1.sense: a fat hog, with or without σῦς, Hom.

div1.head: Σίβυλλα
div1.sense: a Sibyl, prophetess, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: Σιβύλλειος
div1.sense: Sibylline, Plut.

div1.head: Σιβυλλιάω
div1.sense: to play the Sibyl: metaph. to be like an old Sibyl, old womanish, Ar.

div1.head: Σιβυλλιστής
div1.sense: a believer in the Sibyl, a seer, diviner, Plut.

div1.head: σιβύνη
div1.sense: a hunting spear, a spear, pike, Anth.

div1.head: σιγάζω
div1.sense: to bid one be silent, τινά Xen.

div1.head: σιγαλέος
div1.sense: silent, still, Anth.

div1.head: σιγαλόεις
div1.sense: glossy, glittering, shining, splendid, Hom.
div1.etym: From σίαλος, with γ inserted, and ι made long metri grat.

div1.head: σῖγα
div1.sense: silently, σῖγα ἔχειν to be silent, Soph.; κάθησο σῖγα Ar.; alone, σῖγα hush! be still! Aesch.:—the public crier proclaiming silence said σῖγα πᾶς (sc. ἔστω) Ar.
under oneʼs breath, in a whisper, secretly, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: σιγάς
div1.sense: silent, Aesch.

div1.head: σιγάω
div1.sense: to be silent or still, to keep silence, Hdt., Attic; σίγα, hush! be still! Hom.:—Pass., τί σεσίγηται δόμος; why is the house hushed? Eur.
trans. to hold silent, to keep secret, Hdt., Aesch., etc.:—Pass. to be kept silent or secret, Lat. taceri, Hdt., Eur., etc.; ἐσιγήθη σιωπή silence was kept, Eur.

div1.head: σιγηλός
div1.sense: disposed to silence, silent, mute, Soph.; τὰ σιγηλά silence, Eur.

div1.head: σιγή
div1.sense: silence, σιγὴν ἔχειν to keep silence, Hdt.; σιγὴν ποιεῖσθαι to make silence, Hdt.; σιγὴν φυλάσσειν Eur.:—in pl., σιγαὶ ἀνέμων Eur.
σιγῇ, as adv. in silence, Hom.; also like σῖγα, as an exclam., σιγῇ νυν (sc. ἔστε) be silent now! Od.;also, in an under tone, in a whisper, Hdt.; σιγῇ βουλεύεσθαι Xen.
secretly, σιγῇ ἔχειν τι to keep it secret, like σιωπᾶν, Hdt.; σιγᾷ καλύψαι, στέγειν, κεύθειν Pind., Soph.
c. gen., σιγῇ τινος unknown to him, Hdt., Eur.

div1.head: σιγητέος
div1.sense: one must be silent, Eur.

div1.head: σίγλος
div1.sense: the Hebr. shekel, a weight and coin, = 4 Attic δραχμαί, NTest.
the Persian σ. was = 7 1/2 Attic ὀβολοί, Xen.

div1.head: σ
div1.sense: Σ, ς, σίγμα, τό, indecl., a semi-vowel, eighteenth letter of the Gr. Alph.: as numeral σʹ 200, but ͵σ 200, 000.

beside the form Σ, it was written as a semicircle Ϲ. In the written character, final ϲ became ς from which must be distinguished the character ϛʹ 6. There was also a Doric name σάν [ᾰ] (cf. σαμ-φόρας) , which appeared at the end of the alphabet as σαμπί or σαμπῖ, ϡ, 900.
dialectic and other changes:
Aeolic and Ionic into δ, as ὀδμή ἴδμεν for ὀσμή ἴσμεν.
in Aeolic and Doric, and in Poets, ς was often doubled, as ὅσσος μέσσος ὀπίσσω for ὅσος μέσος ὀπίσω, and in fut. and aor. 1 forms, as δαμάσσω ὀλέσσω, etc. for δαμάσω ὀλέσω, etc.
ς sometimes passed into πτ or vice versa, as πέσσω and πέπτω, ὄψομαι (*ὄπτω) and ὄσσομαι, ἐνίσσω and ἐνίπτω.

Doric into ξ, in fut. and aor1 of Verbs, with their deriv. Nouns, as ἐργάξομαι χείριξις for ἐργάσομαι χείρισις:—so in Ionic, διξός τριξός for δισσός τρισσός; and in old Attic, the prep. σύν, with all its Compds., was written ξύν.
Attic ς and σς sometimes passed into ψ, cf. Ψ ψ III.
in Aeolic, as in Lat., ς represents the aspirate, Σαλμυδησσός Ἁλμυδησσός, σῦς (Lat. sus) ὗς, ἅλς sal, ἕξ sex, ἑπτά septem, ἕρπω serpo, ὕλη sylva.
prefixed to words beginning with μ and τ, μύραινα σμύραινα, μικρός σμικρός, τέγος στέγω, Lat. tego; more rarely before κ and φ, σκίδναμαι κίδναμαι, σφάλλω fallo, σφενδόνη funda.
ς was inserted in the middle of words before θ, esp. by Poets in the 1 pers. pl. pass. and mid., as τυπτόμεσθα for τυπτόμεθα; so ὄπισθεν for ὄπιθεν.
conversely, the Lacon. used to throw out ς between two vowels, writing Μῶα for Μοῦσα.
ς changed into ρ, Doric and Attic, when another ρ goes before, as ἄρρην for ἄρσην, θάρρος for θάρσος.
Lacon., ς is substituted for θ, as σιός Ἀσάνα παρσένος for θεός Ἀθήνη παρθένος.
Doric, σδ for ζ, as μασδός τράπεσδα for μαζός τράπεζα.
ς is appended to οὕτω ἄχρι μέχρι before a vowel.

div1.head: σιγύνης
div1.sense: Cyprian word for a spear, Hdt.
σιγύνης among the Ligyes near Marseilles was used for κάπηλος, Hdt.
the Σιγῦναι were a people on the Middle Danube, Hdt.

div1.head: σιδηρεία
div1.sense: a working in iron, Xen.

div1.head: σιδηρεῖα
div1.sense: iron-works, iron-mines, Arist.

div1.head: σιδήρεος
div1.note: σῐδήρεος, α, Ionic η, ον, Epic σιδήρειος, η, ον
div1.sense: made of iron or steel, iron, Lat. ferreus, Hom., etc.; χεὶρ σιδηρᾶ a grappling-iron, Thuc.:— σιδήρειος ὀρυμαγδός, i. e. the clang of arms, Il.; σιδήρεος οὐρανός the iron sky, the firmament, which the ancients held to be of metal, Od.

metaph., σιδήρεος ἐν φρεσὶ θυμός a soul of iron, i. e. hard as iron, Hom.; οἱ κραδίη σιδηρέη Od.; σοί γε σιδήρεα πάντα τέτυκται thou art iron all! Od.:—of Hercules, the ironside, Simon.; ὦ σιδήρεοι O ye ironhearted! Aeschin.
σιδάρεοι, οἱ, a Byzantine iron coin, always in Doric form, Ar.

div1.head: σιδηρεύς
div1.sense: a worker in iron, a smith, Xen.

div1.head: σιδήριον
div1.sense: an implement or tool of iron, σιδηρίων ἐπαΐειν to feel iron, not to be proof against it, Hdt.; θερμὰ σιδήρια hot irons, Hdt.

div1.head: σιδηρίτης
div1.sense: of iron, σ. πόλεμος iron war, Pind.
ἡ σιδηρῖτις λίθος the loadstone, Strab.

div1.head: σιδηροβρώς
div1.sense: iron-eating, Soph.

div1.head: σιδηροδάκτυλος
div1.sense: iron-fingered, Anth.

div1.head: σιδηρόδετος
div1.sense: iron-bound, ἐν ξύλῳ σιδηροδέτῳ, i. e. in the stocks, Hdt.

div1.head: σιδηροκμής
div1.sense: slain by iron, i. e. by the sword, used with the neut. dat. βοτοῖς, Soph.

div1.head: σιδηρομήτωρ
div1.sense: mother of iron, Aesch.

div1.head: σιδηρονόμος
div1.sense: distributing with iron, i. e. with the sword, Aesch.

div1.head: σιδηρόνωτος
div1.sense: iron-backed, Eur.

div1.head: σιδηρόπλαστος
div1.sense: moulded of iron, Luc.

div1.head: σιδηρόπληκτος
div1.sense: smitten by iron, Aesch.

div1.head: σιδηρόσπαρτος
div1.sense: sown or produced by iron, Luc.

div1.head: σίδηρος
div1.sense: iron, Lat. ferrum, Hom., etc.: iron was the last of the metals brought into common use by the Greeks: hence it is πολύκμητος, wrought with much toil, Hom.: and was of high value, pieces of it being given as prizes, Il. It mostly came from the north and east of the Euxine, Σκύθης σ. Aesch.
like Lat. ferrum, anything made of iron, an iron tool or weapon, a sword or knife, an axe-head, etc., Hom., etc.
a place for selling iron, a smithy, a cutlerʼs shop, Xen.

div1.head: σιδηροτέκτων
div1.sense: a worker in iron, Aesch.

div1.head: σιδηροτόκος
div1.sense: producing iron, Anth.

div1.head: σιδηροτομέω
div1.sense: to cut or cleave with iron, Anth.

div1.head: σιδηρουργεῖον
div1.sense: iron-works, Strab.

div1.head: σιδηροφορέω
div1.sense: to bear iron, wear arms, go armed, Thuc.:—Mid., Thuc.
Mid. to go with an armed escort, Plut.

div1.head: σιδηροφόρος
div1.sense: bearing arms or tools, Anth.

div1.head: σιδηρόφρων
div1.sense: of iron heart, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: σιδηρόχαλκος
div1.sense: of iron and copper, τομή Luc.

div1.head: σιδηροχάρμης
div1.sense: fighting (or perhaps exulting) in iron, epith. of war-horses, Pind.

div1.head: σιδηρόω
div1.sense: to overlay with iron, Luc.: —Pass., ἐσεσιδήρωτο ἐπὶ μέγα καὶ τοῦ ἄλλου ξύλου iron had been laid over a great part of the rest of the wood, Thuc.

div1.head: σίδιον
div1.sense: pomegranate-peel, Ar.

div1.head: Σιδόνες
div1.sense: men of Sidon, Il.; also Σιδόνιοι Od.

div1.head: Σιδονίηθεν
div1.sense: from Sidon, Il.

div1.head: Σιδών
div1.sense: Sidon, one of the oldest cities of Phoenicia, Od., Hdt.: hence adj. Σῑδόνιος, η, ον, Il., Aesch.; Σιδονίη (sc. γῆ Od.; Σιδόνιοι men of Sidon, Od.; Σιδώνιος, Hdt., Attic; fem. Σιδωνιάς, άδος, Eur.

div1.head: σίζω
div1.sense: to hiss, of hot metal plunged into water, to which is compared the hissing of the Cyclopsʼ eye when the burnt stake was thrust into it, Od.; so, of a pot boiling, Ar.; of fish frying, Ar.

div1.head: Σιθωνία
div1.sense: Sithonia, a part of Thrace, Hdt.

div1.head: Σικανία
div1.sense: Sicania, i. e. the part of Sicily near Agrigentum: also = Σικελία, Od.

div1.head: Σικανός
div1.sense: a Sicanian, Thuc.: adj. Σικανικός, ή, όν, Thuc.

div1.head: σικάριος
div1.sense: the Lat. sicarius, an assassin, NTest.

div1.head: Σικελία
div1.sense: Sicily, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: Σικελίδης
div1.sense: Sicilian, Theocr.

div1.head: Σικελικός
div1.sense: Sicilian, Ar., etc.

div1.head: Σικελιώτης
div1.sense: a Sicilian Greek, as distinguished from a native Σικελός, Thuc.

div1.head: Σικελός
div1.sense: Sicilian, of or from Sicily, Lat. Siculus, Od., Eur., etc.
Σικελοί, οἱ, the Siceli, the old inhabitants of Sicily, Od., Hdt.

div1.head: σίκερα
div1.sense: a fermented liquor, NTest.

div1.head: σίκιννις
div1.sense: the Sicinnis, a dance of Satyrs used in the Satyrical drama, Eur., Luc.

div1.head: σικύα
div1.sense: a fruit like the cucumber or gourd, perh. the melon, Arist.
a cupping-glass, because it was shaped like the gourd, cucurbita, Arist.

div1.head: σίκυος
div1.sense: a cucumber or gourd, Ar.

div1.head: Σικυώνια
div1.sense: (sc. ὑποδήματα) , τά, Sicyonians, a kind of womenʼs shoes, Luc.

div1.head: Σικυωνόθε
div1.sense: of or from Sicyon, Pind.

div1.head: Σικυών
div1.sense: Sicyon, Il.; also Xen.;—as adj., γῆ Σ. Anth.:—regul. adj. Σικυώνιος, η, ον Sicyonian, Thuc.

div1.head: σίλι
div1.sense: = κρότων or κίκι, called in Hdt. σιλλικύπριον, τό.

div1.head: σιλλαίνω
div1.sense: to insult, mock, jeer, banter, Luc.

div1.head: σίλλος
div1.sense: squint-eyed, Luc.
a satirical poem or lampoon in hexam. verse, such as those written by Timon of Phlius, who was called ὁ σιλλο-γράφος.

div1.head: σίλλυβος
div1.sense: a parchment-label (Lat. index) appended to the outside of a book, Cic.

div1.head: σίλουρος
div1.sense: a large river fish, Lat. silurus, perh. the sheat? Juvenal.

div1.head: σίλφη
div1.sense: an insect, blatta, Luc.: also = tinea, a book-worm, Luc., Anth.

div1.head: σίλφιον
div1.sense: Lat. laserpitium, a plant, used in food and medicine, assafoetida, Solon., Hdt.

div1.head: σιλφιοφόρος
div1.sense: bearing silphium, Strab.

div1.head: σιμβλεύω
div1.sense: intr. to grow in a hive, of honey, Anth.

div1.head: σιμβλήϊος
div1.sense: of or from the hive: fem. σιμβληίς, ίδος, Anth.

div1.head: σίμβλος
div1.sense: a beehive, Hes., Theocr.
metaph. any store or hoard, Ar.

div1.head: Σιμόεις
div1.sense: the river Simois, Il.; contr. Σιμοῦς, οῦντος, Hes.; adj. Σιμοέντιος, contr. Σιμούντιος, α, ον, or ος, ον, Eur.; poet. fem. Σιμοεντίς, ίδος, Eur.; also Σιμοείσιος, ον, Strab.

div1.head: σιμός
div1.sense: snub-nosed, flat-nosed, like the Tartars (or Scythians, as the Ancients called them), Hdt., etc.: —of the nose, snub, flat, opp. to γρυπός, Xen.;—as this kind of nose gives a pert expression, σιμά as adv. means sneeringly, Anth.
metaph. bent upwards, up-hill, πρὸς τὸ σιμὸν διώκειν to pursue uphill, Xen.:—generally, hollow, concave, Xen.

div1.head: Σῖμος
div1.sense: masc. prop. n. flat-nose, Anth.

div1.head: σιμότης
div1.sense: the shape of a snub nose, snubbiness, Xen.
metaph., τὴν σ. τῶν ὀδόντων the upward curve of a boarʼs tusks, Xen.

div1.head: σιμόω
div1.sense: to turn up the nose, and generally, to bend upwards.

div1.head: σίμωμα
div1.sense: the upturned bow of a ship, Plut.

div1.head: σιναμωρέω
div1.sense: to ravage or destroy wantonly, Hdt.:—Pass. to be treated wantonly, Ar.

div1.head: σιναμωρία
div1.sense: mischievousness, Arist.

div1.head: σινάμωρος
div1.sense: mischievous, c. gen. rei, τῶν ἑωυτοῦ σ. ruining his own affairs, Hdt.

div1.head: σίναπι
div1.sense: mustard, NTest.

div1.head: σινδών
div1.sense: sindon, a fine cloth, a kind of cambric or muslin, (prob. derived from Ἰνδός, Sind), Hdt.; σινδὼν βυσσίνη, used for mummy-cloth, Hdt.: generally, fine linen, Soph., Thuc.
a muslin garment, Luc.

div1.head: σινιάζω
div1.sense: = σήθω, to sift, winnow, NTest.

div1.head: σίνις
div1.sense: a ravager, plunderer, Aesch.:—as adj. destroying, σ. ἀνήρ as an example of a γλῶσσα, Poeta ap. Arist.
as prop. n., Σίνις, the destroyer, a famous robber of the Isthmus of Corinth, called ὁ Πιτυοκάμπτης, Eur., Xen.

div1.head: σίνομαι
div1.sense: to do one harm or mischief, to plunder, Od.; to destroy, Od.; to pillage or waste a country, to waste or destroy the crops, Hdt.
generally, to hurt, harm, damage, Hes., Hdt.: in war, to injure, harass, Hdt., Xen.

div1.head: σίνος
div1.sense: hurt, harm, mischief, injury, Hdt.
of things, a mischief, bane, plague, Aesch.

div1.head: σίντης
div1.sense: destructive, ravenous, of wild beasts, Il.

div1.head: Σίντιες
div1.sense: the Sintians, early inhabitants of Lemnos, who were pirates, Hom.

div1.head: Σίνων
div1.sense: Sinon, i. e. the Mischievous, the Greek who persuaded the Trojans to receive the wooden horse, Soph.

div1.head: Σινωπεύς
div1.sense: an inhabitant of Sinope, Xen., etc.

div1.head: Σινώπη
div1.sense: Sinope, a town of Paphlagonia on the Black Sea, Hdt.

div1.head: Σινωπίς
div1.sense: the country of Sinope, Strab.

div1.head: σίον
div1.sense: the water-parsnep or marsh-wort, Theocr.

div1.head: σιπύη
div1.sense: a meal-tub, meal-jar, flour bin, Ar.

div1.head: σίραιον
div1.sense: new wine boiled down, Lat. defrutum, Ar.

div1.head: σιρικόν
div1.sense: silk, v. σηρικός.

div1.head: σιρός
div1.sense: a pit or vessel for keeping corn, Dem.

div1.head: σίσυμβρον
div1.sense: mint or thyme, Ar., Anth.

div1.head: σισύρα
div1.sense: a cloak of goats-hair, which served as a garment by day and a coverlet by night, Ar.

div1.head: σισυριγχίον
div1.sense: a plant of the Iris kind, Theophr.

div1.head: σίσυρνα
div1.sense: a garment of skin, Hdt.

div1.head: σισυρνοφόρος
div1.sense: wearing a coat of skin, Hdt.

div1.head: Σισύφειος
div1.sense: Sisyphian, Eur., etc.; fem. Σισυφίς, Theocr.

div1.head: Σίσυφος
div1.etym: Prob. a redupl. form of σοφός (with Aeolic υ for ο the crafty.)
div1.sense: a king of Corinth, noted as the craftiest of men, punished in the shades below, Hom., etc.

div1.head: σιταγωγέω
div1.sense: to convey corn, Luc.

div1.head: σιταγωγία
div1.sense: conveyance of corn, Luc.

div1.head: σιταγωγός
div1.sense: conveying or transporting corn, σ. πλοῖα provision-ships, Hdt.; σ. ναῦς Thuc.

div1.head: σιτέομαι
div1.sense: to take food, eat, Od., Hdt.
c. acc. to feed on, eat, Hdt.: metaph., σ. ἐλπίδας Aesch.; τὴν σοφίαν Ar.

div1.head: σιτευτός
div1.sense: fed up, fatted, Xen., NTest.

div1.head: σιτεύω
div1.sense: to feed, fatten, Hdt.:—Pass. to feed on, to eat, Plut.

div1.head: σιτηγέω
div1.sense: = σιταγωγέω, to convey or transport corn, Dem.: to import corn, παρὰ τινος Dem.

div1.head: σιτηγία
div1.sense: the conveyance or importation of corn, Dem.

div1.head: σιτηρέσιον
div1.sense: provisions, victuals, esp. of soldiersʼ provision-money, Xen., Dem.:—at Rome, σιτ. ἔμμηνον a monthly allowance of grain to the poorer citizens, Lat. tessera frumentaria, Plut.

div1.head: σιτηρός
div1.sense: of corn, μέτρα σ. corn-measures, Arist.

div1.head: σίτησις
div1.sense: an eating, feeding, ἐπὶ σιτήσει for home consumption, Hdt.; σ. ἐν Πρυτανείῳ public maintenance in the Prytaneum, Ar., Plat.
food, Hdt.

div1.head: σιτίζω
div1.sense: to feed, nourish, fatten, Hdt., Ar.:—Pass. = σιτέομαι, to eat, Theocr.

div1.head: σιτικός
div1.sense: of wheat or corn, σ. τροφή Strab.; ὁ σ. νόμος lex frumentaria, Plut.

div1.head: σιτίον
div1.sense: grain, corn: food made from grain, bread, ποιεῖσθαι σιτία ἀπὸ ὀλυρέων to feed off spelt, Hdt.
generally, food, victuals, provisions, Hdt.; σιτία ἡμερῶν τριῶν three daysʼ provision, of soldiers, Ar.; σιτία καὶ ποτά meat and drink, Plat., Xen.
τἀν Πρυτανείῳ σιτία public maintenance in the Prytaneum, Ar.; cf. σίτησις.
rarely food for dogs, Xen.

div1.head: σιτιστός
div1.etym: verb. adj. of σιτίζω, σιτευτός, NTest.

div1.head: σιτοδεία
div1.sense: want of corn or food, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: σιτοδόκος
div1.sense: holding food, Anth.

div1.head: σιτοδοτέω
div1.sense: to furnish with provisions:—Pass. to be provisioned or victualled, Thuc.

div1.head: σιτολογέω
div1.sense: to collect corn, to forage, Polyb.

div1.head: σιτολογία
div1.sense: a collecting of corn, a foraging, Plut.

sense.trans: a collector of corn or provisions.

div1.head: σιτομέτρης
div1.sense: one who measures out corn: a magistrate who had to inspect the corn measures, Arist.

div1.head: σιτομετρία
div1.sense: the office of σιτομέτρης, Plut.

div1.head: σιτομέτριον
div1.sense: a measured portion of corn, NTest.

div1.head: σιτονόμος
div1.sense: dealing out corn or food, σ. ἐλπίς the hope of getting food, Soph.

div1.head: σιτοποιέω
div1.sense: to prepare corn for food, to make bread, Eur.; σ. τινί to give victuals to any one, Xen.:—Mid. to prepare food for oneself, take food, Xen.

div1.head: σιτοποιία
div1.sense: breadmaking, the preparation of food, Xen.

div1.head: σιτοποιικός
div1.sense: for breadmaking, Xen.

div1.head: σιτοποιός
div1.sense: σ. ἀνάγκη the task of grinding and baking, Eur.
as Subst. one that ground the corn in the handmill, Thuc.; mostly fem. a baking-woman, Hdt.; γυναῖκες σ. Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: σιτοπομπία
div1.sense: the conveyance or convoy of corn, Dem.

div1.head: σῖτος
div1.sense: corn, grain, comprehending both wheat (πυρός) and barley (κριθή) , Od., Thuc.; σ. ἀληλεσμένος ground corn, Hdt., Thuc.
food made from grain, bread, as opp. to flesh-meat, Od., Hdt.; σῖτον ἔδοντες, a general epith. of men as opp. to beasts, Od.; hence of savages, who eat flesh only, οὐδέ τι σῖτον ἤσθιον Hes.
in wider sense, meat, as opp. to drink, σῖτος ἠδὲ ποτής Hom.; σῖτα καὶ ποτά Hdt., etc.
rarely of beasts, food, fodder, Hes., Eur.
in Attic Law, the public allowance of grain made to widows and orphans, Dem.

div1.head: σιτοφάγος
div1.sense: eating corn or bread, Od., Hdt.

div1.head: σιτοφόρος
div1.sense: carrying corn or provisions, Hdt.

div1.head: σιτοφύλακες
div1.sense: corn-inspectors, Athenian officers, originally three in number, but afterwards ten in the City and five in Peiraeeus, who registered imports of corn, and saw that the corn-measures were right, Dem.

div1.head: σίττα
div1.sense: a cry of drovers to their flocks; when ἀπό follows, to call them off; sht! chit! when πρός, to lead them on, Theocr.

div1.head: σιτώνης
div1.sense: a buyer of corn, a commissary for buying it, Dem.

div1.head: σιτωνία
div1.sense: purchase of corn, the office of σιτώνης, Dem.

div1.head: σιφλός
div1.sense: crippled, maimed, Lat. mancus.

div1.head: σιφλόω
div1.sense: to maim, cripple, bring to misery, Il.

div1.head: Σίφνιος
div1.sense: Siphnian, Hdt.

div1.head: Σίφνος
div1.sense: Siphnos, one of the Cyclades, Hdt.

div1.head: σίφων
div1.sense: a tube, pipe, siphon, used for drawing wine out of the cask, Hippon.:— a service-pipe for water in houses, Strab.

div1.head: σιωπάω
div1.sense: to be silent or still, keep silence, Hdt., Attic; φησὶν σιωπῶν, i. e. his silence gives consent, Eur.
trans. to hold silent, keep secret, not to speak of, Xen., etc.:—Pass. to be kept silent or secret, σιγῶσʼ ὧν σιωπᾶσθαι χρεών keeping secret things which ought to be kept secret, Eur.

div1.head: σιωπηλός
div1.sense: silent, still, quiet, Eur.

div1.head: σιωπή
div1.sense: silence, Soph., Eur., etc.; σιωπὴν ποιεῖν Xen.; ἦν σ. there was a hush or calm, Soph.
the habit of silence, Dem.
dat. σιωπῇ as adv., in silence, Hom., Attic

div1.head: σιωπητέος
div1.sense: to be passed over in silence, Luc.
σιωπητέον, one must pass over in silence, Luc.

div1.head: σκάζω
div1.sense: to limp, halt, Il.: metaph., σκ. πρὸς τὴν θεραπείαν Luc.
ὁ σκάζων, also χωλίαμβος, the iambic verse of Hippon., being a regular senarius, with a spondee or trochee in the last place, Anth.

div1.head: σκαιός
div1.sense: Lat. scaevus, left, on the left hand or side, σκαιῇ (sc. χειρί) with the left hand, Il.; χειρὶ σκαιῇ Hes.
western, westward, for the Greek auspex turned his face northward, and so had the west on his left; hence, Σκαιαὶ πύλαι the west gate of Troy, Il.; σκαιὸν ῥίον the western headland, Od.
unlucky, ill-omened, mischievous (because birds of ill omen appeared on the left or in the west, birds of good omen on the right or in the East), Hdt., Soph.
metaph. of persons, like French gauche, lefthanded, awkward, clumsy, Hdt., Eur., etc.

div1.head: σκαιότης
div1.sense: lefthandedness, awkwardness, Hdt., Soph., etc.

div1.head: σκαιουργέω
div1.sense: to behave amiss, Ar.

div1.head: σκαίρω
div1.sense: to skip, frisk, Hom.

div1.head: σκαλαθυρμάτιον
div1.sense: a petty quibble, Ar.

div1.head: σκαλεύς
div1.sense: a hoer, Xen.

div1.head: σκαλεύω
div1.sense: to stir, poke, ἄνθρακας Ar., Luc.

div1.head: σκαληνός
div1.sense: uneven, unequal, ἀριθμὸς σκ. an odd number, Plat.; τρίγωνον σκ. a triangle with unequal sides, Arist.; of a path, uneven, Anth.

div1.head: σκάλλω
div1.sense: to stir up, hoe, Hdt.

div1.head: σκαλμός
div1.sense: the pin or thole to which the Greek oar was fastened by a thong (τροπωτήρ) , Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: σκάλοψ
div1.sense: the digger, i. e. the mole, Ar.

div1.head: Σκαμάνδριος
div1.sense: Scamandrian, Il., Soph., etc.

div1.head: Σκάμανδρος
div1.sense: the Scamander, the famous river of Troy, ὃν Ξάνθον καλέουσι θεοί, ἄνδρες δὲ Σκάμανδρον Il.

div1.head: σκανδάληθρον
div1.sense: the stick in a trap on which the bait is placed, and which, when touched by the animal, springs up and shuts the trap, the trap-spring: metaph., σκανδάληθρʼ ἱστὰς ἐπῶν setting word- traps, i. e. words which oneʼs adversary will catch at, and be caught himself, Ar.

div1.head: σκανδαλίζω
div1.sense: to make to stumble, give offence to any one, τινά NTest.:—Pass. to take offence, NTest.

div1.head: σκάνδαλον
div1.sense: a trap or snare laid for an enemy, NTest.:—metaph. a stumbling-block, offence, scandal, NTest.

div1.head: σκάνδιξ
div1.sense: chervil (i. e. chaerophyllum), Ar.

div1.head: σκαπάνη
div1.sense: a digging tool, mattock, Theocr., Anth.
the act of digging, Anth.

div1.head: σκαπτήρ
div1.sense: a digger, delver, Hom. ap. Arist.

div1.head: σκαπτός
div1.sense: dug: that may be dug: —Σκαπτὴ ὕλη a district in Thrace, Hdt.

div1.head: σκάπτω
div1.sense: to dig, delve, μοχθεῖν καὶ σκ. Ar.; proverb., σκάπτειν οὐκ ἐπίσταμαι Ar.
c. acc.,
to dig the ground, Xen., Luc.
to dig about, φυτὰ σκ. (as we say to hoe turnips), Hhymn.: metaph. to dig up, Eur.
σκ. τάφρον to dig a trench, Thuc.:—Pass., τὰ ἐσκαμμένα scores to mark a leap, metaph., ὑπὲρ τὰ ἐσκαμμένα ἅλλεσθαι to overleap the mark, Plat.

div1.head: σκαρδαμύσσω
div1.sense: to blink, wink, Eur., Xen.

div1.head: σκαριφησμός
div1.sense: a scratching up, σκαριφισμοὶ λήρων small criticisms, petty quibbles, Ar.

div1.head: σκατοφάγος
div1.sense: eating dirt, Ar.

div1.head: σκαφεύς
div1.sense: a digger, delver, ditcher, Eur.

div1.head: σκάφη
div1.sense: anything dug or scooped out,
a trough or tub, basin or bowl, Hdt.
a light boat, skiff, Ar.
proverb., τὴν σκάφην σκάφην λέγειν "to call a spade a spade, " to call things by their right names, Luc.

div1.head: σκαφίδιον
div1.sense: a small skiff, Strab.

div1.head: σκαφίς
div1.sense: Dim. of σκάφη: esp.
a bowl, milk-pail, Od.:— a pot for honey, Theocr.
a small boat, skiff, canoe, Anth.
a shovel, Anth.

div1.head: σκάφος
div1.sense: a digging, hoeing, σκάφος οἰνέων the time for hoeing vines, Hes.

div1.head: σκάφος2
div1.sense: the hull of a ship, Lat. alveus, Hdt., Trag.:—generally, a ship, Aesch., Ar., etc.
= σκαφίς II, Anth.

div1.head: σκεδάννυμι
div1.sense: to scatter, disperse, Hom.
Pass. to be scattered, to disperse, of men, Hdt., Thuc.; of the rays of the sun, Aesch.; of a report, to be spread abroad, Hdt.

div1.head: σκέδασις
div1.sense: a scattering, Od.

div1.head: σκεθρός
div1.sense: exact, careful: adv., -ῶς Aesch.

div1.head: σκελετός
div1.sense: dried up, withered: as Subst. σκελετός, οῦ, a dried body, mummy, Anth., Plut.

div1.head: σκελετώδης
div1.sense: like a mummy, Luc.

div1.head: σκέλλω
div1.sense: to dry, dry up, make dry, parch, Il.
Pass., σκέλλομαι, with intr. perf. act. ἔσκληκα, to be parched, lean, dry, v. κατασκέλλομαι.

div1.head: σκέλος
div1.sense: the leg from the hip downwards, Hdt., etc.; πρυμνὸν σκέλος the ham or buttock, Il.:—as a military phrase, ἐπὶ σκέλος πάλιν χωρεῖν, ἀνάγειν to retreat with the face towards the enemy, Lat. pedetentim, Eur., Ar.
metaph., τὰ σκέλη the legs, i. e. the two long walls between Athens and Peiraeus, Strab.; τὰ μακρὰ σκ. Plut.

div1.head: σκέμμα
div1.sense: a subject for speculation, a question, Plat.
speculation, Plat.

div1.head: σκεπάζω
div1.sense: to cover, shelter, Xen.

div1.head: σκέπανον
div1.sense: a covering, Anth.

div1.head: σκεπανός
div1.sense: sheltered or sheltering, Anth.

div1.head: σκέπαρνον
div1.sense: a carpenterʼs axe or adze, used for smoothing the trunks of trees, different from the πέλεκυς, Od.

div1.head: σκέπασμα
div1.sense: a covering, shelter, Plat.

div1.head: σκέπας
div1.sense: a covering, shelter, ἐπὶ σκέπας in or under shelter, Od.; σκέπας ἀνέμοιο shelter from the wind, Od.; nom. and acc. pl. σκέπα, Hes.

div1.head: σκεπάω
div1.sense: to cover, shelter, ἀνέμων σκεπόωσι κῦμα (Epic for σκεπάουσι) they ward off (provide shelter against) the sea raised by the wind, Od.; κόρυν σκεπάουσιν ἔθειραι Theocr.

div1.head: σκέπη
div1.sense: a covering, shelter, protection, Xen.:—c. gen., ἐν σκέπῃ τοῦ πολέμου under shelter from war, Hdt.; ὑπὸ τὴν Ῥωμαίων σκέπην under their protection, Polyb.

div1.head: σκεπτέος
div1.sense: one must reflect or consider, Ar., Thuc., etc.
σκεπτέος, η, ον, to be considered, examined, Antipho.

div1.head: σκεπτικός
div1.sense: reflective: οἱ σκεπτικοί, the Sceptics or philosophers who asserted nothing, but only opined, Cic. opinatores, Luc.

div1.head: σκέπτομαι
div1.etym: in Att. σκοπῶ or σκοποῦμαι are used in the present
div1.sense: to look about, look carefully, followed by prep. εἰς, Od., Eur.:—c. acc. to look after, watch, Il., Hdt., Attic:—absol. to look out, reconnoitre, Hdt.; σκέψαι look, Aesch.; σκέψασθε look out, Ar.
of the mind, to look to, view, examine, consider, think on, Soph., Thuc., etc.:—σκέψασθε δέ: only consider, Thuc.
to think of beforehand, premeditate, Dem.
perf. also in pass. sense, ἐσκεμμένα things well-considered, Thuc.; σκοπεῖτε οὖν. Answ. ἔσκεπται Plat.; so 3 fut. pass. ἐσκέψεται Plat.

div1.head: σκερβόλλω
div1.sense: to scold, abuse, σκ. πονηρά to use foul abuse, Ar.

div1.head: σκευαγωγέω
div1.sense: to carry away goods and chattels, Dem., Aeschin.

div1.head: σκευαγωγός
div1.sense: conveying goods:— τὰ σκ. baggage-wagons, Plut.; transport vessels, Strab.
as Subst. a baggage-master, Xen.

div1.head: σκευάζω
div1.sense: to prepare, make ready, esp. to prepare or dress food, Hdt., Ar.; σκ. ἔκ τινος περικόμματα to make mincemeat of him, Ar.:—Mid. to prepare for oneself, Eur., Plat.
generally to make ready, Hhymn.; σκ. ἡδονάς to provide, procure, Plat.:—Mid., like μηχανάομαι, to contrive, bring about, Hdt.
of persons, to furnish, supply:—Pass., σιτίοισι εὖ ἐσκευασμένος Hdt.; ποταμοῖσι Σκύθαι ἐσκευάδαται Hdt.
to dress up, dress out, Hdt., Ar., etc.:— Pass., ἐσκευασμένοι fully accoutred, Thuc.; of things, τὰ προπύλαια τύποισι ἐσκευάδαται are decorated with figures, Hdt.

div1.head: σκευάριον
div1.sense: a small vessel or utensil, Ar.:—implements of gaming, Aeschin.

div1.head: σκευασία
div1.sense: a preparing, dressing, Plat.

div1.head: σκευαστέος
div1.sense: one must prepare to do a thing, c. inf., Ar.

div1.head: σκευαστός
div1.sense: prepared by art, artificial, Plat.

div1.head: σκευή
div1.sense: equipment, attire, apparel, dress, Lat. apparatus, Hdt., Soph., etc.
a fashion, style of dress or equipment, Hdt., Thuc.
tackle, as of a net, Pind.

div1.head: σκευοθήκη
div1.sense: a tool-chest, arms-chest, Aeschin.

div1.head: σκευοποιέω
div1.sense: to fabricate, Plut.

div1.head: σκευοποίημα
div1.sense: in pl. the dress of a tragic actor, Plut.

div1.head: σκευοποιός
div1.sense: a maker of masks and other stage-properties, Ar.

div1.head: σκεῦος
div1.sense: a vessel or implement of any kind, Ar., Thuc., etc.:—pl. in collective sense, furniture, house-gear, utensils, chattels, Ar.:—esp. of military accoutrements, equipment, Thuc., Xen.: baggage, luggage, Lat. impedimenta, Ar., Xen.:— the tackling or gear of ships, Xen., NTest.
an inanimate object, a thing, Plat.
metaph., τὸ σκεῦος, the body, as the vessel of the soul, NTest.; σκεῦος ἐκλογῆς a chosen vessel, of St. Paul, NTest.

div1.head: σκευοφορέω
div1.sense: to carry baggage, Xen.:—Pass. to have oneʼs baggage carried, Plut.

div1.head: σκευοφορικός
div1.sense: of or for baggage-carrying, Xen.; βάρος σκ. the load for one animal, a beastʼs load, Xen.

div1.head: σκευοφόρος
div1.sense: carrying σκεύη, αἱ σκ. κάμηλοι the baggage- camels, Hdt.; τὰ σκ. (sc. κτήνη) the beasts of burden in an army, Thuc., etc.
as Subst., of persons, a baggage-carrier, porter, Ar.; οἱ σκ. the sutlers, camp-followers, Hdt., Thuc., etc.

div1.head: σκευοφυλακέω
div1.sense: to watch the baggage, Plut.

div1.head: σκευωρέομαι
div1.sense: Dep.
to look after the baggage (τὰ σκεύη) : hence, generally, to examine throughly, ransack it, Plut.
to fabricate, make up, Dem.; with a sense of fraud or intrigue, Dem.:—absol. to act knavishly, Dem.

div1.head: σκευώρημα
div1.sense: a fabrication, fraud, Dem.

div1.head: σκευωρία
div1.sense: attention to baggage: hence, generally, great care, excessive care, Arist.
fabrication, knavery, intrigue, Dem.

div1.head: σκέψις
div1.sense: a viewing, perception by the senses, Plat.
speculation, consideration, Plat.; νέμειν σκέψιν to take thought of a thing, Eur.; ἐνθεὶς τῇ τέχνῃ σκέψιν Ar.; σκ. περί τινος or τι inquiry into, speculation on a thing, Plat.
hesitation, doubt (v. σκεπτικός), Anth.

div1.head: σκηνάω
div1.sense: = σκηνέω, Xen.
σκηνάομαι Dep., with perf. and plup. pass., to dwell, live, Plat.; ἐσκηνημένοι in covered carriages (v. σκήνη III), Ar.; ἱερά, ἐν οἷς ἐσκήνηντο in which they found harbourage, Thuc.
c. acc., σκηνησάμενος καλύβην having built him a hut or cottage, Thuc.

div1.head: σκηνέω
div1.sense: to be or dwell in a tent, to be encamped, Xen.: generally, to be quartered or billeted, ἐν οἰκίαις Thuc.; ἐν κώμαις, κατὰ τὰς κώμας Xen.; σκ. εἰς τὰς κώμας to go to the villages and quarter themselves there, Xen.

div1.head: σκήνημα
div1.sense: a dwelling-place, Xen.: in pl. a nest, Aesch.

div1.head: σκηνή
div1.sense: a covered place, a tent, Hdt., Soph., etc.: —in pl. a camp, Lat. castra, Aesch., Xen.
generally, a dwelling-place, house, temple, Eur.

a wooden stage for actors, Plat.:—in the regular theatre, the σκηνή was a wall at the back of the stage, with doors for entrance and exit; the stage (in our sense) was προσκήνιον or λογεῖον, the sides or wings παρασκήνια, and the wall under the stage, fronting the orchestra, ὑποσκήνια.
οἱ ἀπὸ σκηνῆς, the actors, players, Dem.
τὸ ἐπὶ σκηνῆς μέρος that which is actually represented on the stage, Arist.; τὰ ἀπὸ τῆς σκηνῆς (sc. ᾄσματα) , odes sung on the stage, Arist.
metaph. stage-effect, unreality, σκηνὴ πᾶς ὁ βίος "all the worldʼs a stage, " Anth.
the tented cover, tilt of a wagon, Aesch., Xen.: also a bed-tester, Dem.
an entertainment given in tents, a banquet, Xen.

div1.head: σκηνίτης
div1.sense: a dweller in tents, Strab.: metaph. a low fellow, Isocr.

div1.head: σκηνοβατέω
div1.sense: to bring on the stage, Strab.

div1.head: σκηνογραφία
div1.sense: scene-painting, Arist.

div1.head: σκηνογραφικός
div1.sense: for or in the manner of scene-painting, Strab.

div1.head: σκηνοπηγία
div1.sense: a setting up of tents: the Feast of Tents or Tabernacles, NTest.

div1.head: σκηνοποιία
div1.sense: a pitching of tents, Polyb.

div1.head: σκηνοποιός
div1.sense: tent-making:—as Subst. a tentmaker, NTest.

div1.head: σκῆνος
div1.sense: metaph. the body (as the tabernacle of the soul), NTest.

div1.head: σκηνοφύλαξ
div1.sense: a watcher in a tent, Xen.

div1.head: σκηνόω
div1.sense: to pitch tents, encamp, Xen.
= σκηνέω, to dwell in a tent, Xen.: generally, to settle, take up oneʼs abode, Xen.:—in perf. pass. to live or be, Plat.
to occupy with tents, Plut.

div1.head: σκήνωμα
div1.sense: quarters, Xen.
metaph. the body, NTest.

div1.head: σκηπτός
div1.sense: a thunder-bolt, Soph., Xen.:— metaph. of pestilence, Aesch.; of war, Eur., Dem.

div1.head: σκηπτουχία
div1.sense: the bearing a staff or sceptre as the badge of command, military command, Aesch.:— generally, command, power, Anth.

div1.head: σκηπτοῦχος
div1.sense: bearing a staff or sceptre as the badge of command, σκ. βασιλεύς a sceptred king, Hom.
as Subst. a wand-bearer, an officer in the Persian court, Xen.

div1.head: σκῆπτρον
div1.sense: a staff or stick to lean upon, a walking-stick, Hom., Aesch.: metaph. of the daughters of Oedipus, σκῆπτρα φωτός his staffs or supports, Soph.

a staff, as the badge of command, a sceptre: in Hom. borne by chiefs, and transmitted from father to son, whence the passage in Il. 2 is called ἡ τοῦ σκήπτρου παράδοσις, Thuc.:—also borne by judges, by heralds, by speakers, who on rising to speak received it from the herald, Hom.
the sceptre, i. e. royalty, kingly power, rule, Il., Trag.

div1.head: σκηπτροφορέω
div1.sense: to rule over, c. gen., Anth.

div1.head: σκηπτροφόρος
div1.sense: bearing a sceptre, kingly, Anth.

div1.head: σκήπτω
div1.sense: to prop, stay one thing against or upon another: Pass. and Mid. to lean upon a staff, Hom.: metaph. to lean upon a person or thing, Dem.
c. acc. rei, to put forward by way of support, allege in excuse, Eur.:—in Mid. to allege on oneʼs own behalf, Hdt., Thuc.; c. inf. to pretend to be, Ar., Dem.
to hurl, dart, Aesch.; metaph., σκ. ἀλάστορα εἴς τινα Eur.
intr. to fall heavily, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: σκηρίπτομαι
div1.sense: Mid., to support oneself, Od.; σκηριπτόμενος χερσίν τε ποσίν τε pressing with hands and feet, Od.

div1.head: σκῆψις
div1.sense: a pretext, plea, excuse, pretence, Trag.; c. gen., κατὰ φόνου τινὰ σκῆψιν on some pretence of murder, Hdt.; σκ. τοῦ μὴ ποιεῖν a plea, excuse for not doing, Dem.

div1.head: σκιαγραφέω
div1.sense: to draw with gradations of light and shade: to sketch out, Lat. adumbrare:—Pass., τὰ ἐσκιαγραφημένα Plat.

div1.head: σκιαγράφημα
div1.sense: a mere sketch, Plat.

div1.head: σκιαγραφία
div1.sense: a sketch or rough painting, such as to produce an effect at a distance, scene-painting, Plat.

trans.i: drawing in light and shade, sketching.

div1.head: σκιάδειον
div1.sense: a sunshade, parasol, Ar.

div1.head: σκιάζω
div1.sense: to overshadow, shade, Il., Eur.
generally, to overshadow, cover, Hes., Hdt.:—Pass., Eur.
to shade in painting, Luc.

div1.head: σκιαμαχέω
div1.sense: to fight in the shade, i. e. in the school (for practice): to fight with a shadow, to fight in vain, Plat.

div1.head: Σκιάποδες
div1.sense: shade-footed, a fabulous people in Libya, with immense feet which they used as sunshades, Ar.

div1.head: σκιά
div1.sense: a shadow, Od.; σκιὰ ἀντίστοιχος ὥς like the shadow that is oneʼs double, Eur.
the shade of one who is dead, a phantom, Od., Trag.; so of one worn to a shadow, Aesch.:—in proverbs of manʼs mortal estate, σκιᾶς ὄναρ ἄνθρωπος Pind.; εἴδωλον σκιᾶς Aesch., etc.
the shade of trees, etc., πετραίη σκιή the shade of a rock, Hes.; ἐν σκιῇ Hes.; ὑπὸ σκιῇ Hdt.; ὑπὸ σκιᾶς Eur.; σκιὰν Σειρίου κυνός shade from itʼs heat, Aesch.

div1.head: σκιαρόκομος
div1.sense: with shading leaves, Eur.

div1.head: σκιάς
div1.sense: any thing serving as a shade, a canopy, pavilion, Theocr., Plut.

div1.head: σκιατραφία
div1.sense: a being brought up in the shade, a sedentary, effeminate life, Plut.

div1.head: σκιατροφέω
div1.sense: to rear in the shade:—Pass. to keep in the shade, shun heat and labour, Hdt., Xen.
intr. in Act. to wear a shade, cover oneʼs head, Hdt.; ἐσκιατροφηκώς, of an effeminate man, Plat.

div1.head: σκιάω
div1.sense: to overshadow:—Pass. to be shaded or become dark, σκιόωντο ἀγυιαί (Epic 3rd pl. imperf.) Od.

div1.head: σκίδνημι
div1.sense: to disperse:— Pass. σκίδναμαι, only in pres. and imperf. to be scattered, to disperse, of a crowd, Hom.; of foam or spray, of a cloud of dust, Il.; σκιδναμένης Δημήτερος when the corn is being scattered, i. e. at seedtime, Orac. ap. Hdt.; ἅμα ἡλίῳ σκιδναμένῳ as the sun begins to spread his light, i. e. soon after sunrise, Hdt.

div1.head: σκιερός
div1.sense: shady, giving shade, Hom., Pind., etc.
shady, shaded, Hes., Pind.
dark-coloured, Anth.

div1.head: σκίλλα
div1.sense: a squill, sea-onion, Theogn., Theocr.

div1.head: σκιμαλίζω
div1.sense: to jeer at, flout, τινά Ar.

div1.head: σκίμπους
div1.sense: a small couch, low bed, Ar., Xen.

div1.head: σκίμπτομαι
div1.sense: to allege, Pind.

div1.head: σκινδάλαμος
div1.sense: a splinter, Lat. scindula:—metaph., λόγων σχινδάλαμοι straw-splittings, quibbles, Ar.

div1.head: σκινδαλαμοφράστης
div1.sense: a straw-splitter, Anth.

div1.head: σκιοειδής
div1.sense: fleeting like a shadow, shadowy, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: σκιόεις
div1.sense: shady, shadowy, οὔρεα σκιόεντα i. e. thickly wooded, Hom.; σκ. μέγαρα dark chambers, Od.
act., νέφεα σκ. overshadowing clouds, Hom.
shadowy, unsubstantial, Anth.

div1.head: σκίπων
div1.sense: a staff, Hdt., Eur., etc.

div1.head: Σκίρα
div1.sense: the festival of Athena Σκιράς, held in the month Pyanepsion, Ar.; different from the Σκιροφόρια, which fell in Scirophorion.

div1.head: Σκιράς
div1.sense: name of Athena, Strab.

div1.head: σκιραφεῖον
div1.sense: a gambling-house, Isocr.

div1.head: σκίραφος
div1.sense: a dice-box:—metaph. trickery, cheating, Hippon.

div1.head: Σκιρῖται
div1.sense: the Scirites, a division of the Spartan army, consisting of 600 foot: they fought on the left wing near the king, and were (originally at least) περίοικοι, from the Arcadian district Σκιρῖτις, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: σκῖρον
div1.sense: the hard rind of cheese, cheese-parings, Ar.

div1.head: σκίρον
div1.sense: the white sunshade which was borne from the Acropolis, in the festivals of Athena Σκιράς (τὰ Σκίρα) , Plut.

div1.head: σκῖρος
div1.sense: stucco: any hard covering, v. σκῖρον.

div1.head: Σκιροφοριών
div1.sense: Scirophorion, the 12th Attic month, the latter part of June and former of July, so called from the festival Σκιροφόρια, Antipho., etc.

div1.head: σκιρτάω
div1.sense: to spring, leap, bound, Il., Eur., etc.:—metaph. of gusts of wind, Aesch.

div1.head: σκίρτημα
div1.sense: a bound, leap, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: σκίρτησις
div1.sense: a bounding, leaping, Plut.

div1.head: σκιρτητής
div1.sense: a leaper, Mosch.

div1.head: σκιρτοπόδης
div1.sense: spring-footed, Anth.

div1.head: Σκίρτος
div1.sense: leaper, name of a Satyr, Anth.

div1.head: Σκίρων
div1.sense: the wind which blew from the Scironian rocks in the Isthmus, Strab.

a robber who haunted the rocks between Attica and Megara, killed by Theseus, Xen.; Σκείρωνος ἀκταί the coast near these rocks, Eur.; the adjacent sea was Σκιρωνικὸν, οἶδμα θαλάσσης Simon. in Anth.; the rocks themselves Σκιρωνίδες πέτραι Eur.; Σκιρωνὶς ὁδός the road from Athens to Megara, Hdt.

div1.head: Σκίταλοι
div1.sense: invoked as the powers of impudence, Ar.

div1.head: σκιώδης
div1.sense: shady, Eur.

div1.head: σκληραγωγέω
div1.sense: to bring up hardy, Luc.

div1.head: σκληροκαρδία
div1.sense: hardness of heart, NTest.

div1.head: σκληρός
div1.sense: hard, Lat. durus, Theogn., Aesch., etc.
of sound, hard, harsh, crashing, Lat. aridus, Hes., Hdt.
hard, stiff, unyielding, Lat. rigidus, Ar., Xen.:—of boys who look old for their age, stiff, sturdy, Plut., Luc.
metaph. of things, hard, austere, severe, Soph., Eur.; σκληρὰ μαλθακῶς λέγων Soph.
adv., σκληρῶς καθῆσθαι, i. e. on a hard seat, Ar.

div1.head: σκληρότης
div1.sense: hardness, Plat.
of persons, hardness, harshness, austerity, Plat.

div1.head: σκληροτράχηλος
div1.sense: stiff-necked, NTest.

div1.head: σκληρύνω
div1.sense: to harden:—metaph. to harden the heart, NTest.

div1.head: σκληφρός
div1.sense: slender, slight, thin, Plat.

div1.head: σκνιπαῖος
div1.sense: dark, σκν. ὁδίτης a wanderer in the twilight, Theocr.

div1.head: σκολιόθριξ
div1.sense: with curled hair or leaves, Anth.

div1.head: σκόλιον
div1.sense: a song which went round at banquets, sung to the lyre by the guests, Ar.; so called from its zigzag course— each guest who sung holding a myrtle-branch (μυρρίνη) , which he passed across the table to any one he chose.

div1.head: σκολιός
div1.sense: curved, winding, twisted, tangled, Lat. obliquus, Hdt., Eur., etc.:— bent sideways, δουλείη κεφαλὴ σκολιή (Hor. stat capite obstipo) Theogn.: metaph. crooked, i. e. unjust, unrighteous, Il., Hes., etc.; σκολιὰ πράττειν, εἰπεῖν Plat.:—so adv. σκολιῶς, Hes.

div1.head: σκολιότης
div1.sense: crookedness, Plut.: in pl. the windings of a stream, etc., Strab.

div1.head: σκολίωμα
div1.sense: a bend, curve, Strab.

div1.head: σκολοπίζω
div1.sense: to impale.

div1.head: σκόλυμος
div1.sense: an eatable kind of thistle, an artichoke, Hes.

div1.head: σκόμβρος
div1.sense: a sea-fish, a kind of tunny, Ar.

div1.head: σκοπάρχης
div1.sense: the chief scout, the leader of a reconnoitring party, Xen.

div1.head: σκοπελοδρόμος
div1.sense: running over rocks, Anth.

div1.head: σκόπελος
div1.sense: a look-out place, a peak, headland or promontory, Lat. scopulus, Hom., etc.

div1.head: σκοπεύω
div1.etym: later form for σκοπέω, Strab., etc.

div1.head: σκοπέω
div1.etym: used by Att. writers only in pres. and impf., the other tenses being supplied by σκέπτομαι.
div1.sense: to look at or after a thing: to behold, contemplate, Pind., Soph., etc.:—absol. to look out, watch, Soph., etc.
metaph. to look to, consider, examine, Hdt., Attic; σκ. τι Thuc., etc.; σκ. περί τινος or τι Plat.: absol., ὀρθῶς σκοπεῖν Eur., etc.
to look out for, c. acc., Xen., etc.
Mid., used just like Act., Soph., Eur.
Pass., σκοπῶν καὶ σκοπούμενος considering and being considered, Plat.

div1.head: σκοπή
div1.etym: = σκοπιά I, in pl., Aesch., Xen.

div1.head: σκοπιάζω
div1.sense: to look about one, spy from a high place or watchtower, Il.: to spy, explore, Od.
trans. to spy out, search out, discover, c. acc., Il., Anth., etc.:—so in Mid. to look out for, Theocr.

div1.head: σκοπιά
div1.sense: a lookout-place, a mountain-peak, Hom.: of the Trojan acropolis, Eur.: cf. σκόπελος.
metaph. the height or highest point of anything, Pind.
a watchtower, Lat. specula, Hdt., Plat.
a look-out, watch, σκοπιὴν ἔχειν to keep watch, Od., Hdt.

div1.head: σκοπιήτης
div1.sense: a highlander, of Pan, Anth.

div1.head: σκοπιωρέομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to look out for, watch, Ar.

div1.head: σκοπιωρός
div1.sense: a watcher.

div1.head: σκοπός
div1.sense: one that watches, one that looks after things, Hom.; of gods and kings, a guardian, protector, Ὀλύμπου σκ. Pind.
a lookout-man, watchman, stationed on a σκοπιά, Lat. speculator, Hom., Xen.: one who marks game, Xen.
a spy, scout, Il., Trag.
the object on which one fixes the eye, a mark, Lat. scopus, Od.; ἀπὸ σκοποῦ away from the mark, Od.; so, παρὰ σκοπόν Pind.; σκοποῦ τυχεῖν to hit the mark, Pind.; ἐπὶ σκοπὸν βάλλειν Xen.
metaph. an aim, end, object, Plat.

div1.head: σκορακίζω
div1.sense: to dismiss contemptuously, Luc.:—Pass. to be treated contemptuously, Dem.

div1.head: σκορδινάομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to stretch oneʼs limbs, yawn, gape, Ar.

div1.head: σκοροδάλμη
div1.sense: a sauce of brine and garlic, Ar.

div1.head: σκοροδίζω
div1.sense: to prime game-cocks with garlic before fighting, Ar.:—Pass., ἐσκοροδισμένος primed with garlic, Ar.

div1.head: Σκοροδομάχοι
div1.sense: garlic-fighters, Luc.

div1.head: σκόροδον
div1.sense: garlic, Lat. allium, the root of which consists of several separate cloves (γελγῖθες) , and is thus distinguished from the onion (κρόμμυον) , and leek (πράσον) , Hdt.; in pl., Ar.

div1.head: σκορπίζω
div1.sense: to scatter, disperse, Strab., NTest.

div1.head: σκορπίος
div1.sense: a scorpion, Plat., Dem.
an engine of war for discharging arrows, Plut.

div1.head: σκοταῖος
div1.sense: in the dark, i.e. before daybreak or after nightfall, Xen.
of things, dark, obscure, Plut.

div1.head: σκοτεινός
div1.sense: dark, Aesch., Eur., etc.; ἀνὰ τὸ σκοτεινόν in the darkness, Thuc.
of a person, darkling, blind, Soph., Eur.
metaph. dark, obscure, Eur., Plat.:—so adv. -νῶς, Plat.

div1.head: σκοτία
div1.sense: darkness, gloom, Anth.

div1.head: σκοτίζω
div1.sense: to make dark:—Pass. to be darkened, NTest.

div1.head: σκότιος
div1.sense: dark,
of persons, in the dark, darkling, σκότιον δέ ἑ γείνατο μήτηρ, i. e. not in open wedlock, Il.; so, σκότιοι παῖδες Eur.; σκ. εὐναί clandestine Loves, Eur., etc.
of things and places, dark, Eur.
metaph., like σκοτεινός, dark, obscure, Ar.

div1.head: σκοτοδασυπυκνόθριξ
div1.sense: dark with shaggy thick hair, κυνῆ σκ., of a "cap of darkness, " Ar.

div1.head: σκοτοδινιάω
div1.sense: to suffer from dizziness or vertigo, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: σκοτοειδής
div1.sense: dark-looking, Plat.

div1.head: σκοτόεις
div1.sense: dark, Hes.

div1.head: σκοτομήνιος
div1.sense: dark and moonless, Od.

div1.head: σκότος
div1.sense: darkness, gloom, Od., Attic
the darkness of death, Il., Eur.
of blindness, σκότον βλέπειν Soph.; σκότον δεδορκώς Eur.
metaph., σκότῳ κρύπτειν, like Hor.ʼs nocte premere, to hide in darkness, Soph.; so, διὰ σκότους ἐστί it is dark and uncertain, Xen.; κατὰ σκότον, ὑπὸ σκότου Soph., etc.

div1.head: σκοτόω
div1.sense: to make dark, to blind:—Pass. to be in darkness: also to suffer from vertigo, Plat.

div1.head: σκοτώδης
div1.sense: dark, Plat.

div1.head: σκύβαλον
div1.sense: dung, filth, refuse, Anth.

div1.head: σκυδμαίνω
div1.sense: to be angry, τινί with one, Il.

div1.head: σκύζομαι
div1.sense: to be angry or wroth with one, τινί Hom.: absol. to be wroth, Il.

div1.head: Σκύθης
div1.sense: a Scythian: proverb., Σκυθῶν ἐρημία, as we might say "the desert of Africa, " Ar.: —fem. Σκύθαινα.
as adj. Scythian, Aesch.
at Athens, a policeman, one of the city-guard, which was mostly composed of Scythian slaves, Ar.

div1.head: Σκυθίζω
div1.sense: to behave like a Scythian: hence, from the Scythian practice of scalping slain enemies, to shave the head, ἐσκυθισμένος ξυρῶι Eur.

div1.head: Σκυθίζω
div1.sense: to behave like a Scythian: hence, from the Scythian practice of scalping slain enemies, to shave the head, ἐσκυθισμένος ξυρῷ Eur.

div1.head: Σκυθικός
div1.sense: Scythian, Aesch., etc.:— ἡ Σκυθική (sc. γῆ) Hdt., etc.:—fem. Σκυθίς, ίδος, acc. ίν, Aeschin.
adv. -κῶς, Strab., Plut.

div1.head: Σκυθιστί
div1.sense: in the Scythian tongue, Hdt.

div1.head: Σκυθοτοξότης
div1.sense: a Scythian bowman, Xen.

div1.head: σκυθράζω
div1.sense: to be angry, peevish, Eur.

div1.head: σκυθρός
div1.sense: angry, sullen, Menand.

div1.head: σκυθρωπάζω
div1.sense: to look angry or sullen, be of a sad countenance, Ar., Xen., etc.

div1.head: σκυθρωπός
div1.sense: angry-looking, of sad countenance, sullen, Eur., Aesch., etc.:— τὸ σκυθρωπόν, σκυλάκαινα, Eur.—adv., σκυθρωπῶς ἔχειν Xen.
of things, gloomy, sad, melancholy, Eur.

div1.head: σκυλακεία
div1.sense: a breeding of dogs, Plut.

div1.head: σκυλάκευμα
div1.sense: a whelp, cub, Anth.

div1.head: σκυλακεύω
div1.sense: to pair dogs for breeding, Xen.
Pass. to be suckled, Strab.

div1.head: σκυλακώδης
div1.sense: like a young dog: τὸ σκυλακῶδες the nature of puppies, Xen.

div1.head: σκύλαξ
