div1.sense: a young dog, whelp, puppy, Lat. catulus, Od., Hes.:—generally, a dog, Soph., etc.
= σκύμνος, Eur.

div1.head: σκύλευμα
div1.sense: mostly in pl. the arms stript off a slain enemy, spoils, Eur., Thuc.

div1.head: σκυλεύω
div1.sense: to strip or despoil a slain enemy of his arms, Hes., Hdt.; c. acc. pers. et rei, Κύκνον σκυλεύσαντες ἀπʼ ὤμων τεύχεα having stript the arms of Cycnus from his shoulders, Hes.
c. acc. rei et gen. pers. to strip the arms off an enemy, Xen.; so, ἀπὸ τῶν νεκρῶν σκ. ψέλια Hdt.

div1.head: Σκύλλα
div1.sense: Scylla, a monster barking like a dog, who inhabited a cavern in the Straits, of Sicily, and rent unwary mariners, Od.

div1.head: σκύλλω
div1.sense: to rend, mangle:—Pass., Aesch.
metaph. to trouble, annoy, Lat. vexare, NTest.:—Pass. or Mid., μὴ σκύλλου trouble not thyself, NTest.; ἐσκυλμένοι troubled, distressed, NTest.

div1.head: σκυλοδεψέω
div1.sense: to tan hides, Ar.

div1.head: σκυλοδέψης
div1.sense: a tanner of hides, Ar.:—so σκυλό-δεψος, ὁ, Dem.

div1.head: σκῦλον
div1.sense: mostly in pl. σκῦλα, the arms stript off a slain enemy, spoils, Soph., Thuc.; εἰς σκῦλα γράφειν to write oneʼs name on arms taken as spoil, Eur.: —rarely in sg., booty, spoil, prey, Eur.

div1.head: σκύλος
div1.sense: a skin, hide, Theocr., Anth.

div1.head: σκυλοφόρος
div1.sense: receiving the spoil, Anth.

div1.head: σκυλοχαρής
div1.sense: delighting in spoils, Anth.

div1.head: σκύμνος
div1.sense: a cub, whelp, esp. a lionʼs whelp, Il., Hdt., Attic; of other animals, Eur., Plut.; in poets also of men, Ἀχίλλειος σκ. Eur.

div1.head: Σκῦρος
div1.sense: the isle of Scyros, one of the Sporades, not far from Euboea, Hom.:—adj. Σκύριος, a Scyrian, Hdt.:—adv., Σκῡρόθεν from Scyros, Il.

div1.head: σκυτάλη
div1.sense: a staff, cudgel, club, Anth.

at Sparta, a staff or baton, used as a cypher for writing dispatches:—a strip of leather was rolled slantwise round it, on which the dispatches were written lengthwise, so that when unrolled they were unintelligible: commanders abroad had a staff of like thickness, round which they rolled these papers, and so were able to read the dispatches:—hence σκυτάλη came to mean a Spartan dispatch, Thuc., Xen.; and generally a message, Pind.

div1.head: σκυταληφορέω
div1.sense: to carry a club, Strab.

div1.head: σκυταληφόρος
div1.sense: carrying a club, Strab.

div1.head: σκυταλίς
div1.sense: a stick, Hdt.

div1.head: σκυτεύω
div1.sense: to be a shoemaker, Xen.

div1.head: σκυτικός
div1.sense: skilled in shoemaking:— ἡ -κή (sub. τέχνη) = σκυτοτομία, Plat.

div1.head: σκύτινος
div1.sense: leathern, made of leather, Hdt., Ar.
metaph. skinny, gaunt, Anth.

div1.head: σκυτοδέψης
div1.sense: a leather-dresser, currier, Theophr.: so, σκῡτόδεψος, ὁ, Plat., Luc.

div1.head: σκῦτος
div1.sense: a skin, hide, esp. a dressed or tanned hide, Od., Ar., etc.
a leather thong, a whip, Dem.; σκύτη βλέπειν to look whips, i. e. as if one was going to be whipt, Ar.

div1.head: σκυτοτομέω
div1.sense: to cut leather for shoes, to be a shoemaker, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: σκυτοτομία
div1.sense: shoemaking, Plat.

div1.head: σκυτοτομικός
div1.sense: of or for a shoemaker, Ar.; ὁ σκ. ὁ σκυτοτόμος, Plat.: ἡ-κή (sc. τέχνη) , = σκυτοτομία, Plat.

div1.head: σκυτοτόμος
div1.sense: a leather-cutter, a worker in leather, Il., Xen., etc.: esp. a shoemaker, cobbler, Ar.

div1.head: σκυτοτραγέω
div1.sense: to gnaw leather, Luc.

div1.head: σκύφος
div1.sense: a cup, can, Od., Eur., etc.: a milk-pail, Theocr.

div1.head: σκωληκόβρωτος
div1.sense: eaten of worms, NTest.

div1.head: σκώληξ
div1.sense: a worm, Lat. lumbricus, Il.
of the grubs, of insects, Ar., etc.

div1.head: σκῶλος
div1.sense: like σκόλοψ, a pointed stake, Il.

div1.head: σκῶμμα
div1.sense: a jest, joke, gibe, scoff, Ar.; ἐν σκώμματος μέρει by way of a joke, Aeschin.; σκ. παρὰ γράμμα a pun, Arist.

div1.head: σκωπτικός
div1.sense: mocking, jesting, Plut., Luc.

div1.head: σκωπτόλης
div1.sense: a mocker, jester, Ar.

div1.head: σκώπτω
div1.sense: to hoot, mock, jeer, scoff at, τινά Ar.; also, σκ. εἰς τὰ ῥάκια to jest at his rags, Ar.; εἴς τινα Aeschin.
in good sense, to joke with, τινά Hdt.
absol. to jest, joke, be funny, Ar., Xen., etc.

div1.head: σκωρία
div1.sense: the dross of metal, slag, scoria, Strab.

div1.head: σκῶρ
div1.sense: dung, Ar.

div1.head: σκώψ
div1.sense: a small kind of owl, Od., Theocr.

div1.head: σμαράγδινος
div1.sense: of smaragdus, NTest.

div1.head: σμάραγδος
div1.sense: Lat. smaragdus, a precious stone of a green colour, a name given to the emerald and to malachite, Hdt.

div1.head: σμαραγέω
div1.sense: to crash, as thunder, Il.; of the sea, to roar, Il.; of cranes, to scream, Il.

div1.head: σμάω
div1.sense: to wipe or cleanse with soap or unguent; (but the Act. is mostly found in compds. δια-, ἐκ-, ἐπι-σμάω) : — Mid., σμᾶσθαι τὴν κεφαλήν to wash or anoint oneʼs head, Hdt.

div1.head: σμερδαλέος
div1.sense: terrible to look on, fearful, aweful, direful, Hom.
terrible to hear, in neut. as adv., terribly, Hom.; so in pl. σμερδαλέα, Il.

div1.head: σμερδνός
div1.sense: Il., Aesch.:—as adv., σμερδνόν Il.

div1.head: σμῆγμα
div1.sense: soap or unguent, Plut.

div1.head: σμηνοδόκος
div1.sense: holding a swarm of bees, Anth.

div1.head: σμῆνος
div1.sense: a beehive, Hes., Plat.
a swarm of bees, Aesch., etc.; of wasps, Ar.:—metaph., of clouds, Ar., etc.

div1.head: σμήχω
div1.sense: to wipe off by help of soap or unguent, to wash off, Od.
to wipe clean, Babr.: proverb., Αἰθίοπα σμ. "to wash a black man white," Luc.: —Mid., σμηχομένα κρόταφον wiping her brow clean, Anth.

div1.head: σμικρός
div1.etym: Ionic and old Attic for μικρός.

div1.head: σμῖλαξ
div1.sense: Lat. taxus, the yew, Plat.
the convolvulus, or perh. bryony, Trag., Ar.

div1.head: σμίλευμα
div1.sense: a piece of carved work: metaph., σμιλεύματα ἔργων finely carved works, Ar.

div1.head: σμιλευτός
div1.sense: cut, carved, Anth.

div0.div1: σμιλεύω σμῑλεύω, to carve finely. from σμί_λη[LSJ supp.]

div1.head: σμίλη
div1.sense: a knife for cutting, carving or pruning, Plat., etc.: a graving tool, chisel, Anth.

div1.head: σμιλίον
div1.sense: Dim. of σμίλη, Lat. scalpellum, Luc.

div1.head: Σμινθεύς
div1.sense: name of Apollo (from Σμίνθος or Σμίνθη a town in Troas), the Sminthian, Il.

div1.head: σμίνθος
div1.sense: a mouse (a Cretan word), Anth.

div1.head: σμινύη
div1.sense: a two-pronged hoe or mattock, Lat. bidens, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: σμυγερός
div1.sense: with pain, painful, Soph. adv. -ρῶς, Soph.

div1.head: Σμυρναῖος
div1.sense: of Smyrna, Pind.

div1.head: σμυρναῖος
div1.sense: of myrrh, Anth.

div1.head: Σμύρνα
div1.sense: Smyrna, in Ionia, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: σμύρνα
div1.sense: like μύρρα, myrrh, the resinous gum of an Arabian tree, used for embalming the dead, Hdt.; called σμύρνης ἱδρώς by Eur.; also used for anointing, Ar.; and a salve, Hdt.

div1.head: σμυρνίζω
div1.sense: to flavour or drug with myrrh: Pass., οἶνος ἐσμυρνισμένος NTest.

div1.head: σμυρνοφόρος
div1.sense: bearing myrrh, Strab.

div1.head: σμύχω
div1.sense: to burn in a mouldering fire:— Pass. to smoulder away, Il., Mosch.

div1.head: σμῶδιξ
div1.sense: a weal, swollen bruise, caused by a blow, Il.

div1.head: σμώχω
div1.sense: to rub down, grind down, Ar.

div1.head: σοβαρός
div1.sense: properly, scaring birds away: — and so,
rushing, rapid, Ar.:—adv. -ρῶς, Ar.
swaggering, pompous, haughty, Ar.; of a horse, Xen.:—adv. -ρῶς, Plut.; also neut. as adv., Theocr.
of things, Ar.

div1.head: σοβέω
div1.sense: to scare away birds, Ar., etc.
generally, to drive away, clear away, Xen.
to move rapidly, πόδα σοβεῖν, of dancing, Ar.:—metaph. in Pass. to be much agitated, vehemently excited, Anth., Plut.
intr. to strut, swagger, bustle, Dem., Plut.; σόβει ἐς Ἄργος bustle off to Argos, Luc.

div1.head: σολοικίζω
div1.sense: to speak incorrectly, commit a solecism, φωνῇ Σκυθικῇ σολ. to speak bad Scythian, Hdt.

div1.head: σολοικισμός
div1.sense: incorrectness in the use of language, a solecism, Luc.

div1.head: σολοικιστής
div1.sense: one who speaks incorrectly, Luc.

div1.head: σόλοικος
div1.sense: speaking incorrectly, using provincialisms, Anacr., etc.
metaph. erring against good manners, awkward, clumsy, Xen., Arist.
div1.etym: Said to come from the corruption of the Attic dialect by the Athenian colonists of Σόλοι in Cilicia.

div1.head: σόλος
div1.sense: a mass or lump of iron, used in throwing, Il.; distinguished from the flat δίσκος or quoit.

div1.head: σόος
div1.etym: Epic and Ionic form of σῶος, σῶς· v. σῶς.

div1.head: σοροπηγός
div1.sense: a coffin-maker, Ar., Anth.

div1.head: σορός
div1.sense: a vessel for holding anything, esp. a cinerary urn, Il.:— a coffin, Hdt., Ar.
as nickname of an old man or woman, Ar.

div1.head: σός
div1.etym: possessive adj. of pers. Pron. σύ, the earlier form being τεός
div1.sense: thy, thine, of thee, Lat. tuus, tua, tuum, Hom., etc.; Epic gen. σοῖο;— in Attic often with the Art., δέμας τὸ σόν, τὸ σὸν κάρα:—σὸν ἔργον, c. inf., ʼtis thy business to . . , Soph.; so, σόν ἐστι alone, Aesch.:— οἱ σοί thy kinsfolk, people, Soph.:— τὸ σόν what concerns thee, thy interest, words, purpose, Soph.:— τὰ σά thy property, Od.; thy interests, Soph.
with a gen. added, τὰ σʼ αὐτῆς ἔργα Il.; σὸν μόνης δώρημα Soph.
objective, for thee, σῇ ποθῇ Il.; σός τε πόθος σά τε μήδεα Od.; σῇ προμηθίᾳ Soph.

div1.head: σουδάριον
div1.sense: the Lat. suda_rium, a kerchief, NTest.

div1.head: Σουνιάρατος
div1.sense: worshipped at Sunium, Ar.

div1.head: Σουνιέρακος
div1.sense: hawk-of-sunium, Ar.

div1.head: Σουνιεύς
div1.sense: a man of Sunium, Decret. ap. Dem.

div1.head: Σούνιον
div1.sense: Sunium, the southern headland of Attica, Od., etc.:—adj., Σουνιακός, ή, όν, Hdt.:—

div1.head: σοῦ
div1.sense: σοῦ, σοῦ, shoo! shoo!, a cry to scare away birds, Ar.

div1.head: Σουσιγενής
div1.sense: born at Susa, Aesch.

div1.head: Σούσιος
div1.sense: a man of Susa, Xen.

div1.head: Σουσίς
div1.sense: = Σοῦσα Aesch.; but Σ. γυνή a woman of Susa, Xen.

div1.head: σοῦσον
div1.sense: the lily, a Phoen. word.

div1.head: Σοῦσα
div1.sense: Susa, in the province of Susiana or Shushan, winter residence of the King of Persia, Hdt., Xen.

div1.head: σοφία
div1.sense: skill in handicraft and art, Il., Xen., etc.:— σ. τινός or περί τινος knowledge of, acquaintance with a thing, Plat.
sound judgment, intelligence, practical wisdom, such as was attributed to the Seven Wise men, Theogn., Hdt.; in not so good a sense, cunning, shrewdness, craft, like δεινότης, Hdt.
wisdom, philosophy, Theogn., Attic

div1.head: σοφίζω
div1.sense: to make wise, instruct, NTest.
Pass. to be clever or skilled in a thing, c. gen., ναυτιλίης σεσοφισμένος skilled in seamanship, Hes.:—absol. to pursue wisdom, be well instructed, Xen.
Mid. to teach oneself, learn, τι Xen.

σοφίζομαι, as Dep., with aor1 mid. and perf. pass. to play subtle tricks, deal subtly, Theogn., Eur., etc.; οὐδὲν σοφιζόμεσθα τοῖσι δαίμοσι we argue not subtly about the gods, Eur.:—in speaking, to use sophistical arguments, to quibble, περί τι Plat.; καίπερ οὕτω τούτου σεσοφισμένου though this man has dealt thus craftily, Dem.

c. acc. rei, to devise cleverly or skilfully, Hdt., Ar.; ἀλλότρια σ. to meddle with other menʼs craft, Ar.; τὸ τοῦτο δεῖ σοφισθῆναι this one must gain by craft, Soph.:—perf. part. σεσοφισμένος in pass. sense, craftily devised, NTest.
c. acc. pers. to deceive, Anth.

div1.head: σόφισμα
div1.sense: any skilful act, the skilful dressing of food, Xen.
a clever device, contrivance, Hdt., Trag.
in less good sense, a sly trick, artifice, Eur., Thuc.; a stage-trick, claptrap, Ar.
a captious argument, a quibble, fallacy, sophism, Plat., etc.

div1.head: σοφιστέος
div1.sense: verb. adj. one must contrive, Arist.

div1.head: σοφιστεύω
div1.sense: to play the sophist, argue as one, Dem.
to give lectures, of the Sophists, Plut.

div1.head: σοφιστής
div1.sense: a master of oneʼs craft or art, an adept, of a diviner, Hdt.; of poets, Pind.; of the Creator, Plat.; metaph., σ. πημάτων an adept in misery, Eur.
like φρόνιμος, one who is clever in matters of life, a wise man, in which sense the seven Sages are called σοφισταί, Hdt.; of Prometheus, Aesch.

at Athens, a Sophist, i. e. a professor of grammar, rhetoric, politics, mathematics, such as Prodicus, Gorgias, Protagoras, Thuc., Plat., etc. At first the Sophists were held in honour; but from their loose principles they fell into ill repute, and the word came to mean,
a sophist (in bad sense), a quibbler, cheat, Ar., Dem., etc.

div1.head: σοφιστικός
div1.sense: of or for a sophist, Plat.
like a sophist, sophistical, Xen., etc. adv. -κῶς, Plat.

div1.head: Σοφοκλέης
div1.sense: Sophocles, Ar., etc.

div1.head: σοφόνοος
div1.sense: wise-minded, Luc.

div1.head: σοφός
div1.sense: properly, skilled in any handicraft or art, cunning in his craft, Theogn., etc; of a charioteer, Pind.; of poets and musicians, Pind.; of a soothsayer, Soph., etc.

clever in matters of common life, wise, prudent, shrewd, σ. ἄνδρες Θεσσαλοί shrewd fellows, the Thessalians! Hdt.; πολλὰ σοφός Aesch.; μείζω σοφίαν σοφός Plat., etc.; τῶν σοφῶν κρείσσω better than all craft, Soph.; σοφόν ἐστι c. inf., Eur.
skilled in the sciences, learned, profound, wise, Eur., Plat., etc.; hence, ironically, abstruse, obscure, Ar., etc.
pass., of things, cleverly devised, wise, Hdt., etc.; σοφώτερʼ ἢ κατʼ ἄνδρα συμβαλεῖν things too clever for man to understand, Eur.
adv. σοφῶς, cleverly, wisely, Soph., Eur., etc.:—comp. -ώτερον, Eur.: Sup. -ώτατα, Eur.

div1.head: σόω
div1.sense: to preserve, save, deliver, 2nd sg. subj. σόῃς, 3rd sg. and pl. σόῃ, σόωσι, Il.
div1.etym: rare Epic Verb for σαόω, σῴζω

div1.head: σπαδίζω
div1.sense: to draw off, Hdt.

div1.head: σπάδων
div1.sense: an eunuch, Lat. spado, Plut.

div1.head: σπαθάω
div1.sense: in weaving, to strike home the woof with the σπάθη; metaph., λίαν σπαθᾶν to go too fast, a cant phrase for throwing away money, Ar.; so, σπ. τὰ χρήματα Plut.:—Pass., ἐσπαθᾶτο ταῦτα these were the prodigalities indulged in, Dem.

div1.head: σπάθη
div1.sense: a flat blade used by weavers in the upright loom (instead of the comb (κτείς) used in the horizontal), for striking the threads of the woof home, so as to make the web close, Aesch.

div1.head: σπαίρω
div1.sense: to gasp, of dying fish, Anth.; cf. ἀσπαίρω.

div1.head: σπανίζω
div1.sense: of things, to be rare, scarce, scanty, Pind., Ar.
of persons, to lack or be in want of, τινός Hdt., Aesch., etc.;—so in Pass., ἐσπανίσμεθʼ ἀρωγῶν Aesch.: absol. to be in want, Eur.

div1.head: σπάνιος
div1.sense: rare, scarce, scanty, Hdt., Eur.; σπάνιον ἑαυτὸν παρέχειν, Lat. difficiles aditus habere, Plat.; ὕδατι σπανίῳ χρώμενοι having a scanty supply of water, Thuc.; c. inf., σπ. ἰδεῖν rare to behold, Xen.: of persons in an adv. sense, σπάνιος ἐπιφοιτᾷ he seldom visits, Hdt.:— σπάνιόν ἐστι, c. inf., it is seldom that . . , Xen.:— τὸ σπάνιον σπάνις, Aeschin.
comp. σπανιώτερος, Hdt., Thuc.: —Sup. -ώτατος, Attic
adv. -ίως, seldom, Xen.; so σπανίᾳ, Plat.: comp. -ιώτερον, Thuc.

div1.head: σπανιότης
div1.sense: lack of a thing, Isocr.

div1.head: σπάνις
div1.sense: scarcity, rareness, dearth, lack of a thing, Eur., Dem.:— οὐ σπάνις ἐστι οὐ σπάνιον, there is no lack, no difficulty, Eur.

div1.head: σπανιστός
div1.sense: of things, scanty, Soph.

div1.head: σπανοσιτία
div1.sense: lack of corn or food, Xen.

div1.head: σπάραγμα
div1.sense: a piece torn off, a piece, shred, fragment, ὅσων σπαράγματα all whose mangled corpses, Soph.; σπάραγμα κόμας Eur.
= σπαραγμός, a tearing, rending, Eur.

div1.head: σπαραγμός
div1.sense: a tearing, rending, mangling, Eur.
a convulsion, spasm, Soph.

div1.head: σπαράσσω
div1.sense: to tear, rend in pieces, mangle, Lat. lacerare, Eur., Ar.:—Mid., σπαράσσεσθαι κόμας to tear oneʼs hair, Eur.
to rend asunder, Aesch.
metaph. to pull to pieces, attack, Lat. conviciis lacerare, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: σπαργανιώτης
div1.sense: a child in swaddling-clothes, Hhymn.

div1.head: σπάργανον
div1.sense: a swathing band, and in pl. swaddling-clothes, Hhymn., Pind.; παῖς ἔτʼ ὢν ἐν σπαργάνοις Aesch.; tokens by which a person is identified, Lat. monumenta, crepundia, Soph., Ar.

div1.head: σπαργανόω
div1.sense: to wrap in swaddling-clothes, swathe, Eur.:—Pass., perf. part. ἐσπαργανωμένος NTest.

div1.head: σπαργάω
div1.sense: to be full to bursting, to swell, be ripe, Eur.
metaph., like Lat. turgere, to swell with passion, Plat.:—absol. to wax wanton, be insolent, Plut.
div1.etym: Prob. from same Root as σφρῑγάω.

div1.head: Σπαρτάκειος
div1.sense: of Spartacus, Plut.

div1.head: Σπάρτηθεν
div1.sense: from Sparta, Od.

div1.head: Σπάρτηνδε
div1.sense: to Sparta, Od.

div1.head: Σπάρτη
div1.sense: Sparta, Hom., etc.

div1.head: Σπαρτιάτης
div1.sense: a Spartan, Eur., Thuc.

div1.head: Σπαρτιᾶτις
div1.sense: (sub. γυνή) a Spartan woman, Eur., etc.; (sub. χώρα) Laconia, Plut.; also as adj., Σπ. γυνή, χθών, γῆ Eur.

div1.head: σπαρτίον
div1.sense: a small cord, Ar.

div1.head: σπάρτον
div1.sense: a rope, cable, Il., etc.; (prob. akin to σπεῖρα) .

div1.head: σπαρτός
div1.sense: sown, grown from seed: metaph., σπαρτῶν γένος children of men, Aesch.
at Thebes, Σπαρτοί, οἱ, the sown-men, those who claimed descent from the dragonʼs teeth sown by Cadmus, the Cadmeans, Thebans, Pind., Eur.; λόγχη σπαρτός the Theban spear, Eur.
scattered, of the limbs of a corpse, Anth.

div1.head: σπάρτος
div1.sense: Spanish broom, esparto, Xen., etc.

div1.head: σπαρτοφόρος
div1.sense: bearing broom, Strab.

div1.head: σπάσμα
div1.sense: a spasm, convulsion, τῶν ὑστερῶν Arist.
a piece torn off, shred, Plut.

div1.head: σπασμός
div1.sense: a convulsion, spasm, Hdt., Soph.

div1.head: σπαταλάω
div1.sense: to live lewdly, to run riot, NTest.

div1.head: σπατάλη
div1.sense: lewdness, wantonness, riot, luxury, Anth.

div1.head: σπατίλη
div1.sense: excrement, Ar.

div1.head: σπάω
div1.sense: of a sword, to draw, Eur.;—mostly in Mid., Hom.:—Pass. to be drawn, Il.; ἐσπασμένοι τὰ ξίφη having their swords drawn, Xen.
πάλον σπᾶν to draw a lot (out of a helmet), Aesch.
absol., σπᾶτʼ ἀνδρείως pull, hoist away, like men.
of violent actions, to pluck off or out, κόμην Soph.
like σπαράσσω, to tear, rend, of beasts, Soph.
to wrench, sprain:—Pass., τὸν μηρὸν σπασθῆναι Hdt.
to snatch, tear or drag away, Eur.
metaph. to carry away, draw aside, Soph., Plat.
Pass. to be convulsed, Soph.
to draw in, suck in, quaff, Aesch., Eur.
to draw tight, pull the reins, Xen.
of angling: hence, proverb., οὐκ ἔσπασεν ταύτηι γε he took nothing by his motion," Ar.
to adopt, appropriate, Anth.

div1.head: σπείραμα
div1.sense: a coil, spire, convolution, Aesch.: αἰῶνος σπ. a period, cycle, Anth.

div1.head: σπειράομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be coiled or folded round.

div1.head: σπεῖρα
div1.sense: Lat. spira, anything wound or coiled: in pl. the coils or spires of a serpent, Eur.; also σπείραις δικτυοκλώστοις with the netʼs meshy folds, Soph.
σπεῖραι βόειαι thongs or straps of ox-hide bound round a boxerʼs fist, the caestus, Theocr.
a body of men-at-arms, the Roman manipulus, = two centuries, Polyb.:—also a cohort, NTest.

div1.head: σπειρηδόν
div1.sense: in coils or spires, spirally, Anth.
(σπεῖρα II) of troops, in maniples, Polyb.

div1.head: σπειρίον
div1.sense: a light, summer-garment, Xen.

div1.head: σπεῖρον
div1.sense: a piece of cloth, εἴλυμα σπείρων a wrapping cloth, Od.; κακὰ σπεῖρα sorry wraps, Od.; ἄτερ σπείρου without a shroud, Od.; also a sail, Od.

div1.head: σπειροῦχος
div1.sense: forming a circle, Anth.

div1.head: σπείρω
div1.sense: to sow:
to sow seed, Hes., Attic
to sow children, to engender, beget them, Soph.:—Pass. to be born, Soph., Eur.
to scatter like seed, strew, throw about, χρυσὸν καὶ ἄργυρον Hdt.; δρόσον Eur.:—to spread abroad, as Virgil spargere voces, Soph.:—Pass. to be scattered, dispersed, Eur., Thuc.
to sow a field, Hes., Hdt., etc.: Pass., ἡ σπειρομένη Αἴγυπτος the arable part of Egypt, Hdt.
proverb., πόντον σπείρειν, of lost labour, Theogn.

div1.head: σπεκουλάτωρ
div1.sense: Latin speculator, one of the body-guard, NTest.

div1.head: σπένδω
div1.sense: to pour or make a drink-offering before drinking, Lat. libare, Hom.:—σπ. οἶνον to pour wine, Hom.; λοιβάς Soph.; σπονδάς, χοάς Eur.; ellipt., σπ. ἀγαθοῦ δαίμονος (sc. σπονδήν) to pour a libation in honour of the good genius, Ar.:—rarely c. dat. rei, ὕδατι σπ. to make a drink-offering with water, Od.:—in NTest. the Pass. is used metaph. of a person, σπένδομαι ἐπὶ τῆι θυσίαι I am offered (as a drink-offering) over the sacrifice.
without any religious sense, to pour, Hdt., Xen., etc.

Mid. to pour libations one with another, and, as this was the custom in making treaties, to make a treaty, make peace, Hdt., Ar., etc.; σπένδεσθαί τινι to make peace with one, Eur., etc.; so, σπ. πρός τινα Thuc., etc.:— σπένδεσθαι τῆι πρεσβείαι to give it pledges of safe conduct, Aeschin.: c. acc., εἰρήνην σπεισάμενοι Λακεδαιμονίοισι having concluded a peace with them, Hdt.; ἐσπεῖσθαι νεῖκος to make up a quarrel, Eur.; σπ. ἀναίρεσιν τοῖς νεκροῖς to make a truce for taking up the dead, Thuc.:—Pass., of a treaty, to be concluded, Thuc.

div1.head: σπέος
div1.sense: a cave, cavern, grotto, Hom.: of the form σπέος, Hom. uses only nom. and acc. sg., with Epic dat. σπῆι; of the form σπεῖος, acc. sg., gen. σπείους, dat. pl. σπέσσι and σπήεσσι; gen. pl. σπείων Hhymn.

div1.head: σπερμαίνω
div1.sense: to sow with seed: to beget, Hes.

div1.head: σπέρμα
div1.sense: that which is sown:
the seed of plants, Hes., Hdt., Attic:—also of animals, Pind., Eur.
metaph. of the germ, origin, element of anything, σπ. πυρός Od.; φλογός Pind.; κακῶν Dem.
seed, offspring, issue, Trag., etc.
race, origin, descent, Trag.

div1.head: σπερμολογία
div1.sense: babbling, gossip, Plut.

div1.head: σπερμολόγος
div1.sense: picking up seeds, of granivorous birds, Plut.
metaph. one who picks up scraps of knowledge, a babbler, Dem., NTest.

div1.head: σπερμοφόρος
div1.sense: bearing seed, Anth.

div1.head: Σπερχειός
div1.sense: the Spercheius, i. e. rapid (from σπέρχω, a river of Thessaly, Il.

div1.head: σπερχνός
div1.sense: hasty, rapid, hurried, Hes., Aesch.

div1.head: σπέρχω
div1.sense: to set in rapid motion:—Pass. to be in haste to do a thing, c. inf., Il.; σπ. ἐρετμοῖς to hasten with oars, to ply them rapidly, Od.: part. σπερχόμενος as adv., in haste, hastily, hurriedly, Hom., Eur.
metaph. to be hasty and angry, Il., Hdt.; μὴ σπέρχου be not hasty, Eur.
intr. = Pass., ὅτε σπέρχωσιν ἄελλαι when storms are driven rapidly, Hom.

div1.head: σπεύδω
div1.sense: trans. to set a-going, to urge on, hasten, quicken, Hom., etc.:—also, to seek eagerly, strive after, Theogn.; promote zealously, to press or urge on, Soph., etc.; so in Mid., Aesch.:—Pass., to be urged on, Hdt.
c. acc. et inf., σπεύσατε Τεῦκρον μολεῖν urge him to come, Soph.
intr. to press on, hasten, to exert oneself, strive eagerly or anxiously, Il., Attic; ὡς σὺ σπεύδεις as you urge, contend, Plat.: part. σπεύδων as adv. in haste, eagerly, Il., Aesch.
c. inf. to be eager to do a thing, Hes., Hdt., etc.; so in Mid., σπευδόμεναι ἀφελεῖν Aesch.
c. acc. rei et inf. to be anxious that . . , Hdt., Xen.

div1.head: σπήλαιον
div1.sense: a grotto, cave, cavern, Plat.

div1.head: σπηλαιώδης
div1.sense: cavern-like, Plat.

div1.head: σπιδής
div1.sense: wide, broad, διὰ σπιδέος πεδίοιο Il.

div1.head: σπιθαμή
div1.sense: the space one can span with the thumb and little finger, a span, Lat. dodrans, about 7 1/2 inches, Hdt., Plat.

div1.head: σπιλαδώδης
div1.sense: rock-like: rocky, Strab.

div1.head: σπιλάς
div1.sense: a rock over which the sea dashes, a ledge of rock, Od.:—generally, a slab, Soph.

div1.head: σπίλος
div1.sense: a spot, stain, blemish, NTest.

div1.head: σπιλόω
div1.sense: to stain, soil, NTest.:—Pass., perf. part. ἐσπιλωμένος NTest.

div1.head: σπινθαρίς
div1.sense: a spark, Hhymn.

div1.head: σπινθήρ
div1.sense: a spark, Lat. scintilla, Il., Ar.

div1.head: σπίνος
div1.sense: a bird of the finch kind, the siskin, Ar.

div1.head: σπλαγχνεύω
div1.sense: to eat the innards (σπλάγχνα) of a victim after a sacrifice, Ar.
to prophesy from the inwards, Strab.

div1.head: σπλαγχνίζω
div1.sense: Mid.-Pass. to feel compassion, mercy, NTest.

div1.head: σπλάγχνον
div1.sense: mostly in pl. σπλάγχνα, the inward parts, esp. the viscera thoracis, i. e. heart, lungs, liver, kidneys, which in sacrifices were reserved to be eaten by the sacrificers, Hom., etc.:—hence the sacrificial feast, Lat. visceratio, Ar.:—also as used in divination, Aesch., etc.
any part of the inwards, the womb, Pind., Soph.: so in sg., Aesch.
metaph., like our heart, the seat of the feelings and affections, Aesch., Eur., etc.:—so in sg., Soph., Eur.; ἀνδρὸς σπλάγχνον ἐκμαθεῖν to learn a manʼs inward nature, Eur.

div1.head: σπλήν
div1.sense: the milt, spleen, Hdt.

div1.head: σπογγιά
div1.sense: a sponge, Ar.

div1.head: σπογγίζω
div1.sense: to wipe with a sponge, Dem.

div1.head: σπόγγος
div1.sense: a sponge, Hom., etc.

div1.head: σποδεύνης
div1.sense: lying on ashes, Anth.

div1.head: σποδέω
div1.sense: to pound, smite, crush, Ar.:—Pass., σποδούμενος νιφάδι pelted by the storm, Eur.; πρὸς πέτρας σπ. dashed against the rocks, Eur.; absol., στρατὸς κακῶς σπ. handled roughly, in sorry plight, Aesch.

div1.head: σποδιά
div1.sense: a heap of ashes, ashes, Od., Eur.
metaph., = σποδός III, Anth.

div1.head: σποδίζω
div1.sense: to roast or bake in the ashes, burn to ashes, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: σποδόομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be burnt to ashes, Anth.

div1.head: σποδός
div1.sense: wood-ashes, embers, and generally, ashes, Od., Hdt., Attic: the ashes of the dead, Aesch., Soph., etc.
dust, Hdt.
metaph., σπ. κυλίκων, of a bibulous old woman, "a sponge, " Anth.

div1.head: σπολάς
div1.sense: a leathern garment, buff-jerkin, Ar., Xen.

div1.head: σπονδαρχία
div1.sense: the beginning of the libation, the right of beginning it, Hdt.

div1.head: σπονδεῖος
div1.sense: used at a libation:— σπονδεῖος (sc. πούς), in metre, a spondee, a foot consisting of two long syllables, being the metre proper to the slow melodies used at σπονδαί (a treaty).

div1.head: σπονδή
div1.sense: a drink-offering, i. e. the wine poured out to the gods before drinking, Lat. libatio, Hes., Hdt.; σπονδὰς θεοῖς λείβειν, σπένδειν Aesch., Eur.

in pl., σπονδαί was a solemn treaty or truce, (because solemn drink-offerings were made on concluding them); σπονδαὶ ἄκρητοι the truce made by pouring unmixed wine, Il.; αἱ Λακεδαιμονίων σπ. the truce with them. Thuc.; σπονδὰς παραδιδόναι Ar.; δέχεσθαι Thuc.; τυχεῖν Xen.; σπ. ποιεῖσθαί τινι to make a truce with one, Hdt.; πρός τινα Ar.; σπ. τέμνειν (like ὅρκια τέμνειν) Eur.; σπ. ἄγειν πρός τινας Thuc.
αἱ Ὀλυμπικαὶ σπ. the solemn truce or armistice during the Olympic games, Thuc.
the treaty itself, εἴρηται ἐν ταῖς σπ. Thuc.

div1.head: σπονδῖτις
div1.sense: making a σπονδή, Anth.

div1.head: σπονδοφόρος
div1.sense: one who brings proposals for a truce or treaty of peace (σπονδαί) , Ar.
a herald or officer who published the sacred σπονδαί of the Olympic and other games, Pind., etc.

div1.head: σποράδην
div1.sense: scatteredly, here and there, Lat. sparsim, Thuc., Plat.: casually, Anth.

div1.head: σποραδικός
div1.sense: scattered, τὰ σπ. ζῷα, opp. to τὰ ἀγελαῖα (gregarious), Arist.

div1.head: σποραῖος
div1.sense: σποραῖα, ων, τά seeds, Babr.

div1.head: σπορά
div1.sense: a sowing of seed, Plat.: of children, origin, birth, Aesch., Soph.
seed-time, Eur.
the seed sown, Eur.:—of persons, seed, offspring, Soph.: generally, θηλὺς σπ. the female race, Eur. Hence.

div1.head: σποράς
div1.sense: mostly in pl. scattered, dispersed, Hdt., Thuc.; of men, σποράδες ᾤκουν, i. e. not in communities, Arist.; αἱ Σποράδες (sc. νῆσοι) the islands off the west coast of Asia Minor, opp. to αἱ Κυκλάδες, Strab.

div1.head: σπορητός
div1.sense: sown corn, growing corn, Aesch.
a sowing of corn, Xen.

div1.head: σπόριμος
div1.sense: sown, to be sown, fit for sowing, Xen., Theocr.; τὰ σπόριμα the corn-fields, NTest.; μέτρον σπ. a measure of seed-corn, Anth.

div1.head: σπόρος
div1.sense: a sowing, Hdt., Xen., etc.
seed-time, Xen., Theocr.
seed, Theocr.
produce, fruit, harvest, crop, Hdt., Soph.

div1.head: σπουδάζω
div1.sense: intr. to make haste,
of things, to be busy, eager, zealous, earnest to do a thing, c. inf., Soph., etc.; also, σπ. περί τινος or τι Xen., Plat.; εἴς or πρός τι Dem.; ἐπί τινι Xen.
of persons, σπ. πρός τινα to be busy with him, Plat.; σπ. περί τινα to be anxious for his success, canvass for him, Xen.; ὑπέρ τινος Dem.
absol. to be serious or earnest, Ar., etc.; ἐσπουδακότι προσώπωι with a grave face, Xen.
trans.,
c. acc. rei, to do anything hastily or earnestly, Eur., Plat., etc.:—Pass. to be zealously pursued, Eur., etc.:—esp. in perf. part., serious, Plat., etc.
Pass., also, of persons, to be treated with respect, to be courted, Arist., etc.

div1.head: σπουδαιολογέω
div1.sense: to speak seriously, talk on serious subjects, Xen.; so in Mid., Xen.:—Pass., to be treated seriously, Xen.

div1.head: σπουδαῖος
div1.sense: of persons, earnest, serious, Xen.; active, zealous, Plut.
good, excellent, Hdt., Plat.; σπουδαῖος τὴν τέχνην Xen.
of men of character and importance, Xen.
in moral sense, good, opp. to πονηρός, Xen.
of things, worth oneʼs serious attention, serious, weighty, Theogn., Hdt., Attic
good of its kind, excellent, Hdt., etc.
adv. σπουδαίως, seriously, earnestly, well, Xen., etc.:—comp., -ότερον, Xen.; Sup. -ότατα, most carefully, in the best way, Hdt.—There are also irreg. comp. and Sup. σπουδαι-έστερος, -έστατος.

div1.head: σπουδάρχης
div1.sense: one who canvasses for office, a place-man, Xen.

div1.head: σπουδαρχία
div1.sense: canvassing for office, Lat. ambitus, Plut.

div1.head: σπουδαρχιάω
div1.sense: to canvass for office, Arist.

div1.head: σπουδαρχίδης
div1.sense: comic Patronymic of σπουδάρχης, son of placeman, Ar.

div1.head: σπούδασμα
div1.sense: a thing or work done with zeal, a pursuit, Plat.

div1.head: σπουδαστέος
div1.sense: to be sought for zealously, Xen.
σπουδαστέον, one must bestir oneself, be earnest or anxious, Eur., etc.

div1.head: σπουδαστής
div1.sense: one who wishes well to another, a supporter, partisan, Lat. fautor, Plut.

div1.head: σπουδαστικός
div1.sense: zealous, earnest, serious, Plat.

div1.head: σπουδαστός
div1.sense: that deserves to be sought or tried zealously, Plat.

div1.head: σπουδή
div1.sense: haste, speed, Hdt., etc.; ὅκως σπουδῆς ἔχει τις according as one makes speed, Hdt.

zeal, pains, exertion, trouble, Od., Attic: —σπουδὴν ποιεῖσθαι, c. inf., to take pains to do a thing, Hdt.; c. gen., σπουδήν τινος ποιήσασθαι to make much ado about a thing, Hdt.; so, σπ. ἔχειν τινός or εἴς τι Eur.; σπουδῇ ὅπλων with great attention to the arms, Thuc.:—in pl. zealous exertions, Hdt., Eur.; also party feelings, rivalries, Hdt., Ar.
zeal, earnestness, seriousness, Eur., etc.
an object of attention, a serious engagement, Eur.
σπουδῇ, as adv. in haste, hastily, Od., Hdt., Attic
with great exertion, with difficulty, hardly, scarcely, Hom.
earnestly, seriously, urgently, Eur., etc.; πολλῇ σπ. very busily, Hdt., etc.; so with Preps., ἀπὸ σπουδῆς in earnest, seriously, Il.; μετὰ σπουδῆς Xen.

div1.head: σποῦ
div1.sense: in Scythian, an eye, Hdt.

div1.head: σπυράς
div1.sense: a ball of dung, as that of sheep or goats: pl. sheepsʼ or goatsʼ dung, Ar.

div1.head: σπυρίς
div1.sense: a large basket, a creel (v. κόφινος), Hdt., Ar., etc.

div1.head: Σταγειρείτης
div1.sense: a Stagyrite, of Aristotle.

div1.head: Στάγειρος
div1.sense: a city in Macedonia, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: στάγμα
div1.sense: a drop, distilment, Aesch.

div1.head: σταγών
div1.sense: a drop, Trag.

div1.head: σταδαῖος
div1.sense: standing erect or upright, Aesch.; στ. ἔγχη pikes for close fight, opp. to missiles (cf. στάδιος 1), Aesch.

div1.head: σταδιασμός
div1.sense: a measuring by stades, Strab.

div1.head: σταδιοδρομέω
div1.sense: to run in the stadium, Dem.

div1.head: σταδιοδρόμος
div1.sense: one who runs the stadium, one who runs for a prize, Simon., Aeschin.

div1.head: στάδιον
div1.etym: pl. στάδια and στάδιοι, but never στάδιος in sg.
div1.sense: a fixed standard of length, a stade, = 100 ὀργυιαί or 6 πλέθρα, i. e. 600 Greek or 606 3/4 English feet, about 1/8 of a Roman mile, Polyb.: —"ἑκατὸν σταδίοισιν ἄριστος "best by a hundred miles, " Ar.; πλεῖν ἢ σταδίῳ λαλίστερος more loquacious than a mile and more, Ar.
a race-course (that of Olympia being a stade long), Pind., etc.; ἀγωνίζεσθαι στ. to run a race, Hdt.; στ. νικᾶν to win one, Xen.

div1.head: στάδιος
div1.sense: standing firm, σταδίη ὑσμίνη close fight, Lat. pugna stataria, Il.; ἐν σταδίῃ (sc. ὑσμίνῃ) Il.
firm, strong, Pind.

div1.head: στάζω
div1.sense: of persons,
c. acc. rei, to drop, let fall or shed drop by drop, Il., Aesch., etc.
c. dat. rei, αἵματι στ. to drip with blood, Aesch.; στάζων ἱδρῶτι Soph.;—rarely c. gen., Aesch.
intr. of things, to drop, fall in drops, drip, trickle, Hdt., Soph., Eur.; metaph., στάζει ἐν ὕπνωι πόνος Aesch.

div1.head: σταθερός
div1.sense: standing fast, steadfast, ἡ σταθερή (sc. γῆ) , terra firma, Anth.;—of the sea, calm, still, Anth.
στ. μεσημβρία high noon, when the sun seems to stand still in the meridian, Plat.
metaph. steady, deliberate, Anth.

div1.head: σταθευτός
div1.sense: scorched, burnt, Aesch.

div1.head: σταθεύω
div1.sense: to scorch, roast, fry, Ar.

div1.head: σταθμάω
div1.sense: to measure by rule, Eur.: —Pass., with fut. mid. -ήσομαι, to be measured, estimated, Ar.
as Dep. (v. σταθμόω), to estimate distance or size, without actual measurement, Hdt., Plat.: metaph. to estimate one thing by another, τί τινι Plat.; absol. to conjecture, Soph.
to attach weight to a thing, value it, Plat.

div1.head: στάθμη
div1.sense: a carpenterʼs line, Hom., Theogn.; —properly a line rubbed with chalk, distinguished from the rule (κανών) Xen., etc.:—proverb., παρὰ στάθμην by the rule, Lat. ad amussim, Theogn.; but in Aesch., παρὰ στ. beside the line, beyond measure; κατὰ στ. νοεῖν to guess aright, Theocr.
the plummet or the plumbline, Anth.
the line which bounds the racecourse, the goal, Lat. meta, Pind., Eur.
metaph. a law, rule, Ὑλλίδος στάθμας ἐν νόμοις, i. e. according to laws of Dorian rule, Pind.

div1.head: σταθμητός
div1.sense: to be measured, Plat.

div1.head: σταθμόνδε
div1.sense: to the stall, homewards, Od.

div1.head: σταθμός
div1.sense: a standing place for animals, Lat. stabulum, a stable, fold, Il.: a stye, Od.: of men, a dwelling, abode, Hes., Soph.
quarters, lodgings for travellers or soldiers, Lat. statio, Xen.
in Persia, σταθμοί were stations on the royal road, where the king rested, Hdt.: hence a dayʼs journey, dayʼs march, averaging about 5 parasangs or 15 miles, Hdt., Xen.
like Lat. statio, a station for ships, Eur.
an upright post, the bearing pillar of the roof, Od.: a door-post, esp. in pl., Hom., Attic
the balance, Ar., Il.; ἱστᾶν σταθμῷ τι πρός τι to weigh one thing against another, Hdt.
weight, σταθμὸν ἔχειν τάλαντον to weigh a talent, Hdt.; absol. in acc., ἴσα σταθμόν equal in weight, Hdt.; ἡμιπλίνθια σταθμὸν διτάλαντα two talents in or by weight, Hdt.:—in pl. weights, Eur., etc.

div1.head: σταθμόομαι
div1.etym: the aor1 mid. σταθμώσασθαι is = σταθμήσασθαι
div1.sense: to form an estimate, to judge or conclude by or from a thing, Hdt.

div1.head: σταῖς
div1.sense: flour of spelt mixed and made into dough, Hdt.

div1.head: σταίτινος
div1.sense: of flour or dough of spelt, Hdt., Plut.

div1.head: στακτός
div1.sense: oozing out in drops, trickling, dropping, distilling, Ar.

div1.head: στάλαγμα
div1.sense: that which drops, a drop, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: σταλαγμός
div1.sense: a dropping, dripping, Aesch., Eur.; στ. εἰρήνης the least drop of peace, Ar.

div1.head: σταλάσσω
div1.sense: to let drop, δάκρυ Eur.
intr. of things, to drop, drip, Eur.; c. acc. cogn., στ. φόνον to drop blood, Eur.

div1.head: σταλάω
div1.sense: to drop, let fall, δάκρυ Anth.

div1.head: στάλιξ
div1.sense: a stake to which nets are fastened, Xen., Theocr.

div1.head: σταλουργός
div1.sense: furnished with a στήλη or gravestone, Anth.

div1.head: σταμίν
div1.sense: pl., the ribs of a ship, which stand up from the keel, Lat. statumina, Od.

div1.head: σταμνίον
div1.sense: a wine-jar, Ar.

div1.head: στάμνος
div1.sense: an earthen jar for racking off wine, Ar.: cf. ἀμφορεύς.

div1.head: στασιάζω
div1.sense: intr. to rebel, revolt, rise in rebellion, τινί against one, Hdt., Xen., etc.; πρός τινα Xen.
in the Greek states, to form a party or faction, be at odds, quarrel, Hdt., etc.
of the states themselves, to be at discord, be distracted by factions, Ar., Thuc., etc.
trans. to revolutionise, throw into confusion, τὴν πόλιν Lys., etc.

div1.head: στασιαστικός
div1.sense: seditious, factious, Plat., etc.: Adv., στασιαστικῶς ἔχειν to be factious, Dem.

div1.head: στάσιμος
div1.sense: standing, stationary; of water, stagnant, Xen.
stable, steadfast, steady, firm, Plat.:—of men, steadfast, steady, solid, Lat. constans, Plat.:—of music, Arist.
στάσιμον (with or without μέλος) , in Tragedy, a regular song of the chorus, prob. so named because it was not sung till the chorus had taken its stand in the orchestra.

div1.head: στάσις
div1.sense: a standing, the posture of standing, Aesch., Plat.
a position, posture. post, station, Hdt., Eur.; τῆς στάσεως παρασύρων τὰς δρῦς tearing the oaks from their ground, Ar.
a point of the compass, ἡ στ. τῆς μεσαμβρίης Hdt.
the position, state or condition of a person, Lat. status, Plat.
a party, company, band, Aesch.: a sect of philosophers, Plut.
esp. a party formed for seditious purposes, a faction, Solon., Hdt., Attic
sedition, discord, Hdt., Attic; στάσιν ποιεῖσθαι Isocr.; πόλιν εἰς στάσιν ἐμβάλλειν Xen.

div1.head: στασιώδης
div1.sense: factious, Arist.: quarrelsome, Xen.

div1.head: στασιωρός
div1.sense: watcher of the station or fold, Eur.

div1.head: στασιωτεία
div1.sense: a state of faction, Plat.

div1.head: στασιώτης
div1.sense: mostly in pl. the members of a party or faction, partisans, Hdt., Attic

div1.head: στασιωτικός
div1.sense: factious, seditious, Thuc.

div1.head: στατέος
div1.sense: one must appoint, Plat.

div1.head: στατήρ
div1.sense: a weight, = λίτρα: then a coin of various values:
the gold stater best known at Athens was the Persian, called στατὴρ Δαρεικός or simply Δαρεικός, Daric, from Darius Hystaspes, worth about 1 l. 2s., Hdt., Thuc.
later a silver stater was in use, = τετράδραχμον, NTest., Xen.

div1.head: στατίζω
div1.sense: to place: Pass. = ἵσταμαι, to stand, Eur.:—so also intr. in Act., Eur.

div1.head: στατός
div1.sense: placed, standing, στατὸς ἵππος a stalled horse, Il., Soph.: —στατὸς χιτών a tunic reaching to the feet, Plut.

div1.head: σταυρός
div1.sense: an upright pale or stake, Hom., etc.: of piles driven in to serve as a foundation, Hdt., Thuc.
the Cross, NTest.: its form was represented by the Greek letter Τ, Luc.

div1.head: σταυροφόρος
div1.sense: bearing the cross, Anth.

div1.head: σταυρόω
div1.sense: to fence with pales, impalisade, Thuc.
to crucify, Polyb., NTest.

div1.head: σταύρωμα
div1.sense: a palisade or stockade, Lat. vallum, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: σταύρωσις
div1.sense: a palisading, Thuc.

div1.head: σταφυλή
div1.sense: a bunch of grapes, Hom., Theocr.
parox. σταφυλή, the plummet of a level, ἵπποι σταφυλῇ ἐπὶ νῶτον ἔϊσαι horses matched in height by the level, matched to a nicety, Il.

div1.head: σταφυλίς
div1.sense: a bunch of grapes, Theocr.

div1.head: σταφυλοκλοπίδης
div1.sense: a grape-stealer, Anth.

div1.head: σταχυητόμος
div1.sense: cutting ears of corn, Anth.

div1.head: σταχυητρόφος
div1.sense: nourishing ears of corn, Anth.

div1.head: σταχυμήτωρ
div1.sense: mother of ears of corn, Anth.

div1.head: σταχυοστέφανος
div1.sense: crowned with ears of corn, Anth.

div1.head: στάχυς
div1.sense: an ear of corn, Lat. spica, Il., Hes., etc.:—metaph., στ. ἄτης Aesch.; of the Theban Σπαρτοί, Eur.
generally, a scion, child, progeny, Anth.

div1.head: στέαρ
div1.sense: stiff fat, tallow, suet, Lat. sebum, opp. to πιμελή (Lat. adeps, soft fat), Od., Xen.

div1.head: στεγάζω
div1.sense: to cover, Xen.: metaph., ὕπνος στ. τινά covers, embraces one, Soph.:—Pass., πλοῖον ἐστεγασμένον a decked vessel, Antipho.

div1.head: στεγάνη
div1.sense: a covering, Anth.

div1.head: στεγανός
div1.sense: covering so as to keep out water, water-tight, waterproof, Xen., Anth.
generally, covering, enclosing, confining, of a net, Aesch.
closely covered, λευκῆς χιόνος πτέρυγι στεγανός, of Polynices, represented as an eagle, covered by his white Argive shield (v. λεύκασπις), Soph.; of a building, roofed, Thuc.
metaph., τὸ οὐ στεγανόν leakiness, Plat.
adv. -νῶς, confinedly, through a tube, Thuc.

div1.head: στέγαρχος
div1.sense: master of the house, Hdt.

div1.head: στέγασμα
div1.sense: anything which covers, a covering, Xen.:— a roof, Lat. tectum, Plat.

div1.head: στεγαστέος
div1.sense: one must cover, Xen.

div1.head: στεγαστός
div1.sense: covered, sheltered, Strab.

div1.head: στεγαστρίς
div1.sense: that serves for covering, Hdt.

div1.head: στέγαστρον
div1.sense: a covering, cover, wrapper, Aesch., Plut.

div1.head: στέγη
div1.sense: a roof, Lat. tectum, Hdt., Aesch., Xen., etc.
a roofed place, a chamber, room, Hdt., Xen., etc.; ἑρκεῖος στ., of a tent, Soph.; ἐκ κατώρυχος στέγη, of the grave, Soph.
often in pl., like Lat. tecta, a house, dwelling, Aesch.; κατὰ στέγας at home, Soph.

div1.head: στεγνός
div1.sense: waterproof, Hdt.; στεγνὰ οἰκήματα, of a cave, Eur.
as Subst., στεγνόν, οῦ, a covered dwelling, Xen.

div1.head: στεγνοφυής
div1.sense: of thick nature, Anth.

div1.head: στέγος
div1.sense: a roof: then, like στέγη, a house, mansion, Aesch., Soph., etc.:—of an urn containing ashes, Soph.

div1.head: στέγω
div1.sense: to cover closely, so as to keep water either out or in:
to keep water out, νῆες οὐδὲν στέγουσαι not watertight, Thuc.:—so in Mid., στέγεσθαι ὄμβρους to keep off rain from oneself, Pind.; ναῦς οὐκ ἐστέξατο κῦμα Anth.
generally, to keep off, fend off weapons, etc., δόρυ στέγειν Aesch.; στ. τὰς πληγάς Ar.
later, to bear up against, endure, Polyb., NTest.:—absol. to contain oneself, hold out, NTest.
with acc. of the thing covered, to cover, shelter, protect, Soph., Xen.
to cover, conceal, keep hidden, Soph., Eur.:—Pass. to be kept secret, Thuc.; παρʼ ὑμῶν εὖ στεγοίμεθʼ let my counsel be kept secret by you, Soph.
to keep water in, hold water, keep in, Eur., Plat.
generally, to contain, hold, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: στείβω
div1.sense: to tread on, tread under foot, Hom.
c. acc. cogn. to tread or walk on a path, Eur.; also, χοροὺς στείβειν to tread measures, Eur.
absol. to tread, Eur.
to stamp down, in Pass., Theocr.; αἱ στειβόμεναι ὁδοί the beaten roads, Xen.

div1.head: στειλειή
div1.sense: the hole for the handle of an axe, Od.

div1.head: στειλειόν
div1.sense: the handle or helve of an axe, Od.

div1.head: στειναύχην
div1.sense: narrow-necked, Anth.

div1.head: στεῖνος
div1.sense: a narrow, strait, confined space, Hom.; στεῖνος ὁδοῦ Il.
generally, pressure, straits, distress, Hhymn.; σωφρονεῖν ὑπὸ στένει to learn wisdom by suffering, Aesch.

div1.head: στείνω
div1.sense: to straiten: Pass. to become strait, to be narrowed, Od.; of persons, to be straitened for room, Il.

to be or become full, be thronged, c. gen., στείνοντο δὲ σηκοὶ ἀρνῶν the folds were crowded with lambs, Od.; c. dat., ποταμὸς στεινόμενος νεκύεσσι Il.:—metaph., ἀρνειὸς λάχνῳ στεινόμενος burdened with its wool, Od.

div1.head: στεῖρα
div1.sense: a shipʼs keel, esp. the curved part of it, cutwater, Lat. carina, Hom.

div1.head: στεῖρα
div1.sense: a cow that has not calved, Od.: of a woman, barren, NTest., Anth.

div1.head: στεῖρος
div1.sense: barren, Lat. sterilis, Eur.

div1.head: στείχω
div1.sense: to walk, march, go or come, Od., Hdt., Trag.:—c. acc. loci, to go to, approach, Trag.
to go after one another, go in line or order (whence στίχος, στίχες, στοῖχος), Il., Hdt.
c. acc. cogn., στ. ὁδόν Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: στελεόν
div1.sense: a handle, Babr., Anth.

div1.head: στελεόω
div1.sense: to furnish with a handle, Anth.

div1.head: στελεχητόμος
div1.sense: cutting stems, Anth.

div1.head: στελεχόω
div1.sense: Mid. Pass. to grow into a stem, Strab.

div1.head: στέλεχος
div1.sense: the crown of the root, stump, whence the trunk springs, Lat. codex, Pind., Dem.

div1.head: στέλλω
div1.sense: to set in order, to arrange, array, equip, make ready, Hom., Hdt., Attic:—also, στέλλειν τινὰ ἐσθῆτι to furnish with a garment, Hdt.; so c. dupl. acc., στολὴν στ. τινά Eur.:—Mid., στείλασθαι πέπλους to put on robes, Hdt.; metaph., ἐπὶ θήρας πόθον ἐστέλλου didst set thy heart upon the chase, Hdt.:—Pass. to fit oneself out, get ready, Il., Hdt.; στολὴν ἐσταλμένος equipt in a dress, Hdt.; ἐστ. ἐπὶ πόλεμον Xen.; metaph., ἐπὶ τυραννίδʼ ἐστάλης Ar.

to despatch on an expedition, and, generally, to despatch, send, Aesch., Soph.:—Pass. to get ready for an expedition, to start, set out, Hdt.; and in aor2 pass. to have set out, to be on oneʼs way, Hdt.; c. acc. cogn., ὁδὸν στέλλεσθαι Soph.; στέλλου begone! Aesch.

in Attic the Act. has sometimes the intr. sense of the Pass., like Lat. trajicere, to prepare to go, start, set forth, where στόλον may be supplied, ἔστελλε ἐς ἀποικίην Hdt., etc.:—reversely, ἡ ὁδὸς εἰς Κόρινθον στέλλει leads to Corinth, Luc.
Mid. in sense of μεταπέμπομαι, to send for one, Soph.: also to fetch, bring a person to a place, Soph.
to bring together, gather up, ἱστία στεῖλαν took in, furled the sails, Od.: and in Mid., ἱστία μὲν στείλαντο they furled their sails, Il.; χιτῶνας ἐστάλατο they girded up their clothes to work, Hes.
in Mid. also to check, repress, λόγον στέλλεσθαι to draw in oneʼs words, i. e. not speak out the whole truth, Eur.
also in Mid. to shrink from a thing, avoid it, NTest.

div1.head: στελμονία
div1.sense: broad belts put round dogs when used to hunt wild beasts, Xen.

div1.head: στέμβω
div1.sense: to shake, agitate, Aesch.

div1.head: στέμμα
div1.sense: a wreath, garland, wound by suppliants round a staff or olive branch, Il., Soph.; sometimes worn on the head, Hdt.

div1.head: στέμφυλον
div1.sense: a mass of olives from which the oil has been pressed, olive-cake, Ar.

div1.head: στέναγμα
div1.sense: a sigh, groan, moan, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: στεναγμός
div1.sense: a sighing, groaning, moaning, Trag.

div1.head: στενάζω
div1.sense: to sigh often, sigh deeply, generally, to sigh, groan, moan, Trag.; τί ἐστέναξας τοῦτο; why utterdst thou this moan? Eur.; c. acc. cogn., παιᾶνα στ. Eur.
trans. to bemoan, bewail, Soph., etc.

div1.head: στενακτέος
div1.sense: one must bewail, Eur.

div1.head: στενακτός
div1.sense: to be mourned, giving cause for grief, Soph., Eur.
mournful, Eur.

div1.head: στεναχίζω
div1.sense: only in pres. and imperf. to sigh, groan, wail, Hom.:—so in Mid., Il.
trans. to bewail, lament, Od.

div1.head: στενάχω
div1.sense: to sigh, groan, wail, Hom.: so in Mid., Il., Aesch., Soph.:—metaph. of the roar of torrents, Il.; the loud breathing of horses galloping, Il.; στοᾶς στεναχούσης groaning from being overcrowded, Ar.
trans. to bewail, lament, Il., Aesch.; so in Mid., Od.

div1.head: στενολεσχέω
div1.sense: to talk subtly, quibble, Ar.

div1.head: στενόπορθμος
div1.sense: at or on a strait, Eur.

div1.head: στενοπορία
div1.sense: a narrow way or pass, Xen.

div1.head: στενόπορος
div1.sense: with a narrow pass or outlet, Hdt., Aesch., Eur.
as Subst. στενόπορα, Ionic στειν-, τά, narrow passes, defiles, Hdt., Thuc.: —in sg. στενόπορον, ου, a strait, narrow, Xen.

div1.head: στενός
div1.sense: narrow, strait, Hdt., Eur., etc.; ἐν στενῷ, Ionic στεινῷ, in a narrow compass, Hdt., Aesch.
as Subst., τὰ στενά the straits, of a pass, Hdt.; of a sea, Thuc.; also, ἡ στενή a narrow strip of land, Thuc.
metaph. narrow, close, confined, ἀπειληθῆναι ἐς στεινόν to be driven into a corner, Hdt.; εἰς στ. καταστῆναι Dem.
scanty, little, petty, Plat.—From old Ionic forms στεινότερος, -ότατος, come irr. Attic στενότερος, -ότατος· but reg. στενώτερος also occurs.

div1.head: στενόστομος
div1.sense: narrow-mouthed, Strab.

div1.head: στενότης
div1.sense: narrowness, straitness, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: στενοχωρέω
div1.sense: to straiten for room, Luc.:—Pass. to be crowded together: metaph. to be straitened, NTest.

div1.head: στενοχωρία
div1.sense: narrowness of space: want of room, Thuc., etc.:—metaph., ἡ στ. τοῦ ποταμοῦ the difficulty of passing the river, Xen.

div1.head: στενόω
div1.sense: to straiten:—in Pass., Anth.

div1.head: Στεντόρειος
div1.sense: Stentorian, with a voice like Stentorʼs, Arist.

div1.head: Στέντωρ
div1.sense: Stentor, a Greek at Troy, famous for his loud voice, Il.

div1.head: στένω
div1.sense: to moan, sigh, groan, Hom., Trag.; so in Mid., Aesch., Eur.
c. gen. to moan or sigh for, Eur.; ὑπέρ τινος Aesch.; τινί or ἐπί τινι Eur.; c. acc. cogn., πένθος οἰκεῖον στ. Soph.:—Mid., Aesch.
c. acc. to bewail, lament, Aesch., etc.; στένειν τινὰ τῆς τύχης to pity him for his ill fortune, Aesch.: so in Mid., στένεσθαί τινα Eur.

div1.head: στενωπός
div1.sense: narrow-looking, narrow, strait, confined, Il.
as Subst., στενωπός (sc. ὁδός) , a narrow passage or way, strait, Od., etc.

div1.head: στεπτός
div1.sense: crowned, Anth.

div1.head: στέργηθρον
div1.sense: a love-charm, love, affection, in sg. and pl., Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: στέργημα
div1.sense: a love-charm, τινος to influence him, Soph.

div1.head: στέργω
div1.sense: to love, of the mutual love of parents and children, Soph., Eur., etc.; of king and people, Hdt., Soph.; of a country and her colonies, Thuc.; of brothers and sisters, Eur.; of friends, Soph.; of husband and wife, Hdt., Soph.
generally, to be fond of, shew liking for, Theogn., Soph., etc.:—also of things, to accept gladly, Hdt., etc.
to be content or satisfied, acquiesce, Soph., Dem.; στέρξον oblige me, do me the favour, Soph.

c. acc. to be content with, acquiesce in, submit to, bear with, Hdt.; στ. τὴν τυραννίδα bear with it, Aesch.; στ. κακά Soph.:—also c. dat., στ. τοῖσι σοῖς Eur.; τῆι ἐμῆι τύχηι Plat.:—c. part., πῶς ἂν στέρξαιμι κακὸν τόδε λεύσσων Soph.; στ. ξυμφορᾶι νικώμενοι Eur.:—rarely c. inf., οὐκ ἔστεργέ σοι ὅμοιος εἶναι Eur.
to entreat one to do, Ἀπόλλω στέργω μολεῖν Soph.

div1.head: στερεός
div1.sense: stiff, stark, firm, solid, Hom., etc.; αἰχμὴ στερεὴ πᾶσα χρυσέη all of solid gold, Hdt.:—adv. -εῶς, firmly, fast, Hom.
metaph. stiff, stubborn, harsh, Hom., etc.: so in adv., Hom.
στ. ἀριθμός a cubic number, Arist.

div1.head: στερεόφρων
div1.sense: stubborn-hearted, Soph.

div1.head: στερεόω
div1.sense: to make firm or solid, Xen.:— to strengthen, NTest.:—Pass. to be made strong, Xen.

div1.head: στερέωμα
div1.sense: a solid body, foundation: metaph. steadfastness, NTest.

div1.head: στερέω
div1.sense: to deprive, bereave, rob of anything, c. acc. pers. et gen. rei, Od., Trag., etc.:—Pass. to be deprived, bereaved or robbed of anything, c. gen., Hdt., Attic
c. acc. rei, to take away, Anth.:—Pass. to have taken from one, βίον στερείς Eur.

div1.head: στέρησις
div1.sense: deprivation, privation, of a thing, Thuc.: absol. negation, privation, Arist.

div1.head: στερίσκω
div1.sense: to deprive of a thing, Thuc.:—Pass. to be deprived of a thing, Hdt., Attic

div1.head: στέριφος
div1.sense: firm, solid, Thuc.
= στεῖρος, Lat. sterilis, barren, Plat.

div1.head: στερκτός
div1.sense: to be loved, amiable, loved, Soph.

div1.head: στέρνον
div1.sense: the breast, chest, both in sg. and pl., Hom., Trag.
the breast as the seat of the affections, the heart, Trag.

div1.head: στερνοτυπής
div1.sense: of or from beaten breasts, Eur., Anth.

div1.head: στερνοτυπία
div1.sense: a beating of the breast for grief, Luc.

div1.head: στερνοῦχος
div1.sense: broad-swelling, of a plain, Soph.

div1.head: στέρομαι
div1.sense: to be wanting in, to lack, want, Lat. carere, c. gen., Hes., Hdt., Attic:—absol. to suffer loss, Soph., Xen.

div1.head: στεροπηγερέτα
div1.sense: either (from ἀγείρω, cf. νεφεληγερέτα) he who gathers the lightning, or (from ἐγείρω) who rouses the lightning, Il.

div1.head: στεροπή
div1.sense: a flash of lightning, Il., Hes., etc.:—generally flash, gleam, sheen, Hom.

div1.head: Στερόπης
div1.sense: lightner, name of one of the three Cyclopes, Hes.

div1.head: στέροψ
div1.sense: flashing, Soph.

div1.head: στερρόγυιος
div1.sense: with strong limbs, Anth.

div1.head: στερρός
div1.sense: stiff, firm, solid, strong, Eur.: stiff with age, Ar.
hard, rugged, uneasy, λέκτρα Eur.
metaph. stubborn, obdurate, hard, Aesch., Eur., etc.:—adv., στερρῶς, stiffly, obstinately, Xen.

div1.head: στεῦμαι
div1.etym: used by Hom. only in 3rd sg. pres. and imperf. στεῦται, στεῦτο, and once by Aesch. in 3rd pl. στεῦνται
div1.sense: Dep., to make as if one would, to promise or threaten that one will, Il.; also with aor. inf., στεῦται ἀκοῦσαι Od.; so, στεῦται ἀμφιβαλεῖν Aesch.: —absol., στεῦτο he made eager efforts, Od.

div1.head: στεφανηπλόκια
div1.sense: a place where wreaths are plaited or sold, Anth.

div1.head: στεφανηπλόκος
div1.sense: plaiting wreaths, Plut.

div1.head: στεφάνη
div1.sense: anything that encircles the head, for defence or ornament:
the brim of the helmet, projecting behind as well as before, Il.
part of a womanʼs head-dress, a diadem, coronal, Il., Hes., etc.:—metaph., of a city, ἀπὸ στεφάναν κέκαρσαι πύργων thou hast been shorn of thy coronal of towers, Eur.
the brim or edge of anything, the brow of a hill, edge of a cliff, Il.; of a basket, Mosch.

div1.head: στεφανηφορέω
div1.sense: to wear a wreath, Eur., Dem.

div1.head: στεφανηφορία
div1.sense: the wearing a wreath, esp. of victory, Pind., Eur.
the right of wearing a crown, Dem.

div1.head: στεφανηφόρος
div1.sense: wearing a crown or wreath, crowned, Eur.; στ. ἀγών στεφανίτης ἀγών, Hdt.
the title of certain magistrates who had the right of wearing crowns, as the Archons, Aeschin.

div1.head: στεφανίζω
div1.sense: to crown, Ar.

div1.head: στεφανίτης
div1.sense: of a crown: στ. ἀγών acontest in which the prize was a crown, Xen., Dem.

div1.head: στέφανος
div1.sense: properly, that which surrounds, στ. πολέμοιο the circling crowd of fight, Il.; of the wall round a town, Pind.; καλλίπαις στ. a circle of fair children, Eur.

a crown, wreath, garland, chaplet, Hes., etc.: esp. at the public games, a crown of victory, Pind., Hdt., etc.:— these prize-crowns were mostly of leaves, of κότινος at the Olympic games, δάφνη at the Pythian, σέλινον at the Nemean, κισσός or πίτυς at the Isthmian.
generally, the meed of victory, the prize, victory, like Lat. palma, Soph.; στέφανον προτιθέναι to propose a prize, Thuc.
generally, a crown of glory, an honour, glory, Inscr. ap. Hdt.:— a crown as a badge of office or distinction, Dem.

div1.head: στεφανόω
div1.sense: used by Hom. in Pass., to be put round, Lat. circumdari, ἢν περὶ μὲν φόβος ἐστεφάνωται round about which (the shield) is Terror wreathed, Il.; ἀμφὶ δέ μιν νέφος ἐστεφάνωτο all round about him was a cloud, Il.; περὶ νῆσον πόντος ἐστεφάνωται the sea lies round about the island, Od.
to be surrounded, Lat. cingi, ἐστεφανωμένος τιήρην μυρσίνηι having his tiara wreathed with myrtle, Hdt.

Act. to crown, wreathe, χαίτην Pind.; στ. τινά Eur., etc.: c. dupl. acc., εὐαγγέλια στεφανοῦν τινά to crown one for good tidings, Ar.:—Pass. to be crowned or rewarded with a crown, Hdt., Pind.:—Mid. to crown oneself, στεφανοῦσθε κισσῶι Eur., Ar.
in Mid. to win a crown, of the victor at the games, Pind.
to crown as an honour or reward, Eur., Lys.:—to crown or honour with libations, Eur.
Pass. to wear a crown as a badge of office, Xen., Dem.

div1.head: στεφανώδης
div1.sense: like a wreath, wreathed, Eur.

div1.head: στεφάνωμα
div1.sense: that which surrounds, a crown or wreath, Theogn., Pind.; στ. πύργων [the cityʼs] coronal of towers, Soph.
a crown as the prize of victory, Pind.
an honour, glory, Pind.

div1.head: στέφος
div1.sense: a crown, wreath, garland, Eur.; pl. στέφη, στέμματα, Aesch., Soph.
of libations, Aesch.

div1.head: στέφω
div1.sense: to put round, Lat. circumdare, ἀμφὶ κεφαλῆι νέφος ἔστεφε δῖα θεάων Il.; θεὸς μορφὴν ἔπεσι στέφει Od.:—Mid. to put round oneʼs head, Anth.
to surround, crown, wreath, τινὰ ἄνθεσι Hes.; μυρσίνης κλάδοις Eur.:—Mid., στέφου κάρα crown thy head, Eur.:—Pass. to be crowned, Aesch.
to crown with libations, Soph.

div1.head: στῆθος
div1.sense: the breast, Lat. pectus, Hom., Xen.
metaph. the breast as the seat of feeling, the heart, Hom. (always in pl.), Aesch.

div1.head: στήκω
div1.etym: late pres. formed from ἕστηκα perf. of ἵστημι
div1.sense: to stand, NTest.

div1.head: στήλη
div1.sense: a block of stone used as a prop or buttress to a wall, Il.: a block of rockcrystal, in which the Egyptian mummies were cased, Hdt.
a block or slab, bearing an inscription; and so,
a gravestone, Hom., Attic

a block or slab, inscribed with record of victories, dedications, treaties, decrees, etc., Hdt., Attic; γράφειν τινὰ εἰς στήλην, ἀναγράφειν ἐν στήλῃ, whether for honour, or for infamy, Hdt., Dem.:—also the record itself, a contract, agreement, κατὰ τὴν στήλην according to agreement, Ar.; στῆλαι αἱ πρὸς Θηβαίους Dem.
a boundary post, Xen.:— the turning-post at the end of the racecourse, Lat. meta, Soph., Xen.
for Στῆλαι Ἡρακλήιαι, v. Ἡράκλειος.

div1.head: στηλίτης
div1.sense: of or like a στήλη, Luc., Anth.
inscribed on a στήλη, posted or placarded as infamous, στηλίτην τινὰ ἀναγράφειν, ποιεῖν Isocr., Dem.

div1.head: στηλόω
div1.sense: to set up as a monument, Anth.

div1.head: στημόνιον
div1.etym: Dim. of στήμων signf. I, Arist.

div1.head: στημορραγέω
div1.sense: intr. to be torn to shreds, Aesch.

div1.head: στήμων
div1.sense: the warp in the ancient upright loom, Hes., Plat.
a thread, Batr.

div1.head: στήριγμα
div1.sense: a support, Eur.
= στῆριγξ 2, Plut.

div1.head: στηριγμός
div1.sense: a propping, supporting; and (in pass. sense) fixedness, steadfastness, NTest.

div1.head: στῆριγξ
div1.sense: a support, prop, stay, Xen.
the fork with which the pole of a two-wheeled chariot was propped, Lat. furca, Lys.

div1.head: στηρίζω
div1.sense: to make fast, prop, fix, set, Il.; λίθον κατὰ χθονὸς ἐστ. he set the stone fast in the ground, Hes.:—Mid. to fix for oneself, Anth.
metaph. to confirm, establish, NTest.
intr. = Pass., στηρίξαι ποσὶν ἔμπεδον Od.; κῦμα οὐρανῶι στηρίζον a wave rising up to heaven, Eur.; and metaph., κλέος οὐρανῶι στηρίζον Eur.
of diseases, to fix, settle, determine to a particular part, ὁπότε εἰς τὴν καρδίαν στηρίξαι (sc. ἡ νόσος) Thuc.

Pass. and Mid. to be firmly set or fixed, to stand fast or steady, στηρίξασθαι to get a firm footing, Il.; δώματα πρὸς οὐρανὸν ἐστήρικται the house is lifted up to heaven, Hes.; so, ὀρθὴ δʼ ἐς ὀρθὴν αἰθέρʼ ἐστηρίξατο Eur.
metaph., ὅπου στηρίζει ποτέ wheresoever thou art tarrying, art settled, Soph.

div1.head: στήσιος
div1.sense: Ζεὺς Στ. Jupiter Stator, Plut.

div1.head: Στησίχορος
div1.sense: the Lyric poet Stesichorus, whose real name was Tisias, Simon.

div1.head: στιβαδοκοιτέω
div1.sense: to sleep on litter, Polyb.

div1.head: στιβαρός
div1.sense: compact, strong, stout, sturdy, Hom., Hes.

div1.head: στιβάς
div1.sense: a bed of straw, rushes, or leaves, Eur., Theocr.
a mattress, pallet, Hdt., Ar.

div1.head: στιβέω
div1.sense: to tread, traverse: Pass., πᾶν ἐστίβηται πλευρόν every side has been traversed, Soph.

div1.head: στίβη
div1.sense: frozen dew, rime, hoar frost, Od.

div1.head: στιβίζομαι
div1.sense: Mid. or Pass. to paint oneʼs eyelids and eyebrows with black paint (στίβι) , Strab.

div1.head: στίβι
div1.sense: Lat. stibium, = στίμμι.

div1.head: στίβος
div1.sense: a trodden way, track, path, Hhymn., Soph., etc.
a track, footstep, Hdt., Aesch., etc.; κατὰ στίβον on the track or trail, Hdt.; στίβοι φιλάνορες traces of her who had lain in the bed, Aesch.
a going, gait, Soph.

div1.head: στιγεύς
div1.sense: one who tattooes, a tattooer, Hdt.

div1.head: στίγμα
div1.sense: the mark of a pointed instrument, a tattoo-mark, brand, Hdt., NTest.

div1.head: στιγματηφορέω
div1.sense: to bear tattoo-marks, Luc.

div1.head: στιγματίας
div1.sense: one who bears tattoo-marks, a branded culprit, runaway slave, Xen., etc.

div1.head: στιγμή
div1.sense: a spot, point, Arist.:— metaph. a jot, tittle, Dem.; ἐν στ. χρόνου in a moment, NTest.

div1.head: στίζω
div1.etym: the Root is !στιγ, cf. ἔστιγμαι, στιγμή, etc.
div1.sense: to mark with a pointed instrument, to tattoo, Hdt., Xen.
to brand, as a mark of disgrace, Hdt., Ar.; ἔστιζον στίγματα βασιλήια branded them with the royal brand-marks, Hdt.; esp. of runaways, δραπέτης ἐστιγμένος Ar.
c. dupl. acc., στίγματα στίζειν τινά to brand one with a mark, Hdt.
metaph., βακτηρίαι στ. to beat black and blue, Ar.
to mark with a full stop, Lat. interpungere, Anth.

div1.head: στικτός
div1.sense: punctured, Anth.:—generally, spotted, dappled, Soph., Eur.; στικτὰ ὄμματα, of the hundred eyes of Argus, Eur.

div1.head: στίλβω
div1.sense: to glisten, Hom., Eur.; c. acc. cogn., στ. ἀστραπάς to flash lightning, Eur.:—metaph. to shine, be bright, Eur.

div1.head: στίλη
div1.sense: a drop, Lat. stilla: metaph. a little bit, a moment, Ar.

div1.head: στιλπνός
div1.sense: glittering, glistening, Il.

div1.head: στίξ
div1.etym: the other cases are taken from στίχος
div1.sense: a row, line, rank or file, esp. of soldiers, Il., Aesch., etc.:—metaph., ἐπέων στίχες verses, lays, Pind.

div1.head: στιπτός
div1.sense: trodden down, close-pressed, Lat. stipatus, Soph.; στιπτοὶ γέροντες tough, sturdy old fellows, Ar.

div1.head: στῖφος
div1.sense: a close-pressed or compact body: a body of men in close array, a column, mass, Hdt., Aesch.; νεῶν στῖφος the close array of ships, Aesch.

div1.head: στιφρός
div1.sense: firm, solid, Xen.

div1.head: στιχαοιδός
div1.sense: one who sings verses, a poet, Anth.

div1.head: στιχάομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to march in rows or ranks, esp. of soldiers, Il.; of ships in line, Il.; of shepherds with their herds, Il.: later, we have Epic 3rd pl. στιχόωσι in same sense, Mosch.

div1.head: στίχινος
div1.sense: of lines or verses, στ. θάνατος of one who was rhymed to death, Anth.

div1.head: στιχογράφος
div1.sense: writing verse, Anth.

div1.head: στίχος
div1.sense: a row or file of soldiers, Xen.
a line of poetry, a verse, Ar.

div1.head: στλεγγίς
div1.sense: a scraper, to remove the oil and dirt (γλοίος) from the skin in the bath, Plat., etc.
a tiara, Xen.

div1.head: στοά
div1.sense: a roofed colonnade, piazza, cloister, Lat. porticus, Hdt., Xen.
at Athens this name was given to various public buildings:
a storehouse, magazine, warehouse for corn, Ar.
ἡ βασίλειος or ἡ τοῦ βασιλέως στοά the court where the ἄρχων βασιλεύς sat, Ar., Plat.
the Poecile or Painted Chamber, in which Zeno of Citium taught, and so his school was called οἱ ἐκ τῆς στοᾶς or Στωικοί, Luc.
a shed to protect besiegers, Polyb.

div1.head: στοιβάζω
div1.sense: to pile up, pack together, Luc.

div1.head: στοιβή
div1.sense: a plant used for stuffing or padding; and metaph. " padding, " an expletive, Ar.

div1.head: στοιχάς
div1.sense: in rows:— αἱ Στοιχάδες (sc. νῆσοι) a row of islands off Marseilles, now les Isles dʼ Hieres, Strab.

div1.head: στοιχεῖον
div1.sense: properly, one of a row: hence,
in the sun-dial, the shadow of the gnomon, Ar.
generally, one of a series, an elementary sound of the voice, a letter, Plat.:— κατὰ στοιχεῖον in the order of the letters, alphabetically, Anth.
in pl. the elements, Plat., etc.
the elements of knowledge, rudiments, ἀρξάμενοι ἀπὸ τῶν στ. Xen.

div1.head: στοιχέω
div1.sense: to go in a line or row: to go in battle-order, Xen.
c. dat. to be in line with, walk by rule or principle, c. dat., NTest.

div1.head: στοιχηγορέω
div1.sense: to tell in regular order, Aesch.

div1.head: στοιχίζω
div1.sense: to set a row of poles with nets to drive the game into, Xen.
to order or arrange in system, Aesch.

div1.head: στοῖχος
div1.sense: a row, στοῖχοι τῶν ἀναβαθμῶν, of a flight of steps, Hdt.; κατὰ στοῖχον in a row, Thuc.: of ships, a column, ἐν στοίχοις τρισί Aesch.; of soldiers, a file, Thuc.
a line of poles supporting hunting-nets, Xen.

div1.head: στολάς
div1.sense: moving in close array, Eur.

div1.head: στολή
div1.sense: an equipment, armament, Aesch.
equipment, raiment, apparel, Hdt., Trag.
a piece of dress, a garment, robe, Soph., Eur., etc.; στ. θηρός, of the lionʼs skin which Hercules wore, Eur.

div1.head: στολιδόομαι
div1.sense: Mid. to dress oneself in a garment, c. acc., Eur.

div1.head: στολιδωτός
div1.sense: στ. χιτών a tunic hanging in folds, Xen.

div1.head: στολίζω
div1.sense: to put in trim, στολίσας νηὸς πτερά having trimmed the sails, Hes.
to equip, dress:—Pass., ἐστολισμένος δορί armed with spear, Eur.
metaph. to deck, adorn, Anth.

div1.head: στόλιον
div1.sense: a scanty garment, Anth.

div1.head: στόλισμα
div1.sense: a garment, mantle, Eur.

div1.head: στολίς
div1.sense: a garment, robe, Eur., etc.; νεβρῶν στολίδες, i. e. fawnskins worn as garments, Eur.
νηῶν στολίδες sails, Anth.
in pl. folds in a garment, Eur.

div1.head: στόλος
div1.sense: an equipment for warlike purposes, an expedition by land or sea, Hdt., Trag., etc.; τεθριπποβάμων στ. an equipage with four horses, Eur.
generally, a journey or voyage, Soph., etc.; ἰδίῳ στόλῳ in a journey on oneʼs own account, opp. to δημοσίῳ or κοινῷ στ. (on behalf of the state), Hdt., Thuc.
the purpose or cause of a journey, a mission, errand, Soph., Ar.
an armament, army, or, a sea-force, fleet, Attic; οὐ πολλῷ στόλῳ, i. e. in one ship, Soph.; πρόπας στόλος all the host, Soph.
παγκρατίου στ., periphr. for παγκράτιον, Pind.
= ἔμβολον, a shipʼs beak, Pind., Aesch.

div1.head: στομαλίμνη
div1.sense: a salt-water lake, estuary, Strab.: so, στομάλιμνον, ου, τό, Theocr.

div1.head: στόμα
div1.sense: the mouth, Lat. os, Hom., etc.

the mouth as the organ of speech, δέκα μὲν γλῶσσαι, δέκα δὲ στόματʼ Il.; στ. τὸ δῖον the mouth of Jove, Aesch.; Μοισᾶν στόμα their mouthpiece, Theocr.;—with Preps., ἀνὰ στόμα ἔχειν to have always in oneʼs mouth, Eur.: ἀπὸ στόματος by word of mouth, Xen., etc.: διὰ στόμα was in every oneʼs mouth, Aesch.; πᾶσι διὰ στόματος ʼtis the common talk, Theocr.: ἐξ ἑνὸς στ. with one voice, Ar.; κατὰ στόμα face to face, Hdt., Attic

στ. ποταμοῦ the mouth of a river, Lat. ostia, Hom., etc.; so, ἠιόνος στ. μακρόν the wide mouth of the bay, Il.; στ. τοῦ Πόντου, Lat. fauces Ponti, Hdt.:—also, a chasm or cleft in the earth with a stream gushing out, Hdt.; τὸ ἄνω, τὸ κάτω στόμα τοῦ ὀρύγματος the opening or width of the trench at top, at bottom, Hdt.
any outlet or entrance, Od., Xen.
the foremost part, face, front:
of weapons, the point, Il.; the edge of a sword, NTest.:—also like Lat. acies, the front, στόμα πολέμοιο, ὑσμίνης Il.; so alone, Xen.
generally, ἄκρον στ. πύργων the top of the towers, Eur.; τὸ στόμα τοῦ βίου the verge of life, Xen.

div1.head: στόμαργος
div1.sense: busy with the tongue, loud-tongued, Aesch., Soph.; στ. γλωσσαλγία wearisome wordiness, Eur.

div1.head: στοματουργός
div1.sense: word-making, Ar.

div1.head: στόμαχος
div1.sense: properly, a mouth, opening: hence,
the throat, gullet, Il.
in late Gr. the orifice of the stomach, the stomach.

div1.head: στόμιον
div1.sense: the mouth of a cave, Soph.: a cave, vault, Aesch.: the socket of a bolt, Anth.
a bridle-bit, bit, Hdt., Trag.; metaph., στ. Τροίας a bit or curb for Troy, i. e. the Greek army, Aesch.

div1.head: στομόω
div1.sense: to muzzle or gag, Hdt.
(στόμα II) to furnish with an edge: metaph. to steel, harden, train for anything, Ar.:—Pass., Plut.
to fringe, fence, Plut.; Pass., [δράκαινα ἐχίδναις ἐστομωμένη Eur.

div1.head: στομφάζω
div1.sense: to mouth, rant, vaunt, Ar.

div1.head: στόμφαξ
div1.sense: a mouther, ranter, Ar.

div1.head: στόμωμα
div1.sense: a mouth, entrance, Aesch.

div1.head: στόμωσις
div1.sense: a furnishing with a sharp edge: metaph., πολλὴν στόμωσιν ἔχειν to have a sharp edge, Soph.

div1.head: στοναχέω
div1.sense: to groan, sigh, Il.
trans. to sigh, groan over or for, τινά Soph., Mosch.

div1.head: στοναχή
div1.sense: a groaning, wailing, Hom., Eur.; in pl. groans, sighs, Il., Soph.

div1.head: στονόεις
div1.sense: causing groans or sighs, Hom., Aesch., etc.
generally, mournful, sad, wretched, Hom., Soph.; neut. as adv., Aesch.

div1.head: στόνος
div1.sense: a sighing, groaning, lamentation, Hom.; of the sea, Soph.

div1.head: στόνυξ
div1.sense: any sharp point, as of a rock, Eur.: a pen-knife, Anth.

div1.head: στοργή
div1.sense: love, affection, of parents and children, Antipho.

div0.div1: στόρνυμι, στορέννυμι The Root is !στορ. to spread the clothes over a bed, λέχος στορέσαι, Lat. lectum sternere, to make up a bed, Il.; κλίνην ἔστρωσαν Hdt.; absol. to make a bed, χαμάδις στορέσας Od. generally to spread, strew, ἀνθρακιὴν στ. Il.; στιβάδας NTest. to spread smooth, level, πόντον στ., Lat. sternere aequor, Od.:—metaph. to calm, soothe, στορέσας ὀργήν Aesch. to level, lay low a tree, Anth.: metaph., λῆμα στ., Eur.; φρόνημα Thuc. ὁδὸν στ. to pave a road, Lat. viam sternere:—Pass., ἐστρωμένη ὁδός Hdt. to strew or spread with a thing, μυρσίνηισι τὴν ὁδόν Hdt.:—Pass., of a room, to be ready furnished, NTest.; cf. στρῶμα.

div1.head: στόρθυγξ
div1.sense: a point, the tyne of a deerʼs horn, Anth.

div1.head: στοχάζομαι
div1.sense: to aim or shoot at, c. gen., τοῦ σκοποῦ Plat., etc.
metaph. to aim at, endeavour after, Plat.; στ. φίλων κριτῶν to aim at having friends as judges, Xen.
to endeavour to make out, to guess at a thing, c. gen., Isocr.:— absol. to make guesses, conjecture, Soph., Xen.

div1.head: στόχασμα
div1.sense: the thing aimed, a javelin, Eur.

div1.head: στοχαστέος
div1.sense: one must aim at, τοῦ μέσου Arist.

div1.head: στοχαστικός
div1.sense: skilful in aiming at, able to hit, c. gen., Arist.
able to guess, sagacious, Plat.: adv., στοχαστικῶς ἔχειν to be sagacious, Arist.

div1.head: στόχος
div1.sense: an aim, shot, Eur.

div1.head: στραγγαλίζω
div1.sense: to strangle, Strab.

div1.head: στραγγεύομαι
div1.sense: Mid. to squeeze oneself up, twist oneself, metaph. to keep loitering about, Ar.

div1.head: στραγγουρία
div1.sense: retention of the urine, strangury, Ar.

div1.head: στράγξ
div1.sense: that which is squeezed out, a drop, Anth.

div1.head: στράπτω
div1.sense: to lighten, Soph.

div1.head: στρατάρχης
div1.sense: the general of an army, Hdt.

div1.head: στρατεία
div1.sense: an expedition, campaign, στρατηίην or -είαν ποιεῖσθαι Hdt., Thuc.; ἀπὸ στρατείας coming from war, after service done, Aesch.; κατὰ τὴν Σιτάλκου στρατείαν about the time of his expedition, Thuc.; ἐπὶ στρατείας or ἐν στρατείᾳ εἶναι to be on foreign service, Plat., Xen.: pl. military service, warfare, Plat.
στρ. ἡ ἐν τοῖς μέρεσιν, an expedition for special service, to train the young soldiers next after serving as περίπολοι, Aeschin.

div1.head: στράτευμα
div1.sense: an expedition, campaign, Hdt., Attic
an armament, army, Hdt., Attic:—also a naval armament, Soph., Thuc.
= στρατός, the host, people, Eur.

div1.head: στρατεύσιμος
div1.sense: fit for service, serviceable, Xen.

div1.head: στράτευσις
div1.sense: an expedition, Hdt.

div1.head: στρατευτέος
div1.sense: one must make an expedition, Xen.

div1.head: στρατεύω
div1.sense: to serve in war, serve as a soldier, do military service, take the field, march, Hdt., Attic; c. acc. cogn., στρ. στρατείαν Eur.
Dep. στρατεύομαι, fut. -εύσομαι: aor1 ἐστρατευσάμην and ἐστρατεύθην: perf. ἐστράτευμαι:—to serve, take the field, Lat. militari, Hdt.; ἐστρατευμένος having been a soldier, Ar.
to lead an army, march, Hdt., Attic

div1.head: στρατηγέω
div1.sense: to be general, Hdt., Attic:—c. gen. to be general of an army, Hdt., Attic:—to lead as general, c. dat., ἐστρατήγησε Λακεδαιμονίοισι Hdt.; c. acc. cogn., στρ. πόλεμον to conduct war, Dem.: with neut. adj., to do a thing as general, τοῦτο Xen.; πάντα Dem.:—Pass. to be conducted, Plat., Dem.
metaph., ποῦ σὺ στρατηγεῖς τοῦδε; how claimʼst thou to command this man? Soph.

div1.head: στρατηγία
div1.sense: the office, dignity, or post of general, command, Hdt., Attic; of naval command, Xen.
the office of στρατηγός at Athens, a sort of war-minister, Ar., Plat.:—at Rome the Praetorship, Plut.
a period of command, campaign, Xen.
the qualities or skill of a general, generalship, Xen.

div1.head: στρατηγιάω
div1.sense: to wish to be a general, wish to make war, Xen., Dem.

div1.head: στρατηγικός
div1.sense: of or for a general, Plat.:— ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) = στρατηγία II, Plat.;so, τὰ στρ. Xen.
of persons, fitted for command, versed in generalship, Xen., etc.:—adv. -κῶς, εὖ καὶ στρ. Ar.
at Rome, praetorian, Strab.

div1.head: στρατήγιον
div1.sense: the generalʼs tent, Lat. praetorium, Soph., Dem.
at Athens, the place where the στρατηγοί held their sittings, Aeschin.

div1.head: στρατηγίς
div1.sense: of the general, πύλαι στρ. the entrance of the general s tent, Soph.; ναῦς στρ. the admiralʼs ship, flag-ship, Thuc.; so, ἡ στρ. alone, Hdt.: at Rome, σπεῖρα στρ. the praetorian cohort, Plut.

div1.head: στρατηγός
div1.sense: the leader or commander of an army, a general, Hdt., Attic: generally, a commander, governor, Soph.

at Athens, the title of 10 officers elected yearly to command the army and navy, and conduct the war-department, with the Polemarch at their head, Hdt., Thuc., etc.; when distinguished from ναύαρχος and ἵππαρχος the στρατηγός is commander of the infantry, Dem.
one of the chief magistrates of several Greek cities, Hdt., Polyb.
στρ. ὕπατος, or στρατηγός alone, the Roman Consul, Polyb.; στρ. ἑξαπέλεκυς the Praetor, Polyb.:—also one of the duumviri or chief magistrates of Roman colonies, NTest.
an officer who had the custody of the Temple at Jerusalem, NTest.

div1.head: στρατηλασία
div1.sense: an expedition, campaign, Hdt.
the army itself, Hdt.

div1.head: στρατηλατέω
div1.sense: to lead an army into the field, Hdt., Aesch., etc.
c. gen. to be commander of, to command, Eur.; c. dat., Eur.

div1.head: στρατηλάτης
div1.sense: a leader of an army, a general, commander, Soph., Eur., etc.; of an admiral, στρ. νεῶν Aesch.

div1.head: στρατιά
div1.sense: an army, Aesch., Thuc., etc.: absol. a land force, as distinguished from a fleet, Hdt.
generally, a host, company, band, Pind.
= στρατεία, an expedition, Ar., Thuc.

div1.head: στράτιος
div1.sense: warlike, Hdt.

div1.head: στρατιώτης
div1.sense: a citizen bound to military service; generally, a soldier, Hdt., Attic; collectively, ὁ στρατιώτης the soldiers, Thuc.

div1.head: στρατιωτικός
div1.sense: of or for soldiers, Xen., etc.:— τὸ στρ. (sc. ἀργύριον) the pay of the forces, Dem.; but, τὸ στρ. (sc. πλῆθος) the soldiery, Thuc.; τὰ στρατιωτικά (sc. πράγματα) military affairs, Xen.
fit for a soldier, military, στρ. ἡλικία the military age, Xen.
warlike, soldierlike, γένη Arist.
adv. like a soldier, Isocr.:—of ships, στρατιωτικώτερον παρεσκευασμένοι equipped rather as troop-ships than for battle, Thuc.

div1.head: στρατιῶτις
div1.sense: as adj., στρ. ἀρωγά the martial aid, Aesch.
στρ. (sc. ναῦς) , a troop-ship, transport, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: στρατολογέω
div1.sense: to levy soldiers: Pass., Plut.

div1.head: στρατόμαντις
div1.sense: prophet to the army, Aesch.

div1.head: στρατοπεδάρχης
div1.sense: a military commander, Lat. tribunus legionis, Luc.

div1.head: στρατοπέδευσις
div1.sense: an encamping, Xen.
an encampment, the position of an army, Xen.

div1.head: στρατοπεδευτικός
div1.sense: of an encampment, Polyb.

div1.head: στρατοπεδεύω
div1.sense: to encamp, bivouac, take up a position, Xen.:
as Dep. στρατοπεδεύομαι, Hdt., Thuc., etc.; perf. ἐστρατοπεδεῦσθαι to be in camp, Xen.: of a fleet, to be stationed, Hdt.

div1.head: στρατόπεδον
div1.sense: the ground on which soldiers are encamped, a camp, encampment, Hdt., Aesch.:— hence, a camp, encamped army, Hdt., Thuc.
generally, an army, Hdt.; also, a squadron of ships, Hdt., Thuc.
the Roman legion, Polyb.

div1.head: στρατός
div1.sense: an encamped army, generally, an army, host, ἀνὰ στρατόν or κατὰ στρ. throughout the army, Hom.; Epic gen. στρατόφι Il.; of a naval force, Aesch., etc.
the soldiery, people, exclusive of the chiefs, Hom.: so, the commons, people, Pind., Aesch.
any band or body of men, Pind.

div1.head: στρατοφύλαξ
div1.sense: a commanding officer, Strab.

div1.head: στρατόω
div1.sense: to lead to war; only found in aor1 pass. part. στρατωθέν (sc. στόμιον) the curb formed by the army, Aesch.: v. στρατάω.

div1.head: Στρατωνίδης
div1.sense: Comic patronymic, son of the army, Ar.

div1.head: στρεβλός
div1.sense: twisted, crooked, Arist.; of the brows, knit, wrinkled, Anth.: metaph., στρεβλοῖσι παλαίσμασι by cunning dodges in wrestling, Ar.

div1.head: στρεβλότης
div1.sense: crookedness, Plut.

div1.head: στρεβλόω
div1.sense: to twist or strain tight, στρ. τὰ ὅπλα ὄνοισι to draw the cables taut with windlasses, Hdt.: to screw up the strings of an instrument, Plat.
to twist or wrench a dislocated limb, with a view to setting it, Hdt.
to stretch on the wheel or rack, to rack, torture, Ar.:—Pass., στρεβλοῦσθαι ἐπὶ τροχοῦ Ar.
metaph. to pervert or distort words, NTest.

div1.head: στρέμμα
div1.sense: a wrench, strain, sprain, Dem.

div1.head: στρέπταιγλος
div1.sense: whirling-bright, Ar.

div1.head: στρεπτός
div1.sense: flexible, pliant: στρεπτὸς χιτών a shirt of chain-armour, Lat. lorica annulata, Il.; στρεπταὶ λύγοι pliant withs, Eur.: twined, wreathed, Anth.
στρεπτός, οῦ, a collar of twisted or linked metal, Lat. torques, Hdt., Xen., etc.
of pastry, a twist or roll, Dem.
metaph. to be bent or turned, στρεπτοὶ καὶ θεοὶ αὐτοί the gods themselves may be turned (by prayer), Il.; στρ. γλῶσσα a glib, pliant tongue, Il.
bent, curved, of a pick-axe, Eur.; of a bow, Theocr.

div1.head: στρεπτοφόρος
div1.sense: wearing a collar, Lat. torquatus, Hdt.

div1.head: στρεύγω
div1.sense: Mid.-Pass. to be squeezed out in drops: metaph. to be drained of oneʼs strength, exhausted, Hom.

div1.head: στρεφεδινέω
div1.sense: to spin or whirl something round: Pass., ὄσσε οἱ στρεφεδίνηθεν (for -νήθησαν) his eyes span round, of one stunned by a blow on the nape of the neck, Il.

div1.head: στρέφω
div1.sense: to turn about or aside, turn, Hom., etc.; στρ. ἵππους to turn or guide horses, Il.; στρ. σάκος to sway the shield, Soph.
ἄνω καὶ κάτω στρ. to turn upside down, Aesch., Plat.; so, κάτω στρ. Soph.; so, στρέφειν alone, to overturn, upset, Eur.
to twist a rope, Xen.
metaph. of pain, to twist, torture, Ar., Plat.
to twist, plait, ἐστραμμένα Xen.: to spin, Luc.
metaph. to turn a thing over in oneʼs mind, τί στρέφω τάδε; Eur., Dem.
to turn from the right course, divert, embezzle, Lys.
Pass. and Mid. to turn oneself, to turn round or about, turn to and fro, Il.; ἔνθα καὶ ἔνθα στρέφεσθαι, of one tossing in bed, Il.
to turn to or from an object, to turn back, return, Il., Soph.; στραφέντες ἔφευγον Xen.
of the heavenly bodies, to revolve, Od.; of the distaff, Plat.

to twist about, like a wrestler trying to elude his adversary; so, in argument, to twist and turn, shuffle, τί ταῦτα στρέφει; why dʼye shuffle so? Ar.; τί δῆτα ἔχων στρέφει; why then do you keep shuffling, Plat.; πάσας στροφὰς στρέφεσθαι to twist every way, Plat.
to turn and change, Soph.; τοῦ δὲ σοῦ ψόφου οὐκ ἂν στραφείην I would not turn for any noise of thine, Soph.
to twist oneself up with a thing, stick close to it, Od.:—then, like Lat. versari, to be always engaged, Plat.
generally, to be at large, go about Soph.
ἐστραμμένος, η, ον, of places, ἐστρ. ἐπὶ τόπον turned towards, Polyb.
in strict Mid. sense, to turn about with oneself, take back, Soph.
intr. in Act., like Pass. to turn about, Il.; of soldiers, to wheel about, Xen.

div1.head: στρεψοδικέω
div1.sense: to twist justice, Ar.

div1.head: στρεψοδικοπανουργία
div1.sense: cunning in the perversion of justice, Ar.

div1.head: στρηνής
div1.sense: strong, hard, rough, harsh: neut. as adv., Anth.

div1.head: στρηνιάω
div1.sense: to run riot, wax wanton, NTest.

div1.head: στρῆνος
div1.sense: wantonness, NTest.

div1.head: στριβιλικίγξ
div1.sense: Comic word, οὐδʼ ἂν στριβιλικίγξ not the least, not a fraction, Ar.

div1.head: στροβέω
